Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, James DeBello, Cerina Vincent, Joey Kern, Giuseppe Andrews and Richard Fullerton star in this 2002 horror film. This begins with a hermit in the woods getting food for his dog and becomes infected by a lethal flesh-eating virus. We then meet a group of college friends, Paul (Strong), Karen (Ladd), Bert (DeBello), Marcy (Vincent) and Jeff (Kern) who head to a cabin in the woods for a week. Soon, Bert encounters the infected hermit and the nightmare begins when he and the others start catching the disease and fight to stay alive. Andrews plays Sheriff Deputy Winston and Fullerton plays the Sheriff who discover what's happening with them. This isn't a bad horror flick and the make-up effects by K.N.B. are great as usual. The film pays homage to "The Evil Dead," "Outbreak," "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" and "Night of the Living Dead" with a bit of humor and the director, Eli Roth also makes a cameo as Grim. I recommend this.

Review title: Liked the title, enjoyed the movie
Review_body: Here is a movie that is dealing with a flesh-eating disease caused by a pollutant. It sounds familiar, but that's what "Cabin Fever" is about. I liked the setting of the movie, and the cast was great too. Cheryl Ladd's daughter Jordan, very beautiful. The others very cool looking as well. I liked the part where they go to the general store and they see the rifle on the rack, and the old man used a racial slur that angered the teen couples. Don't blame them whatsoever. When they go out into the cabins. The movie title proves its point, but in a different way. Find the source of the pollution way easy, but how would a corpse would cause such damage? For the people at the general store, I sure was fooled. The old man wasn't as racist as anybody thought he was. The African-American travelers were into hunting as well as anyone. And he was talking hip-hop like, he was cool. Depsite what went on in the movie, it was very watchable. I wish the critics were easy on this film. What's their problem? I've never complained about it. It was great! Rating 3 out of 5 stars.

Here we go again into idiocy and mediocrity, or so I thought with my first viewing of "Cabin Fever," another tailor-made, teen horror flick ready for consumption by the braindead, MTV-energized masses of blood/sex-crazed adolescents.Five friends have (unwisely) chosen to venture into the woods for a week-long vacation. They end up spending their time in one of those big, spooky cabins that brings back memories of another classic horror film that took place in the woods ("The Evil Dead," anyone?). As you would know it, the friends all start coming down with the symptoms of an unknown contagion, and alas, they realize that they've all been infected with a flesh-eating virus, which causes all kinds of nasty scabs and copious amounts of blood to form on the skin through no visible wounds. The friends all naturally start to panic ("Don't touch him/her!" or "I am getting the hell out of here!") and pretty much everything starts to come apart between them (pretty much like society would if there really was a deadly virus on the loose; more on this later)."Cabin Fever" took a lot of people by surprise last September. I noticed that the film was completed in 2002 but its release was delayed until last year, probably because of the very real and scary S.A.R.S. outbreaks in Asia and Canada. The movie itself has quite a lot of tension, shockingly gross special effects (watch out for that bathtub shaving scene), and some very bizarre dark humor, mostly involving the locals. For a horror film, I wouldn't recommend showing this one to the kiddies as they might be frightened by some of the horrific things that they see on screen.What I picked up from the film is that it attempts to be a parable on one of the great scare stories of our time  the unknown, out-of-control virus. It works on the premise that somewhere out there, maybe in the forest or a top-secret lab, lurks a virus so deadly that if it got out, would unleash hell on earth.To further deliver that terrifying notion, the friends pretty much serve as a stable society that's about to become very "unstable." ENTER: a dissident, a catalyst; something to throw this society into a panic that it would eventually fall into and never recover  in this case, that catalyst is a lethal virus that to quote Dustin Hoffman from 1995's "Outbreak," "Is one-billionth our size and it's killing us." This formerly stable society starts to crumble under its own paranoia and fear as the virus spreads and kills whomever/whatever it comes into contact with; the friends (society) start to become suspicious of one another, instead of trying to work together to stamp the virus out. And well, it is anarchy from that point on... ...And the ending further proves that anarchy will reign supreme if a sequel is ever produced.

Review title: There made little to funny to take serious
Review_body: I thought it was time to re-watch this,as there are another two upcoming movies for this series.I have not seen this movie for years but i don't remember the acting being really bad the last time i saw it , The written for this felt all over the place but I did enjoy the main plot of the movie,it wasn't just another bunch of collage kids going into woods and getting killed by a mask killer but this is was some kind of infection that peels your skin off.Which i thought was really good idea, it could have been better if didn't have to many funny moment in this movie.The ending of the movie was really funny and it as it wss nod to The Night of the living dead ending!5 out of 10

Review title: . I want more like this film gushing blood vomit fest .
Review_body:
I kept reading about members of this thread talking about Eli Roth and the AMC s Eli Roth's History of Horror. I have not seen any of his films . I decided to check out ' Cabin Fever ' . I know I am probably the only person in this thread to not see it as I always thought I look like garbage . But since I started following this thread I have expanded my Horror repertoire. I was right 'Cabin Fever' was garbage . Well not so fast . I was bored with the lame acting and was suffering the Net as I watched . But about 2/3rd through the film . Eli Roth really stared ti ramp up the entire film by like 100% . He introduced a black sheep deputy sheriff who was hilarious. Spoiler but not to bad . At one point the deputy sheriff gets a call from the 'Sheriff' asking if he had found the crazy party in the woods at this point the deputy sheriff had found the crazy party and was in full participation drinking beer and smoking weed instead of busting up the party. Funny as hell. That when I shut off my PC and was engaged . Then 'Cabin Fever' went for a crap film to a blood bath of gore and black comedy . The red necks out for revenge was graet. The weird kid that bits " Pancake's pancake's what a trip. The infection that ramps up and spreads killing in glorious blood soaking vomit splashing gore fest . Bottom line the film did a 180 and it turn out to be very satisfying. And the bluegrass music at the end of film was the cherry on top. I want more like this film gushing blood vomit fest .
First hour 2/10 Last 32 minutes 10/10'Cabin Fever' 8/10 order it on Blu-ray for my collection.

Review title: This didn't receive great reviews but I sure had fun watching it
Review_body: I liked this, granted it had its moments of weirdness. A real mix of horror, comedy and gross-out gore but it worked for me. Its a bit of a throwback film to the chillers of the 1970's, cliché in its initial set up following a group of college friends who embark on a last hurrah after college vacation deep into the mountains to spend a week at a remote cabin.They meet several strange/bizarre townsfolk along the way and then on their first night encounter a man who is "sick" his flesh literally melting off his face as he vomits blood all over their vehicle. In trying to get rid of the man they accidentally set him on fire and he runs off into the bushes. Before long our group starts to show signs of a horrible flesh eating disease, with the fear of contagion driving them to turn on each other.This didn't receive great reviews but I had helluva fun watching it. It was disgusting, disturbing, funny, full of WTF moments, bizarre characters and left me afraid to drink the water as well as seriously wondering about the motivation of (the director) and Kung-Fu kid yelling 'PANCAKE". 11/1/15

Review title: ELI ROTH'S DEBUT FILM IS A BLOOD SOAKED MASTERPIECE!!!
Review_body:
I have absolutely loved Eli Roth's now cult classic "CABIN FEVER" ever since i first saw it in the cinema on a rainy Autumn afternoon & i just loved everything about it, actually it's always been a favourite Horror movie of mine & one of my most watched films ever!!!
A very very rare thing is about this great film is the bunch of "kids" are a group i really liked, except maybe "Bert" lol he was an idiot but funny, i really like that group & most or nearly all Horror films have a bunch of kids/ teens that you hate & really want them to die except maybe like one person!!!
Eli Roth also served us the best possible mix of Horror & Comedy, so we are shocked at the gore but can laugh at the kids reactions or over panicked state, it's the best blend I've ever seen in a Horror-comedy.It's now 2018 & i still think Cabin fever is Roth's best film, everything is just great Horror fun with excellent performances & a group of kids you actually like & want to survive.
Yep back in 2002 when Cabin fever came out it was a huge Horror hit & made on a tiny budget but Eli pulled it off as a fun throwback to the crazy, silly & funny 80's Horror flicks!!! It's pure late night entertainment!!!
The cast is excellent especially the underrated "RIDER STRONG" who really is great as the lead in this film, he's the guy you really want to survive & Rider gives a great performance like a young "Bruce Campbell" did in the first 1981 "Evil Dead" he's that good in this & infact Rider Strong became a go to guy for lots of low budget Horror movies after Cabin fever, some are good like the terrifying Borderland (2007) & the fun Tooth & Nail (2007) & some that was terrible like Pulse 3 (2008) & Cabin fever 2 (2009) both terrible lol but another good Horror Thriller flick Rider starred in was Death Valley (2004) that was a good film so He became a new Horror icon in a way like how the brilliant "Tom Atkins" started out!!!Cabin Fever is equally as great as the "classic" Horror's of the past such as those that inspired this movie such as Evil Dead (1981),The Thing (1982), Texas chainsaw massacre (1974), Deliverance (1972) & many more that's how BRILLIANT Cabin Fever is & how important this is to the Horror genre!!!!
This has become one of my favourite "Horror" films of all time & one of my personal favourite movies of all time!!!"ELI ROTH" completely gets WHAT we all love in Horror, that balance of deranged humour & gory scares & because Roth was a Horror film geek before becoming a director he so knows what horror fans wanna see, he nailed it with Cabin fever & he won't ever beat the impact this had on the Horror genre at the time!!! Thank you Roth for being a perfectionist & that's why his Cabin fever looks beautiful & not just a cheap looking indie film.Cabin Fever has that proper vintage throwback feel of filthy-nasty-savage 70's & early 80's trashy grindhouse cinema but made with more skill & style than those made back then.I can't praise the excellent performance by "Rider Strong" enough as his "Paul" character goes through hell & goes from average timid teen to savage survival Hero, through the movie his character is the best written & Rider gives it his all with alot of emotion, heart & brings it up way above average for a low budget Horror!!! Infact Paul is one of the best written Horror heroe's in the genre & to me he's as good as "Bruce Campbell" in the first "Evil Dead" as both characters are put in similar survival circumstances & go from average joe to badass hero.
Also "Rider Strong" at the time of getting the role in "Cabin fever" really wanted to get as far away from his wholesome wimpy heartthrob character from the t.v series "Boy Meets World" & that was a great move for him as here's this young guy from the world of sickly sweet "Disney" series to a bloody gruesome gritty splatter flick, where he has sex & kills rednecks & gets absolutely covered in blood!!! A great part for him as the audience gets a nice comforting familiar feel seeing him in the movie, but he is becomes a savage killer in order to survive, he was perfectly cast in my opinion.It's a shame "Rider Strong" didn't become a breakout star after "Cabin fever" as he proved he is a great actor & can be a great unexpected lead.
Well in my opinion he made one of the best Horror movie hero characters come to life from the pages of Eli Roth's debut masterpiece classic & roth has still never done better!!!
Eli Roth does know the Horror genre & his Cabin fever is a brilliant homage to those old school 70's & 80's glory days of Horror like i said & it was so refreshing when it came out & with that decent cast!!!
Also another excellent performance is from "Joey Kern" as Jeff that's my 2nd fave performance after "Strong's" Performance.
My favourite scene is the Awesome sequence where "Paul" savagely kills the three rednecks that come to the Cabin to kill the teens, it's such an exciting,intense & bloody scene, just amazing!!!Cabin fever is a great Horror film that is gross out & fun & very violent but with great characters & a sense of fun, the cabin looks beautiful & old & full of history like the cool "Evil Dead" cabin, you feel there's a deep history behind that lonely old Cabin in the middle of the woods!!!
The flesh eating virus is terrifying & all too real, the local rednecks are scary but all done with that 80's sense of fun & when there is some very serious scenes the mood & atmosphere is perfect!!! Eli Roth just gets it all right in this movie, his other films are very good but it's his Debut that is the "Classic" or "Masterpiece" of his career.
There's so many good elements to this movie it's hard to name them all & so many nice little gems of scenes & imagery, like the Fall setting with all the crispy leaves falling & the ground covered with the colours of Autumn it looks beautiful!!!
Also the music score by Nathan Barr is amazing!!!
I am a "Rider Strong" fan because of his excellent performance as "Paul" in Cabin fever!!! A Nostalgic Horror CLASSIC to me & one I've watched hundreds of times & it never gets boring & that's the sign of a classic film!!!
Also it's a perfect Horror to watch over the Halloween season as it's set in the lovely Autumn time & the over all tone is very primal survival Thriller & bloody virus body Horror with some humour & heart full of 80's Horror fun.
The people that hate on this excellent film are the ones who really don't get that demented blood soaked comedy Horror from the 80's but i do & i loved it probably even more than most Horror's from that era!!!Cabin fever is still director Eli Roth's best film & it came out way back in 2002 but that's how good & how much fun it is as a proper well made bloody survival Horror film with some funny moments but at it's heart it's a proper Horror movie loving crafted like the one's we all grew up on so thank you Eli Roth.
Cabin fever is in my top 5 fave Horror movies of all time & it's genuinely one of my top 10 fave movies of all time.Perfect late night entertainment & definitely one of the best Horror choices at a sleepover it's that good.

Review title: Bloody, Gory, Dark, and Comic - Not For Everyone.
Review_body: I saw Cabin Fever in the theater during it's national release (September 12, 2003), and I remember seeing the previews on TV and thinking "Holy crap that looks scary!", but it wasn't scary at all. The advertisements made it look more supernatural, but it was exactly the opposite. I was expecting something like "The Shining" perhaps, but "Cabin Fever" is so very far from that."Cabin Fever" follows five college students who rent a cabin in the woods to celebrate their graduation, have one fun time before entering the real world. Then one night at the campfire, a horribly sick man approaches them, his flesh deteriorating, and they accidentally light him on fire. Guilty and scared, they decide to find help, but then Karen begins to get sick, and she seems to have to same virus as the man did. The true colors of the group begin to show, as they turn on each other and end up doing horrible things to try and avoid catching the mysterious virus. Kind of funny who it didn't matter if they were around the ones who were infected, because the virus was actually in the water system they were drinking from. This entire film is basically a nasty, sometimes comic bloodbath. The actors were good here and the secluded setting was also good, but the movie failed to scare me. It was more fun and games than just downright horror, more of a dark comedy. Dark comedy isn't bad, but it's just not what I was expecting from this movie. Maybe if it had been advertised differently, I would have enjoyed it more, but it just wasn't what I was expecting it to be. 7/10.

Review title: Extremely dumb horror film has the unexpected flair of style at several moments.
Review_body: When five friends (Rider Strong, Jordon Ladd, James DeBello, Cerina Vincent & Joey Kern) decide to spend a weekend deep into the woods. Thinking that they will have the greatest spring break until a strange man (Arie Verveen). Which this man is infected with an incurable disease. When the man was attacked seeking for help from the these five young people. The five friends accidentally set him on fire and he runs off to the woods burning. When he turns up dead on a pond, the virus from his body spreads slowly to the Cabin. Where these five people are staying. When one of them gets sick, they realized that anyone could be next. Now they turn to each other and the rest of the town realize that the disease is the least of their problems.Directed by first time filmmaker:Eli Roth (Hostel) makes this darkly humour horror film, that is at times genuinely scary and funny. Roth also appears in a cameo. Roth is also one of the film's producers. Roth also receives story credit and co-writing the screenplay. Guiseppe Andrews, who is better known from the film "Detroit Rock City". Andrews has a funny bit role as a fun loving party going deputy. This film was shot under $2 Million and it looks great, thanks to Scott Keven's excellent cinematography. There's terrific Make-Up Effects work by KNB EFX Inc (Evil Dead 2, Army of Darkness, Land of the Dead). There is also an fine music score by Nathan Barr and Angelo Badalamenti (Better known as David Lynch's Composer).DVD features five commentaries tracks! Which is all done by the director:Roth (Who seems to be really proud of the film). Roth does have a solo commentary. Roth shares his other four commentary tracks with the cast, filmmakers, friends and his parents! DVD also has an behind the scenes featurette, director's animated shorts and more. DVD has an sharp anamorphic Widescreen (2.35:1) transfer and an terrific-Dolby Digital 5.1 Surround Sound. This film is not the for the squeamish but the film is actually well received by several top critics and including Oscar-Winner Director:Peter Jackson (The Lord of the Rings Trilogy) loves this film! This movie does take it's time to start moving but do not miss this unique black horror comedy. Which is certainly worth a look. Super 35. (***/*****).

Review title: Note To Cerina Vincent: Call Me!
Review_body: As a borderline hypochondriac myself, I must confess that the thought of necrotizing fasciitis--more popularly known as the flesh-eating virus--gives me the heebie-jeebies. (And for those viewers who think this disease is some kind of joke or urban myth, all I can say is, take a look at some of the hideous pictures that the Wikipedia site displays in its article for this subject!) Thus, I just knew that the 2003 film "Cabin Fever"--in which a group of teens rents an idyllic retreat in an autumnal setting but soon contracts this dreaded illness from a wandering bum--would be a fairly intense experience for me. And, thanks to the great work done by co-writer, producer and director Eli Roth, as well as his quintet of young actors, man, was I ever right!In the film, as our five teens drive to their wilderness retreat, David Hess' song "Wait for the Rain" is heard playing on their car stereo; the same song that had presaged the doom of the two young gals in Wes Craven's repugnant "Last House on the Left," and a sure sign, with its memorable line "and the road leads to nowhere," that trouble is brewing. (If I were to ever hear this tune played when I was outside, I would probably immediately rush back home to huddle indoors!) And for the five teens--three guys, played by Rider Strong, James De Bello and Joey Kern, and two truly beautiful young women, played by Jordan Ladd and Cerina Vincent--that trouble erupts fairly quickly. To the film's great credit, these five are all likable and differentiated types, and their reactions to their horrible health crisis--only compounded when the whacky locals decide they must be wiped out--are credible and realistic. "Cabin Fever" begins on a humorous note but quickly gets a lot more serious, only shading back toward levity, unbecomingly and ironically, in its final few minutes. Besides the Craven film mentioned above, the film tips its hat in homage to such horror classics as "The Texas Chain Saw Massacre" and, given the final fate of the Joey Kern character, "Night of the Living Dead." First-time director Roth, two years before working on his first "Hostel" film, displays great flair and imagination here; it is at times difficult to believe that "Cabin Fever" was his first go behind the camera! The film's special FX are just fine, though the gross-out images here are far less disturbing than those Wiki shots I mentioned earlier. The monster that Jordan Ladd's character becomes is perhaps the most shocking, especially when shown, contrapuntally in flashback, next to her gorgeous former self. "Cabin Fever" boasts many impressive and memorable scenes, especial standouts, for this viewer, being the gruesome spectacle of Cerina shaving her legs in a bathtub, that mentally disturbed kid screaming "Pancakes" as he sinks his teeth into one of the teen's hands, and those "Christian" rednecks coming after the De Bello character with their shotguns. In all, the film IS an extremely intense yet enjoyable experience, and a truly superior modern-day horror wringer. It was hugely profitable on its initial release, and deservedly so. To end on a lighter note, that Wiki article tells us that those prone to necrotizing fasciitis include people who are immunocompromised, diabetics, those with malignancies or chronic systemic diseases, and those who abuse drugs and alcohol. Care to take a guess as to which group our quintet of teens falls into?

Truly one of the weirdest films i've ever encountered, Cabin Fever starts out strong, but ultimately feels too messy and too uneven to go any of the bold places it tries to go. The film is a weird combination of zombie flick, comedy, horror, isolation, parody, and so much more- it's hard to understand what they were exactly going for while making it. I enjoyed the beginning of the film, an amusing and obvious tribute to films like Evil Dead but as it goes on, it takes itself to a strangely dramatic and underwhelming place. The acting is all over the place, the look of the film is super 2000's- whether that's a good thing or not I don't know- but the fun little soundtrack at hand proves to be the only thing along with the look that the film is consistent with. The pacing can be a drag, the last 15 minutes are certainly a step in the right direction, but in the end Cabin Fever is too much of a mixed bag to be worth watching- and too all over the place to be enjoyable.
My Rating: 5/10

Review title: Eli Roth is not a good writer or director.
Review_body: I have seen both this and Hostel and I realize what Eli loves. He loves nonstop drug use and really loud music, all set to no plot. I hate this movie. It's about a group of teenagers who go out in the forest and a horrible disease plagues them. It's a lame game of ten little indians where the characters are totally one dimmensional, and not only do you not care if they get killed, you want them to get killed. I just can't explain how bad this truly is. it's as though Mr. Roth just put together a bunch of stupid ideas and put them into a stupid movie. The ending is pretty much stolen from "Night of the Living Dead" except for the hillbillies playing the guitars. I miss the old horror movies, where they were amusing, and ACTUALLY SCARY!!!! My rating: 1/10. 88 mins. R for drug use, sex, nudity, language and violence.

Here is an exciting movie, with a good story, some really twisted humour, and plenty of chills and thrills.  I haven't been this satisfied by a scary movie in a while, and everything is just perfectly set up.  We get some really exciting jolts, and unexpected twists.  I couldn't help comparing it "28 Hours" and thinking how much better this one was.  Go in, and get ready for some serious fun.

Review title: Yes, it did make me want to run outside
Review_body:
**SPOILER ALERT
I thought it started out sort of clever - two of the guys saying they'd drink only beer for the rest of the (ha, ha) 'vacation' - it seemed like a good way for the script to explain what I presumed would be their survival.
But then it all just turned to garbage, melodrama and stupidity galore.
Much as one enjoys seeing obnoxious teens suffering, you can do better than this by watching practically anything else. I do like the one guy that was in "Detroit Rock City" and I saw him in something else w/Jonathan Tucker.   Hope he gets a real chance in a good movie soon, but this wasn't it.  1/10.

As much as I dislike the films of Eli Roth, I found this entry in his oeuvre to be his most palatable. While this movie isn't good, it does seem to play with a lot of tropes, and it seems to have fun doing it. There's a cool concept here, and even if it isn't executed in the best way possible it is interesting, and there are some decent scenes. As a whole I'm pretty ambivalent about this movie; it's all right, but nothing spectacular... that blood-vomiting scene was pretty freaking hysterical though...

Review title: Heady horror, but an original 'comedy' of errors
Review_body: Cabin Fever is one of those movies where people make split second decisions that have monumental consequences. It's entertaining. You go through the movie, well into it, still somewhat amazed that if only they'd taken door B rather than door A the whole scenario would have been far less extreme. It's clever writing and the filmmaker justly deserves his accolades. Cabin Fever is an exciting watch, no problem, easily worth an 8. The joker in the pack is an oddity that I found somewhat irreconcilable with my brain without making a sympathetic effort. He looks way too old to be a 13 year old brat. To a lesser degrees his companions, both showing signs of early baldness, also look beyond their just-made-it-to-collage status. They are all great actors, as are the other characters, it's a fun movie.I also had a look at the 2016 remake. It's basically the same movie save for being far more scenic with a better edit. What I found difficult was rather than reigning in the paradoxes in the ages and behaviour, the new movie seems to exacerbates them. I got bored before the end and didn't finish it, but that's only because it became obvious that the same things were going to happen.

An escapist trip becomes the stuff of nightmares and uncontrollable paranoia for the five college kids who meet something nasty in the woods they've come to find solace in. Eli Roth, a self-confessed admirer of all things horror and gore, brings quite a bit of atmosphere into his okay story but fails to establish the one important thing that could have made his film better: a close relationship between the audience and the main characters. It does seem to hurt his story, since we never get to find out why this infection is taking place or anything about these kids (and the young actors play their underwritten parts like they're in a much larger production). All we know is that Roth is setting them up for something incomprehensible and gory. Maybe I'm being too demanding because CABIN FEVER does deliver even when it's average in comparison to other body-horror films. Overall, a nice debut from Roth.

Some college students decide to spend their vacation in a strange house in a strange forest. Then, some weirdo guy shows up and their car breaks. I know it may not sound particularly original..."Cabin Fever" is one of those movies that you know everyone will end up dead-- and maybe one of them "makes it" in the end. The actors aren't known, but their acting is decent and enough for this kind of film. Hot girls, pretty guys and the party is ready. Direction, along with editing, deliver a scary and tense atmosphere that will probably frighten and entertain you. Some scenes are really agonizing to see, such as the bath's -- I confess I put my hand on my eyes in this part. The 93 minutes of running seem to go very quickly and the writer doesn't delay the story; things happen all the time. My only complaints are that sometimes it gets too gory for my young stomach, and the bizarre ending. Aside that, it is all that it promises.

Review title: Good Entry For A First Timer
Review_body: Here is our buddy Eli Roth, the new whiz kid in horror (or so I've been told) I figured I'd give more then one of his films a chance (second chance actually). Cabin Fever stars Boy Meets World favourite Shaun Hunter, or by his real name Rider Strong, which is also a good porn name. Also, Jordan Ladd plays his girlfriend. Along with their friends they go up to a Cabin to celebrate graduating. Things go bad when one gets a flesh eating disease and the friends turn on each other for survival.Sound familiar? Well, it's basically a remake of Evil Dead, with changes here and there. Instead of the undead, it's simply a flesh eating disease. There you go, same movie. The big difference is Evil Dead is pure genius, where Cabin Fever is a poor imitator.Why doesn't Cabin Fever play out like a decent homage to older scary horror films, because it's tries to be better then what it actually is. Cabin Fever is a B horror film that thinks it's actually scary. I'm sorry, but it isn't.One main problem is the atmosphere. What made Evil Dead scary was that the cabin was in the middle of nowhere. They were stuck and had no place to go. Here, there is a town not ten minutes away. Get in car, go to town, or better yet go home, movie over. I just couldn't get into it knowing that salvation was minutes away. The suspense is all gone.If it's not ripping off Evil Dead (Roth can call it homage all he wants, but it was a rip-off) then it's Night Of The Living Dead. Straight up, one character dies exactly the same way as another in the original Night of the Living Dead. When a film has a homage, there is a wink and a nod, Cabin Fever never winks or nods, he straight up steals. Not to mention half the audience watching this probably doesn't even know what films it is 'homaging'.Now I know Roth loves horror films and I know his intentions might have been good, but it just doesn't come across in the same manner, to me at least. the guy isn't a bad director, he just needs better, more original material.I enjoyed the make-up though. That was probably the most scary thing. I do give credit for what he accomplish though. First film and all, much better then his later efforts with Hostel. Cabin Fever is something that I might like years later, which is why this rating is really generous.Also...pancakes?

Yes. Well; As the publisher Anthony Blond once said; 'story is something that happens to someone you have been moved to care about.' I did not care about any character in this movie. Ergo; there was no story.It began as typically as all teen horror movies have always begun. A bunch of silly, shallow, hedonistic, impractical, irrational, self-centred brats find themselves confronted by something that's not very nice. It might be a blob. It might be a chainsaw in Texas. It could certainly be zombies. It might be Micheal Myers. It could even be Freddie Kruger. Crikey; it might even be some strange bloke with a seemingly incurable, rampant contagion wandering about in a forest.Whatever the case, its a cue for them to begin dying in the most disagreeable circumstances that any second-rate, unimaginative director can dream up.There have actually been some fairly well-made movies of this genre, though non actually come to mind. But this one is a plucked turkey.The prettier the babes, the more likely they are going to meet some especially grisly come-uppance. Whereas the 'dudes' - advertising their frivolous unreliability with backward-pointing baseball caps - will squabble and fall-out.Every little tired cliché happened by the numbers. Although I had never seen this movie before, I talked it through almost every trite little chill. You knew that one would fall in the water, fiddling about with the corpse. You knew that the sole survivor would get blown away at the very moment of triumph. You knew that they would never manage to shoot the dog. You knew that it wouldn't be the end of the matter when all of the juvenile protagonists had been slaughtered.I brought no expectations to this movie, but always a little hope. It is possible to do the thing in a believable, harrowing, and horrific way. It's simple, straightforward formula. But it wasn't used here.There are lots of interesting movies that touch upon a similar theme. There's the 'Living Dead' franchise. There's 'The Crazies'. Crikey; there's even John Carpenter's seminal 'The Thing'. OK; these don't entail teenagers, but whoever said that adolescents were interesting? Other adolescents, that's all.If you want formulaic crap; this is it. If you want a decent chiller; look elsewhere.

Review title: I Think This Film Hates Me
Review_body: This film is about a group of five friends who rent a cabin in the woods. One of the friends catches a horrifying flesh-eating virus. Suddenly, the friends turn on one another in a desperate attempt to keep from contracting the disease themselves."Cabin Fever" is a horrible film. For one, it tries to be many genres at once. Is it supposed to be a homage, a slasher, a black comedy, or a scary movie with unintentional comedy? Nobody can tell. There's a serious scene at first and a second alter, it turns funny. When the film tries to be funny, the humor is quite bland, excluding the ending. I liked the ending a lot.But apart from the ending, I was pretty disappointed and disgusted. The violence is cringe-worthy, more looking away from the screen than being scared. The tone changes within each scene, sometimes funny, sometimes scary, and sometimes quite random. In fact, you see a girl doing karate in slo-motion. What are we supposed to get from that? This same girl would bite one of the characters. Was that supposed to be funny? I don't know.Some of the performances were decent, and many were quite amateurish. I didn't care for most of the characters. I liked the plot but the execution was done horribly. As a horror film, I didn't know what it was trying to be. I didn't find it funny, tense, nor scary. By the end, you're left indifferent, thinking, "What have I just been through?" Unfortunately, you'll never know the answer to that question.

Review title: A Laughable Horror Flick, but i enjoyed it
Review_body: A group of college students head up to a remote cabin for a weekend of alcohol and sex, but when one of them becomes sick; they begin to turn on each other.Cabin Fever is funnier than it is scary, in fact it is questionable whether it is in fact scary at all, but it is certainly entertaining and it's packed with gruesome gore and corny lines. The humour is not present because it's a low budget production or the acting is wooden, the effects are actually pretty good and so are the cast. Cabin Fever was funny because it was meant to be, it never takes itself seriously for a moment and the script is deliberately loaded with cheesy lines.As a pure comedy its not great, as a horror movie its not great, but as an entertaining comedy horror flick is hits the spot, and it may well become a cult movie in years to come.6/10
I had watched in tamil dubbed...It was not great but still feel good horror movie... Thnks for tamilrockers to introduced this movie..

The whole idea of this film is pretty basic: it's the usual five kids taking a trip to a cabin in the woods, and so on. However, the approach is a bit different. While the movie is extremely bloody, and some parts are pretty shocking, the fact is that it's just all really funny. The characters were believable enough, but they were also presented in an unfavorable light that made them easy to laugh at. It was as if Eli Roth did not take any of his characters all that seriously, so he had no trouble making fun of them. The humorous twist made watching this movie a highly enjoyable experience. Also, I found it intriguing how after the initial encounter with the diseased man, the only threat was the possibility of being infected. I think this helped the film to seem more realistic and more terrifying than if it had gone in the more typical direction of having the kids fight off the same already-dead people for the duration of the movie.The film contains a number of tributes to classic horror films that are sure to please any fan, yet is still original and brilliant in its own right. It has everything: blood, suspense, humor, a great score, and an ending that is ironic and amusing.B+

Review title: Eli Roth makes his debut and for better or worse makes it loud and unapoloetically Roth
Review_body: Set in the backwoods area of Bunyan County, five college students come to a rented cabin for a vacation of sex, drinking, drugs, and debauchery. However after an encounter with a diseased hermit, one by one the group falls victim to an aggressive flesh eating virus taking a physical and mental toll on the group that spirals out of control.Eli Roth whether you like his work or hate it, one can't diminish his drive or tenacity. Working his way through the Hollywood scene in the 90s in fits and starts with people like Howard Stern, WCW, and even David Lynch, one can certainly say that Roth is a very passionate individual who doesn't slack when it comes to his passions. Made for a scant $1.5 million dollars, Cabin Fever put Eli Roth on the map as a filmmaker, becoming the fledgling studio Lionsgate's highest grossing movie of that year, and drawing praise from film critics such as Stephen Holden and Peter Travers, as well as filmmakers such as Peter Jackson and Quentin Tarantino (who would later become a friend and collaborator of Roth on several projects). Cabin Fever certainly has a lot working for it, but it challenges you to hate it with nearly unrelenting effort.A big reason that Cabin Fever tapped into the cultural zeitgeist of the horror scene when it did was it was one of the first major horror releases to try to make from the post modern mold that Scream had shepherded the genre towards. While Scream was and still is well regarded for what was a refreshingly acerbic and intelligent take on the horror genre, it also has gotten a fair share of detractors for how many rip-offs and copycats it spawned in not just tone, but also marketing, style, and general approach that filled the genre with pretentious, know-it-all teenagers to 20-somethings who seemed almost glib about the horror they were in rather than being legitimately scared by it. Cabin Fever breaks from this mold by going back to the beginning. While Cabin Fever is very contemporary and does feature homages in both style and setting to classic drive-in horror be it Friday the 13th type slashers, hillbilly horror like Deliverance or Texas Chainsaw Massacre, or even Cabin in the Woods type features like the first The Evil Dead, it doesn't wear these influences on its sleeve nor does it call attention to them through self aware dialogue. Cabin Fever is definitely a horror film with a sense of humor, but it doesn't call attention to it as was the case with many post Scream horror films which makes it refreshing by being something of a throwback.The movie while technically solid and rich in atmosphere is definitely stamped with Roth's trademark style (which will determine whether you love or hate this movie). The five characters we follow are all varying degrees of abrasive, annoying, stupid, and/or unlikable. James DeBello as Bert, the group's one member who doesn't bring a female counter part, is definitely one of the most unlikable people ever created for a movie. When we're introduced to Bert he casually shoplifts a Snickers bar from the General Store for no other reason than "he can", and once he arrives at the cabin he goes around the woods causally shooting squirrels and chipmunks because "they're gay". The movie's dialogue is laced with causally usage of the word "gay" as a synonym for stupid or casual insinuations of homophobia and usage of the word "retarded" and while the movie is aware that its characters are all awful people, there's not all that much to them as we slowly wait for them to die off one by one.Roth for as much as he clearly loves the atmosphere and iconography of the films of his youth, doesn't feel like he understands them beyond the surface level. In many ways you can probably see parallels between Bert and Margot Kidder's Barb from Black Christmas or Larry Zerner's Shelly from Friday the 13th part 3 in how they're foul mouthed "funny one" who build their identities around casual insults and or pranks, but both Barb and Shelley had humanity behind their abrasiveness that made them feel human enough to see them as characters beneath their cruel behavior. Bert really doesn't have that humanity to him, in fact it's never even all that clear why these people are friends in the first place other than they've been put here by Roth to endure physical and psychological punishment. Maybe Roth is basing this on a dynamic he had with his own friends (since the movie was inspired by his skin infection he contracted with his friends in Iceland) but there's not much that sets up how this dynamic formed nor what it's built upon. Something like this CAN work, but you've got to throw the audience a bone so they can understand it.The actual horror in Cabin Fever is reasonably decent. The isolated backwoods areas that make up Bunyan County, the dilapidated shacks that populate the lakeside area, and the country General Store make for some nice atmospheric locations that give a good sense of dread and isolation. The humor is very hit and miss. Some humor such as some long form setups based around the General Store (particularly a joke involving the owner's causal use of the N-word that has a pitch perfect payoff at the end of the movie) are really good, while others such as a cop obsessed with partying with the wayward youth who come for sex, drinking, and drugs are more confusing than they are funny. I can't really say that Cabin Fever is all that "scary" since it doesn't really create much in the way of dread or panic and often feels more like an Itchy & Scratchy cartoon where we're waiting to see what insane levels of punishment await our characters.Cabin Fever excels with some really excellent gore work and many of its scenes such as the Bowling Alley Massacre story, the leg shaving scene, and too many others to mention becoming iconic benchmarks for the genre in the 00's decade. Roth makes these moments incredibly tangible and the squelching, splatter, and oozing are just so lovingly well constructed that it's easy to see why Peter Jackson was so generous with the praise.Cabin Fever is a divisive movie, and it's by design. Eli Roth as a filmmaker is a Provocateur who thumbs his nose at convention and makes his movies without restraint or consideration for good taste. While he doesn't balance the over the top gore and humor as well as his influences like Jackson and Raimi, he does have an understanding of his influences and exudes passion in his every frame with shots carrying a visceral and dynamic nature that brings beauty to the brutality. I'm not sure I can say I "liked" Cabin Fever, but it's an incredibly quotable movie with scenes that do stick with you because of how unrestrained they are. Eli Roth has made the movie he wanted to make, abrasive, violent, vulgar, silly, disgusting, juvenile, well shot, well crafted, atmospheric, with meticulous attention paid to little details. If that sounds like the type of movie you'd like, then look no further, you found it and it's a success.Love it or hate it, Eli Roth makes his debut going full force establishing his style unapologetically without remorse, shame, or restraint

Review title: Cabin Fever; or a good reason to just drink beer in the woods
Review_body: Watching "Cabin Fever" reminded me of the fun one could have while making a horror film. One could argue that modern horror is too detailed, over-produced, under talented, and quintessentially making the same mold over and over merely for cinema dollars. The argument is tired, but true. Made in 2002, and only grossing about 21 million, this was a small blip on everyone's radar. Found randomly on DVD one October at my local video store, "Cabin Fever" was a means to merely scare a gathering of friends, or perhaps just gather some laughs. Little did we realize that this was something stronger than just your average teen-horror flick. Director Eli Roth (speaking pre-"Hostel") knew his horror genre. Being an assistant with David Lynch for many years, he understands that spooky doesn't mean linear, that blood does come in gallon containers and the more obscure the better. "Cabin Fever" proved that with mediocre dialogue, great horror shots, and the fear of the unknown (which was left unknown throughout the film). He tells us the fears, but not his characters – giving us tension with the horror. While "Hostel" seems too mainstream and less Lynch-ian for my standards, "Cabin Fever" complete with "pancakes", "Denis", the box, and the fear of this backwoods community, is that diamond in the rough. This singular film demonstrated the power behind Roth, and his missed opportunity for films to come.There is no arguing that this is an amateur film. The edits are rough, the story is haphazard, and the characters are bland, but what is impressive is the passion behind the camera. The flux of different genres blended together proves that Roth had done his homework, that he loves horror, and wasn't afraid of taking chances. He created a horror film without giving us a monster, the choice of a faceless virus wreaking havoc onto a group of unsuspecting teens was bold, but worked perfectly. Fear was created within the unknown, or more importantly, from what we knew but our characters did not. Cliché to the hilt, our leaders in this rag-tag group of C-actors (of which our leader is the boy from "Boy Meets World") try to break the mold, but nothing spectacular comes of it. This, oddly, works for "Cabin Fever" because the core of the film doesn't need popular faces, but instead a stark need for bleak realism. As horror watchers, we know that the outcome for those with cliché lines is not positive, so Roth plays with that. He builds non-existent characters to run around screaming, while we scream back. "Go out of the woods" – "Get in the cabin" – "Don't stare at the naked woman" – "Get help!" are all things not said within the film, but instead in the audience. Roth pulls you in. Instead of being a mere spectator, "Cabin Fever" asks you to be involved.Two big scenes (amongst many) stand out as reasons to watch this film. Whether you are a horror fan or not, these two speak volumes of what Roth learned from Lynch when working together. The first is Dennis. The child at the store that has a fascination with biting people that sit next to him, who loves pancakes, and equally enjoys karate moves – was one of those moments that proved Roth's loyalty to the trade. The slow motion karate reminded me of "Twin Peaks" and the music that accompanied added to that feel. The entire station was pulled from a Lynch world, and I would have considered this theft if the two hadn't worked together. Instead, it felt more like a homage, a brief "thank you" to Roth's mentor. With that said, the second scene that speaks volumes of Roth's talent is something that he has carried with him throughout his "Hostel" years. The unknown. Without spoiling anything, when our group of gun-toting locals arrive to the cabin, two have guns while one merely carries a box. When two fall shy of their goals, the other merely attempts to open a box as his form of defense. What was in that box? What could have protected him? This is the unknown makes "Cabin Fever" stand out stronger than others of this genre released at the same time. Sure, it's small – but the effect and conversation that follows with your peers is sublime.Again, "Cabin Fever" wasn't the bee's knees of horror films, but unlike Roth's future endeavors it demonstrated his ability to take a small idea and blossom it into true fear. Many will probably not enjoy this film, seeing "Hostel" as his penultimate work, this will seem lackluster – but for those nay-sayers against his torture-porn, this is a throwback to a stronger era of horror movie-making. One part David Lynch, one part "Wrong Turn", and one part "The Stand" (that's a lot of parts) – Roth proves that he can handle a camera, a story, and a crew whilst scaring us, grossing us out, and creating a world within a world.Overall, I am not afraid to say that I like "Cabin Fever". When I first saw it I was impressed by what little I understood and what Roth spoon-fed me. I thought he was a director to watch, and I still think he has quite a bit of potential, but to be remembered merely for "Hostel" just doesn't cut it. "Cabin Fever" is a great entry into the world of horror, creating genuine scares and following a predesigned structure (not a bad thing for this film) – he uses his own techniques to tell his story. "Cabin Fever" remains a strong entry into the world of horror. If you are new to Roth, I say start here – if you are disappointed with his future work – go back and see this again. You will not be disappointed.Grade: **** out of *****

saw this once before way back when and remember enjoying it. A lot of people don't like the work of Eli Roth. I don't think he is an amazing director or anything but I did enjoy Knock Knock and Hostel immensely. His films are often stupidly cheesy and full of graphic violence but I can appreciate that, the lowest form of entertainment. I knew I had to revisit this film after watching the terrible 2016 reboot (why the hell did that happen).The story of the film is quite simple. It's about 5 friends who are vacationing at a cabin. Little do they know that there is a type of flesh eating disease spreading around in the area that makes people's skin fall off. They also later find out that it is being spread through water. The film definitely is influenced by The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Evil Dead but this film is definitely of that calibre. It's still a dumb enjoyable bloodfest. Which is what is expected from this director.The scares (the few that are present) don't really work and use the often played out jarring sound as something pops up. The blood and makeup is quite good. The skin falling off looks quite real and some of it really does make your skin crawl. The dialogue is so dumb and you get the typical prototype of dumb sex fueled teens who get themselves into trouble (as is par with horror films).The cast aren't particularly great although it was nice to see Rider Strong in a lead role. Jordan Ladd kind of faded into obscurity soon after. The film also has a cameo from Eli Roth, who basically plays an idiot. It's a truly dumb film but mindlessly entertaining. I don't think it's Roth's best (Knock Knock has definitely taken that cake) but it's an entertaining bloody debut.7/10

Director Eli Roth's first movie, "Cabin Fever", has been considered a breath of fresh air and a wake up call for the horror genre; while it is certainly different from most of this generation horror movies, the movie has a few big flaws that hurt the film and make the experience no as satisfying.Let's start from the beginning, the plot is an quite clever take on the "alone in the woods" set up. A group of college students go to a cabin in the woods in order to spent a week of beer, fun and sex. Everything goes right until they meet a hermit that carries a strange but deadly disease. While they get rid of him, one of them get the disease, and soon they find each other fighting between them and turning against each other.The plot is very original and is a great setting for a horror movie. Sadly, and while it really delivers some suspense, the concept of friends turning against each other is soon forgotten and we get strange scenes of comic relief that feel out of place. It is one of the major flaws because at the times when the suspense rises Roth suddenly includes an anti-climatic joke that not only breaks the suspense, it breaks the whole pace and rhythm of the movie.Fortunately, when the movie remembers it is a horror, it really works. The disease is some kind of flesh-eating bacteria that slowly rots the body while the person is still alive. The SFX of the disease symptoms are top-notch and the camera work is outstanding in general.The acting is quite good, and better than average; sadly,their performances are ruined by the uneven script that makes the characters unlikeable. A big mistake in my opinion, because horror movies make you feel sympathy for the character, not hate. However, I repeat, it is certainly not the actor's fault, because the script demands them to be that way. A shame indeed, because the cast ends up playing cartoons instead of real characters.The direction is remarkably good, with a definite style of its own although it clearly shows its influences, particularly Sam Raimi and his cult classic "Evil Dead". It makes a good movie that is worth a watch.Eli Roth has a bright future, with a better script he certainly will deliver a masterpiece soon. However, "Cabin Fever" is a good debut, a fine horror movie, but not the outstanding masterpiece the hype pretends it is. 6/10. Good movie? Yes. Future of horror? Not yet.

Review title: "I made it! I made it! I knew it!"...and I didn't regret!
Review_body: Cabin Fever is the debut film of Eli Roth, as a producer, and what a debut, I might say! The film was really a surprise to me, as I wasn't expecting a movie with all that strength! Great plot (at last a horror/gore movie that hasn't psychos, sharpened knifes or ghosts!), great setting, nice acting, brilliant humour at some parts, great soundtrack (a few songs by Angelo Badalamenti and fantastic string sounds almost all the movie) and good horror scenes. In fact, after seeing Hostel, I didn't expect that the previous Eli Roth movie was so good! Comparing to this movie Hostel was a regression! The plot is really simple and follows, in a general way, the traditional plot-keys of a slashing movie. However it's very well structured and the main theme is a lot different from traditional horror movies. The "killer" it's not a psycho, a ghost, or a "scary monster", but just an epidemic/virus. I know it's not the first time that an epidemic is used in a horror movie, but it's not very common I guess. The acting is also very nice, and the setting explores the "always fantastic" interior southern lands of the U.S.A About the humour we cannot say it's always present, since it's not a comedy, but it has some great moments of dark humour! One I can remember is when the blond guy, at the end, starts shouting: " I made it! I made it! I knew it! They are all dead, but I made it", and suddenly he's full carved of bullets from sheriff and his men! Hilarious! But there's a few more The soundtrack was really great! First, because I adore Angelo Badalamenti, I know him from David Lynch movies, and he can creates fantastic sound atmospheres which mix melody with mystery He's a great musician! Second, because the soundtrack is full of scratching string sounds! Cellos, violins, freezing sounds! That's cool! It made me remember the horror movies from the 70's. That's the classic horror's film sound! The kind which we use to say: "They don't make it anymore" The horror/gory scenes are also very well done, especially because they're very realistic. Some of them made my blood run chill, not because they were scary, but because it's a kind of scene that really makes me freeze: when the girl is taking a bath and shaving her legs and her skin stars to drop! Skin someone alive impresses me, even more than if he's cut in pieces! Well, globally, the gory scenes were good because in spite of not being so many like that they were very bloody! Cabin Fever was really a nice surprise, a lot better than Hostel. I'm expecting to see the next works of Eli Roth!

(spoilers)There are some good scares to be had here, but this works mainly on trying to disgust you. A have this theory that if you want to know if a movie's scary, try eating while watching it (popcorn doesn't count). This movie is not a good one to eat in front of, since its fairly high on the disgust-o-meter. It has a fairly good creepy atmosphere, but its terribly uneven.Cabin Fever labours under the fact that the bad guy is an illness, betraying the fact that the filmmakers have constantly struggled to make it scary, constantly resulting to scare and shock tactics to make the audience jump to compensate for the lack of a human bad guy. The tactics include Dennis, the dog, the men from the store and the lamb. The music doesn't help - Ennio Morricone's three songs stick out like sore thumbs next to the music the rest of the film has.All this would be fine if not for the fact that the characters are so obnoxious! Cerina Vincent is beautiful but very synthetic-looking (Areola the naked exchange student from Not Another Teen Movie!), James DeBello with his Oscar-the-Grouch voice is that same tired backwards-cap jock we're all tired of, Rider Strong is (another one of those clean-cut Jared Leto types) is that same frustrated quiet guy in love with his best friend (Jordan Ladd), who is an uptight manipulator.Interestingly, Cerina and Jordan are the two girls from Lynch's digital video short Darkend Room if you've seen that.

This movie was actullay not bad despite what most people tend to think. The acting was actullay good the plot was interesting and it had some edge of your seat moments.This movie is about a group of 20 somethings who go out to a cabin in the woods for the weekend. While partying one night a strange "hermit" apporoaches them with what looks like some kind of disease. They are scared of it being contagious so they attempt to scare the stranger off accidentally killing him in he process. Having their vehicle wrecked in the encounter they are stranded as the disease starts to pick them off one by one.This movie was pretty good don't listen to everybody on here. It was low budget yes but you cant really tell. The only negative thing I would have to say about this movie is that for no reason at all Roth throws in jokes here and there. They are quite amusing but it throws off the entire atmosphere of the movie.Good movie though give it a watch
Cheap horror at its not so finest. Brainless and dead like how the disease in the movie leaves its victims. Nostalgia may make some people miss this movie, but honestly, it's really not that great.

The premise of "Cabin Fever" may not be the most original one, but it could have set up a good claustrophobic thriller, a study of mankind even. "Cabin Fever" is neither. Instead it turned out to be "Friday The 13th" with a killer virus, only the dialog and the acting are even cheesier (yes, it's possible!). As soon as I recognized one of the actors (James DeBello, the guy who plays Bert) to be the same guy who had already annoyed the hell out of me in another useless movie, called "100 Girls", I knew that "Cabin Fever" was going to be a letdown. DeBello has such a moronic smile, I want to throw my T.V. out of the window every time he comes on. He's playing the immature, annoying member of the group again and he did a good job at that. Makes me think he's either like that in real life too or he's indeed a damn fine actor (yeah, right). All the time I couldn't stop thinking, why would anyone try to make something out of such a bad script? Why hire stunt people who set themselves on fire? Why the make-up artists and all the rest of the crew? Why buy the rights to the script in the first place? Had anybody actually read this? Apparently the movie was written by a six year-old! I bet, some people responsible for this mess got fired at Lion's Gate. I will give the movie one extra point for the final joke, which is kind of funny, but, well, completely out of place in a movie that's trying so hard to be scary for the rest of the time. Then again, maybe it was all just a big joke.

Eli Roth's directorial debut can be a bit dense at times and is full of shameless clichés, but has gained a cult-following over the years for being a halfway decent horror movie made at only a 1.5 million dollar budget. Five college graduates who rent a cabin in the woods (already two clichés in just half a sentence) fall victim to a flesh-eating virus. Idea came from Roth's experience of developing a facial rash from rotten hay during an Iceland trip. Sound mixer John Neff survived the real flesh-eating bacterium, which took 13 days of non-stop intensive care to cure. Despite the real-life inspirations from Roth and Neff who maintain the make-up in the film is 100% accurate, the movie never hooks the viewer into the story's reality.** (out of four)

Review title: Eli Roth's first film delivers on everything his second should have, and more
Review_body: Despite all of the hype, Hostel has got to be one of the worst and most vile pieces of celluloid I have ever had the displeasure of watching. Not for the violence, but for the fact that it just sucked, horrendously. I would see and read how well liked Eli Roth was for making the movie, and it would just disappoint me even more. I kept asking myself why anyone would like such a horrible movie, and then I realized that I had to see Cabin Fever before I tried to draw anymore conclusions.Following in the steps of The Evil Dead and Night of the Living Dead before it, Cabin Fever tells the story of five friends who rent a cottage in the woods after graduating from college. A chance arrival from a stranger covered with a flesh-eating disease ends in a murder, and before you know it, one of the friends has the virus. From here, they all race to try and get help, before it takes them too.No, the film is not deep, and no, it is not very original either. But thankfully, Roth pays homage to the men who have clearly inspired him, and made a decent horror movie that could actually play for scares and laughs (and not just for the sake of pointing out how ridiculous it is). What this film has, that Hostel sorrowly lacks, is being completely devoid of seriousness. Never is there a moment in the film where the characters go all serious. It plays itself up as a parody, and it stays very much in that realm for the entirety of the film. Yes, they have some dramatic moments, but they never cross the line between parody and complete earnestness. For that reason alone, I can respect this film a whole lot more than Hostel.But while the laughs come as fast and furious as the scares, the film still reeks of having the random and completely demented moments that I imagine Roth loves. They work better here than they did in Hostel, but do we really need a whole hour to pass before all hell breaks loose in the final thirty minutes? Clearly Roth could not have been that desperate for filler that he sacrificed his slow brooding horror for moments that just seem rather, off. He brings in random characters all over the place (including one played by himself), and really, they do nothing for the movie. Having them come to the enigmatic town, catch the disease and then try to get help would have been a much easier way of getting this movie from point A to point B. Hell, he could have even kept the ridiculous nature of the town's residents after they see the destruction of the disease, and it could have played itself out to be so much stronger than it is.But then, I must ask, why does no one in this movie seem to understand each other? Clearly he could have used one character to be sympathetic, but no one is. Even Jordan Ladd's Karen, who spends two of the film's three acts locked in a shed, does not even wince out the tiniest bit of sympathy. Does Roth really feel the need for all of his characters to do terrible things, and not be likable one bit? I came away with an awful taste in my mouth after watching the behaviour in the characters in Hostel, and here, they act out much of the same behaviour, only with a hell of a lot more drama and proper parody. It just seems a bit bizarre to have such off-putting characters, despite whether or not they do not last the entirety of the film's running time.The film also benefits from not dwindling on any one thing. The violence is fast, furious and brutal. But never are we subjected to long and ridiculous shots of it. Here, Roth seems to know exactly what to show, and exactly what to cut out. He seems very cooperative with his material, and he seems to know exactly what he is doing. So how then, can we compare this to his manipulative and perversely repetitive sequences in Hostel? I just cannot seem to shake the fact that he seems to really have an avid knowledge of what to do in this movie, but does not seem to have any sort of idea what to do with the far better concept at work in his second film. Maybe I should just chock it up to the likes of Sam Raimi, George Romero and Peter Jackson for obviously influencing his work in this film. Like his own personal fanboy Quentin Tarantino (which hurts me deeply), Roth wants to ape the successful moments from the films these directors made, and their unique visions. Through his own concoction, Roth managed to come up with a half-decent horror film that has all of the modern day problems all horror films have, but still manages to do what it sets out to do from the start.Eli, this is the type of film you were born to create. It has just the right amount of laughs and the right amount of cheeky horror to set itself apart from the movies that just want to scare the bejesus out of its viewer. You knew how to direct this kind of movie, and you clearly demonstrated how well you could do it with this film. So why change the formula? Was it really worth it? I can only hope that Hostel: Part II has more parts Cabin Fever than it does Hostel. Because if it is just the genre-melding mess the original film was, I am going to have to stay with my original diagnosis of Roth as a filmmaker. And sit saddened, wishing there could be a successor to this film, flaws and all.6/10.

"Cabin Fever" is an ambitious movie, but unfortunately, ambition doesn't equate to success. "Cabin Fever" wants to be many things, but it doesn't really succeed at any of them. Primarily, it wants to be both a scary bloodbath and also a homage to schlocky B-movies. While some movies have succeeded in this arena, they are more of the exception than the rule. And, sad to say it, "Cabin Fever" is not among them.Five friends Paul (Rider Strong), Karen (Jordan Ladd), Bert (James DeBello), Marcy (Cerina Vincent) and Jeff (Joey Kern) have just graduated from college and are taking a week long vacation in the woods to drink and have sex non-stop. But trouble starts even before they arrive. Soon, they are battling a skin disease that is eating them alive (literally).It's actually a shame that Eli Roth chose this premise as a means to pay homage to schlock movies. Done right, this could have been a terrifying movie (and filled with the copious amounts of gore that Roth clearly loves). As it is, it seems like a wasted premise instead of a homage. There's simply not enough cheese to make it enjoyable enough in that respect.The problems don't stop there. The actors are too boring to either sympathize with or laugh at. Needless to say, this severely hampers the film's ability to scare its audience or make them appreciate the homage. The only actor worth mentioning is James DeBello. He's terrific as the big dumbass Bert. This is the lumbering idiot who will gleefully be a slob and still laugh after you realize that he let one rip. Sadly, the other actors aren't as good. Rider Strong may have made his mark with TV audiences as Shawn Hunter in "Boy Meets World," but he's lost in another movie here. He takes his performance way too seriously instead of going along with the flow and just having a good time, thus he comes across as stiff and out-of-place. Jordan Ladd and Cerina Vincent are basically the same except that they look different and have different things happen to them. Joey Kern is obnoxious as Jeff, but not in a good way. In one of the interviews on the DVD, Eli Roth commented that Jeff is supposed to be a dick, but Kern is so annoying that you can't wait for him to die. That's a far cry than appreciating someone for playing a character who's a complete jerk.Eli Roth is a member of the so-called "Splatter Pack." While he clearly is unafraid of showing blood and gore, as a filmmaker, he does not match up to the other members of the group, such as James Wan and Leigh Whanell (the "Saw" movies) or Neil Marshall ("The Descent," "Dog Soldiers"). "Cabin Fever" suffers from a plethora of problems, one of which is pacing. Getting to know the characters is crucial for any film, but none of the characters in "Cabin Fever" are interesting enough to hold our attention for as long as it takes for Roth to get things going. The second problem is that Roth loses control of things fairly early in the movie. Films need to be directed by a sure hand; "Cabin Fever" seems uncertain of what it is doing. It keeps spinning its wheels, but it's doesn't know where it's going. Some characters and plot points are grafted into the screenplay, and they don't really fit."Cabin Fever" isn't a terrible movie; there are a few tense moments, and DeBello is always fun to watch, but it's just not a very good one. According to the documentary on making the film, people were lined up to get into a 1,000 seat theater at the Cannes Film Festival. I wouldn't be surprised if this was a movie that really depended on audience participation (like "The Rocky Horror Picture Show"). Or maybe I'm not "schooled" enough in the films that Roth is trying to pay homage to. Whatever the reason, I didn't enjoy "Cabin Fever" as much as I hoped I would.Note: Roth clearly has a sense of humor. Watch the "Family Friendly Version" in the Special Features, and you'll see why.

This movie rides a too little story, and to depreciate it, is the awful acting, one girl in a black bikini, sun baking on a lazy boy in an plague infested river, she might as well been a corpse. The hillbilly music at the end credits was another minus. Five college friends head off to the woods, where a flesh eating virus, found in the polluted river, turns our fun seekers, into flesh rotting corpses. As to keep the movie running at adequate running time, which seems almost to last forever, first they show small symptoms like fevers, coughs whatever, until the slow and ugly disintegration takes effect where they form into grotesque states of being, one by one, where it's kill or be killed. Two knowing their fate have one last sexual encounter in a barn, where the first victim was kept in a quarantine by the others. So really there's your movie, it's gore, and make up effects, great, but this isn't enough to sustain it from being a good quality horror film, to Roth's following, brilliant shocker, Hostel, which is still one of the most scariest horrors I've seen in I don't know when. The mains, most of them unknowns, excluding one who's star shone bigger, gave such incredulously bad performances, I was in a state of utter disbelief. It's like they weren't ever trying to act, where you think a Christian name like Rider could make you a big star. One plus if you can call it that, was the psychopathic hillbilly locals, who added some air of menace to this insubstantial debut. Fortunately Roth went onto a better class of stuff, superior to this backwoods drivel.

Review title: An unfairly criticised debut; it really is not that bad
Review_body: Eli Roth's debut, Cabin Fever, seems to be hated by the majority on IMDb and many other critics. I, however, found this to be a rather enjoyable little film that just falls short of being great. To sum up this movie: take a bit of The Texas Chain Saw Massacre, a bit of The Evil Dead, a couple of elements from The Thing and Last House on the Left and you have Cabin Fever. A horror movie about five teenagers going to holiday in a cabin in the woods after college where the nearest town is filled with hicks and everything is slowly getting infected by an unknown virus which starts to turn everyone against each other. Roth blends horror with a small amount of comedy which suits this type of movie. The five teens are a mixed bunch (the dumb guy, the horny couple and the innocent couple). Most of them swear, drink, have wild sex and smoke drugs and because of this may seem annoying and clichéd, on the contrary, Roth has captured the attitude of what teenagers were (and still are) like. We do all that they do (well, not so much drugs..) and to me that makes them more realistic. The locals aren't so realistic and seem to be their for comic relief and body count (which isn't a bad thing). There is plenty of gore and plenty of scenes to make you squirm in disgust.The reason I don't give this a really high score is because the pacing seemed jumbled to me. For me, the running time was really short and there were not enough scares throughout. This movie had potential to be more than the final product but I respect what Roth has done and considering it was his first movie it is remarkably good and for that I give it:8/10

Wildly shocking and amusing debute film for young director Eli Roth is perhaps the best example of current old-school horror around!Five youths retreat to a cabin in rural North Carolina, where they come in contact with a deadly flesh-eating virus!Packed with tension, gore, psychological terror, and dark humor Cabin Fever is a knock-out of a horror film and very clever in its premise. Director/writer Eli Roth shows that he's a genre fan, making references to a number of classic horror films, not to mention using some of David Hess's original songs for Craven's Last House on the Left (1972). Roth manages to use slick humor and spine-tingling horror together in a very effective way! The film has many of the horror movie conventions, yet never really falls into the cliché trappings of so many B horror flicks. You simply don't know where the twisting plot of the movie is going at any time. The movie is nicely shot in Mount Airy, NC. Roth tosses in some style in his direction, making some of the moments of dream-like psychological horror nightmarishly good. The musical score is quite good. David Hess's son Jesse Hess does a good cover on his father's old song 'The Road Leads to No Where' for the films closing credits. The makeup FX for this film are outstanding and stomach-churning! There's plenty of blood to be had for the gore-hounds. The cast is great. Rider Strong is good in his role of a teen struggling to survive. Beautiful Jordan Ladd does a heart-felt performance as Strong's love interest. The ever-funny James DeBello is perfect as a jerky friend. Cerina Vincent and Joey Kern also turn in good performances as the other desperate-to-survive youths. Giseppee Andrews does a humorous turn as a local deputy/"party man" and Roth himself appears as a stoner camper. The rest of the cast, most of whom play weird country characters are solid as well.Why so many people have come to dislike this movie is a mystery to me! Many complain about Roth using both horror and off-beat humor, but it works! At any rate, Cabin Fever was one of the most successful horror movies of it's year and is probably one of the most entertaining horror films in many years. Genre fans simply shouldn't miss it.*** 1/2 out of ****

Review title: Avalanche of Gore not needed and bad story
Review_body: I can look rude to say that but this movie had no sense, its just a big mess , basically you get the usual teens(the chicks, the chick's boyfriend, the morons best friends, the shy girl etc) and then you put them in a non-sense plot. A virus that come from water? yeah but it come from what originally? there that deer that they hurt who morph into a blood geyser for no reason, there the morons who shot animals for fun, the crazy kid who think he is jackie chan then biting peoples... the hilbillies that try to shot the ''heroes'' because there kid bite one of them and get sick... They beat the hell out of somebody who want help for no reason, seriously this movie story have completely no sense, there an avalanche of gore for no reason, i was expecting some kind of demonic killer from preview and basically its just a virus making people rot on place. We where at this close to just stop the DVD half movie because we where so bored...

Review title: My 2nd Ever Horror Film I Watched
Review_body: Because of the age I was when I watched this, It was much scarier then to me than it is now. But will have a special place in my movie library lol.

Review title: Eli Rotten's best film. . . how depressing.
Review_body: You'll laugh watching this movie. I promise. Not because it's funny. Though, there are a couple rather funny jokes. But the majority of laughs come from the "my god I can't believe this film was actually produced" kind of humour.If you want a quality horror/comedy film that takes place in the woods and involves people going insane, just go rent the Evil Dead films. At least those ones are actually original and don't need completely moronic writing and directing in order to get cheap laughs.3/10. Next.-AP3-

Review title: Very Enjoyable, Though Not a Masterpiece
Review_body: It really took me a while to get around to watching this film. The plot sounded promising and appeared to be a combination of teen-horror and disease/infection/virus disaster movies.The most I can say about this movie is that it delivered exactly what it promised, nothing more nothing less. The acting was average, but not bad at all. The characters were your usual stereotypical teens ("easy to get" attractive girl and her douche boyfriend, a good girl, a good guy, and an idiot. Nothing even slightly innovative here). The story was textbook teen horror - going on vacation to a desolate old town, meeting some creepy locals, getting to a neat cabin in a creepy forest, the works!
