It's all there.Just when you'd expect Jason to appear and start hacking and slashing, the second ingredient of the combination appeared, and the disease outbreak began. One of the better things in this movie was how it portrayed the disease. Just enough gore to make it realistic, but not too much so as not to use gore as a cheap cheat. Another nice part of this movie was the relationship between good-boy and good-girl, which was quite beautiful.One thing was rather original, and that was the comic relief, provided this time not by "the idiot" (who wasn't all that funny), but by the weird freaky Sheriff's Deputy who spoke, behaved and looked just the stoner type idiot you'd expect to find in such films, only that he wasn't with the guys on vacation, he was the law! You know you're in good hands when that kinda guy is wearing the badge :)I fail to understand all the hate towards this movie. If one expected to be swept of their feet and utterly amazed, then yes, they would be disappointed. But not every movie can be the best one ever. Some are just fun to watch. So while this movie gave us nothing new we haven't seen before and nothing too profound or exquisite, it was fun to watch. I would recommend it to anyone modest enough to enjoy a good presentation without it being the decade's masterpiece.

*******SPOILERS AHEAD!!!!*******"Cabin Fever" is not a perfect film, but it does has it's moments.The story is interesting, but a lot of the plot is not explained: WHERE did the disease come from? You know that most of the kids get it by drinking the water, but not where it came from. Oh, and what's with the town people? They apparently know about what's going on. HOW long have they've known about the disease?Interesting story though: 5 friends from college go to the woods to have fun (Of course, you get your drugs, sex and rock and roll). They end up becoming infected with the disease, which causes them to throw up a LOT of blood and their flesh to decay. The results are VERY unpleasant! A lot of silliness is around, too (What's with the stoner or cop?).Whatever you do, you don't want to watch this while having a drink of water. You may end up a bit paranoid (Like me. I had a large glass of ice water and watched the film!).

Review title: Fails as Both a Horror Movie and a Comedy
Review_body: Cabin Fever is a disaster that fails to live up to its hype, and makes one wonder how Eli Roth ever got to direct another movie. Long story made short, the usual gang of idiotic college students encounters a flesh eating disease in the woods. (Jason was off fishing.) All hell breaks loose.The film fails as a horror movie because the only thing it has to offer is gore. No real suspense, nothing really disturbing, just gross out scenes. Although the gore may be shocking to mainstream viewers, anyone familiar with Japanese or Chinese horror movies will be yawning. Furthermore, the characters are so stereotypical that you could care less what happens to them, so you have no real investment in the movie.The stereotypical characters also hurt in the comedy department. For the most part, there isn't anything to see here that you wouldn't see in a bad episode of Saturday Night Live. A typical example is the idiotic deputy who comes across as a David Arquette character portrayed by a cheaper actor than David Arquette.My prescription: Quarantine this movie.

...buckets of blood, gore, and entertainment.What stinks is that I watched this movie on SyFy(channel 40) and most of it was cut.The movie still somehow managed to show at least some gross moments that were both disgusting and cool.The plot involves some teenagers who go to a cabin and they suddenly catch a virus that spreads to each person one by one.Now you know why it's called 'Cabin Fever'.What happens while they discover that their skin is falling off and start coughing blood is very gross and shouldn't be watched by those who have weak stomachs for gore.Still, 'Cabin Fever' delivers lots of gore and shouldn't be taken too seriously if it wants to be liked.

You know what Cabin Fever needed? Someone normal working on the set. I guess those people were all booked up doing something else. The film isn't horrible but it isn't good either. Eli Roth couldn't figure out what mood or vibe to give the film so he just went all over the place. Making it comical, gross, nauseating, scary. Some people might say, "well, it has everything." Maybe. But it didn't keep me engaged in the story-it was distracting. One of the characters acts so weird all I could think of is "I'm glad I didn't have to work with him." And the "documentary" on the DVD didn't make him look any more normal! That's how bizarre this guy is. Nothing here to really sink your teeth into. And the characters are so cruel to the first victim of the "skin condition" you don't care what happens to THEM. Skip it.

There are not many horror movies nowadays which I consider to actually be any good. "The Ring", "The Grudge", "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" remake,and "30 Days of Night" are examples of how sad and pathetic the Horror scene has become. However, "Cabin Fever" is a relief from those static, boring horrors of today. It is actually sick and twisted, like many older horror films. I loved it and was actually startled in many parts by the twists and shocks. THere weren't any cheap "psychotic" scenes, like in The Ring. Some of the characters were twisted and crazy, but thats what made them good. And I love the random humor throughout the eeriness. Recommend this movie to any classic horror fans. 9/10

I didn't think this movie was all THAT bad. I mean, at least it was somewhat original. Instead of several unlikable young adults heading off into the woods to drink and have sex and eventually get killed and eaten by inbred cannibals, we get several unlikable young adults heading off into the woods to drink and have sex and get killed off by their own stupidity. A nice, creepy, flyblown opening sets us up rather well. A nasty virus (origin unknown and never explained) finds its way to the cabin via a backwoods hobo, and quickly infects our cast of beautiful people. Their truck damaged by the virus-maddened hobo (and their drinking water polluted by his rotting corpse, which has fallen into the nearby river), our group of five is virtually stranded, and it isn't long before the flesh- eating disease is turning the beautiful people into some pretty nasty looking specimens. I found it difficult to feel any sympathy for the infected city folk; they were all pretty annoying and not terribly unlike the college kids in my apartment complex who yell and scream (and puke) underneath my bedroom window at 2am when I have to get up at 5am. I did, however, appreciate the realistic reactions of the characters when they realize what is happening: instead of bonding together and fighting to survive, they scatter, bicker, regard each other with suspicion, abandon their lovers, act like immature jackasses and kill each other. In short, they're pretty realistic in all of their shallowness and selfishness. I also rather enjoyed the dark comedy that ran through this film; the pancake loving Dennis, the nightmarish rabbit, the pot smoking deputy, the bowling alley massacre and the supposedly racist old man. These scenes were few and far between, but they were the most interesting ones in the movie, usurped only by the ending which is a morbid punchline to a very long, sick joke.This isn't a perfect film, but as far as horror films go, I've seen a LOT worse. People who enjoy bloody splatter and black comedy may appreciate this odd little film. I give it a 6 out of 10. Sue me, I kinda liked it.

There's a major difference between releasing an original, intense, edge-of-your-seat, scary, gore-fest, and doing like filmmaker Eli Roth and his team have done with "Cabin Fever" and simply acted like it. The film follows five college graduates into a cabin in the woods that begins to prove fatal as one after the other succumbs to this mysterious, fast-acting, flesh-eating disease. It's not long before the friends turn on one another, and can barely stand the sight of one another, much less want to be in the same vicinity as them. As gross as it all sounds, there's a certain spark behind the basic premise of this film that could have worked, in the hands of a less cocky filmmaker. Unfortunately what we end up with is poorly drawn characters whose sole purpose seems to be to look beautiful at the beginning to make the inevitable decomposition more contrasting, a hackneyed script so profanity-laden as to leave the viewer tuning out the dialogue, and several incomprehensible subplots that motivate little more than (in one instance) an on-screen appearance by director Roth. This is sloppy film-making in several ways! Avoid this time devourer.

I watched this movie after knowing movie's cult status and that it's director the same who directed Hostel. The movie was creepy and it gave me feelings of Evil Dead.For a debut movie, director did good work. Performance by the cast was okay, not effective. You are unable to connect with them and don't even feel sad for them. The movie was also lacking some good background music that could have helped movie to become more spooky and creepy.Overall, you can give it a try. You may enjoy it especially if you are fan of low budget B grade horror-dark comedy movies.

Cabin Fever offers some intense and scary moments but its really just the same except not very memorable. As a last hurrah after college, friends Jeff, Karen, Paul, Marcy and Bert embark on a vacation deep into the mountains. They drive to a remote cabin to enjoy their last days of decadence before entering the working world. Then their friend Karen gets sick and to avoid catching her virus they lock her in a shed. They look at one another and realize that any one of them could also have it. What soon began as a struggle against the disease turns into a battle against friends, as the fear of contagion drives them to turn on each other. The kids confront the terror of having to kill anyone who comes near them, even if it's their closest friend. The plot sure does sound scary and they did a decent job of executing it. I had heard that this film was really scary and I guess I did have high expectations. I should have lowered them as this was a slightly above average horror flick and nothing more. The story was decent with some clever twists and then it also had some old, annoying clichés. The acting was alright with the best being Rider Strong. His performance was nothing special but he stood out from everyone else. The rest of the kids are played by Jordan Ladd, James DeBello, Joey Kern and Cerina Vincent. They all play their roles well but don't really have a big impact on the viewer, which is okay since this is just a teenage horror flick. Eli Roth did an okay job of directing but he isn't that great at building suspense. I thought the film got really stupid at times like the kid who liked pancakes. I guess the director was making a reference to some film but it wasn't really needed. There were a lot of plot holes as well like who was the pancake kid? The film is pretty gory not over the top but enough to satisfy people. Cabin Fever pays homage to older horror classics which is nice but I didn't really think that helped the quality of the picture. In the end, this is a decent horror flick that's worth checking out. Rating 6/10

Review title: A Scary,Effective,Gory,and Darkly Funny Horror Film. Eli Roth's Best Film.
Review_body: Eli Roth's Cabin Fever is a great horror film that combines scares,gore,frights and dark humor that wonderfully pays homage to Horror films from the 70s and 80s. This is Eli Roth's best film that deserves more respect and is very underrated.Cabin Fever tells the story of five college students Paul(Rider Strong),Karen(Jordan Ladd),Bert(James Debello),Marcy(Cerina Vincent)and Jeff(Joey Kern)who are on vacation and decide to rent a cabin in the woods. When there,the group discovers that there is a flesh eating virus that's spreading around the forest that threatens to to take them one by one. The group also has to deal with crazed local hillbillies,hermits,dangerous animals,cops and themselves getting into frightening and bizarre situations.Cabin Fever is a film that seems to have divided Horror fans since it's release in 2003 where some love the film and some hate the film I fall into the former category and truly feel that Cabin Fever is terribly underrated. Cabin Fever is a great Horror film that takes viewers back to the days when Horror Films were bloody,frightening,gory and truly politically incorrect and Roth just rolls with it paying homage to Horror classics from the 1970s and 80s such as John Carpenter's The Thing,The Texas Chainsaw Massacre and The Evil Dead working as an homage but it's own film as well. The film has a great atmosphere that changes when things fall apart. In the beginning of the movie it's very fun and lighthearted where you get to know the main characters and what they're about and who they are. When the threat of the flesh eating virus comes around the film becomes darker and there's looming sense of dread and fear and when the characters start turning on each other it's real and believable. The film ultimately works as metaphor for the AIDS and HIV virus where most human beings live in fear of getting a deadly disease whether by breathing,touching or sex. The themes in the film will be relevant to people who watch the film and will stick with you after you view the film. What is also great about Cabin Fever is how it's not a Scream-type film and how the film takes itself seriously. While the film makes reference and pay's homage to the classic Horror films of the 70s and 80s,the film and it's characters aren't self-aware and know that they're in a Horror film. Roth smartly takes the material very seriously and the characters are in a horrific situation that is real and frightening and avoids having main the characters make lots of Humorous references to Horror films and treats the film as if you are with the characters going through the very same thing they are going through,treating the situation as dark and realistic as possible. What I also love about Cabin Fever is the dark Humor and slow build up. The Humor in the film is funny,insane,well-placed,dark and at times surreal and unexpected where one minute you are screaming in terror and you are laughing your head off the next. With CF Roth balances Horror and Humor well and that's one of the main reasons the CF works. Where most Horror films now are fast paced and get to the point,Cabin Fever is more like the Horror films of the 70s and 80s where Horror films were done with slow build-ups with characters and the dialog and then when things go to hell you care for the main characters. Eli Roth doesn't use fast editing or fancy camera tricks to get the viewer involved in the story,but with old fashion storytelling getting the viewer into the dark,scary and sometimes bizarre world of Cabin fever. Roth shows us the cabin and the woods making the main characters feel like their isolated from the world where there is no escape or hope. The ending of Cabin Fever is fantastic because it's funny and disturbing and will have you laughing in tears and disgust. A great ending. The cast does a great job. Rider Strong(best known for his role as Shawn Hunter on Boy Meets World)does a great job as Paul,bringing depth and sympathy to the role. Jordan Ladd is wonderful as Karen Paul's long time friend. James Debello is fantastic as Bert the funny guy. Cerina Vincent is great and sexy as Marcy the highly sexual girl in the group. Joey Kern does a wonderful job as Jeff,Marcy's boyfriend. Giuseppe Andrews is funny and memorable as Deputy Winston,a cop who loves woman and wants to party. Arie Verveen is wonderful as Henry the Hermit and brings sadness to the role. Director Eli Roth has a fun and small cameo as skateboarder Grim,a guy who hangs with group a bit.Eli Roth's direction is excellent with Roth bring slow camera movements,a great visual style and camera angles and color changes. Great job,Roth.The score by Nathan Barr is amazing and effective and fits in with the films tone. The score definitely reminded me of the Horror scores of the 70s and 80s and it's great. I also loved the use of songs from the Wes Craven classic The Last House on The Left and they fit in well with the film. The special effects by the great K.N.B EFX group is great,memorable,realistic,bloody and gory and messy. K.N.B does it again.In final word,if you love Horror films I highly suggest you see Cabin Fever,a scary,Gory,funny and memorable and probably in fifteen or twenty years will go down as a Horror classic and be more recognized. Highly Recommend. 10/10.

I thought that Cabin Fever was quite a good horror film, it was quite some time before i got the chance to see this film. the film is about five friends, Marcy,Bert,Karen,Paul,and Jeff who decide to leave the city for a get-way in the mountains, they rent a cabin in the hills. one of the friends Bert goes out shooting in the woods for squirrels but instead he shoots a man with a flesh eating disease. The man starts begging for Bert to help him. Later that night the man comes back to their cabin also he is very drunk. One by one, the friends become infected with the disease. This turned out to be not too bad a horror film in the end 4/10

Review title: Repulsive, offensive and brainless - which makes it sound leagues more interesting than it is
Review_body: While I certainly was no stranger to horror and slasher films in my youth and have soft spots for Halloween and even the first few Friday the 13th films, I neither understand nor find entertaining the torture porn genre that has infiltrated mainstream horror in the last couple of decades. Case in point being Eli Roth's Cabin Fever, which actually managed to get a mainstream release, a couple of critics and industry insiders who apparently felt there was something worthwhile here to compliment, and enough press coverage to arouse the interest of genre enthusiasts. The end result is pure torture for the viewer.Roth, who claims to be a horror genre fan (as well as believing he is a competent director), sets his story in the woods and provides five 20-somethings to blunder their way into his nightmare. Instead of a mad slasher, we get instead flesh-eating viruses. This might seem novel if there was any effort to develop anything in this screenplay, but I digress. In brief, our five nitwits encounter a gaggle of locals, who all appear to be suffering from some form of in-bred stupidity and played by people who were apparently rejects from casting for Deliverance. At one point, a wandering hermit obviously in the throes of a deadly illness, comes to them for help and our intrepid group naturally do what any would do to a sick person seeking help, they attack him and set him on fire. The burning carcass drags its way to the drinking well and falls in, thus contaminating the water supply to their cabin and starting an uninventive countdown of which one will be the first to contract the illness. It is not really spoiling anything in Roth's nasty film to say that it will naturally be the only person who experiences an iota of remorse for the death of the hermit.Pretty much nothing makes sense in Roth's asinine film, but it matters little to the director whose only goal seems to be to set the stage so that increasingly grotesque gross-out effects can take over. Filmmakers like Roth need to understand that there is a huge difference between being scared and being repelled - and if you cannot tell what that is than you are in the wrong line of work. Roth's idea of brilliant dialog revolves around how many times the F-word can be said in quick succession. "Character development" here seems to be confused with how stupid and unlikable the characters can be made to be. All five of the central characters are revealed fairly quickly to be dumb, thoughtless, selfish, hateful, nasty predators without any moral compass. The peripheral characters are not any better and feature such lunatic moments as a wacko who tries to bite people, while shouting "PANCAKES" and doing faux karate moves...seriously! Was it really impossible to come up with anyone who could evince even a moment's sympathy? Perhaps making everyone ethically repugnant is supposed to make the viewer "enjoy" watching the flesh blister and rot from bodies. I suppose there are those who enjoy such sights for their own merits. The ending is predictably downbeat and preposterous, but by that time if you are still watching, you probably will just be relieved that it is over.Of the cast, I only recognized one guy that used to be on the lousy Boy Meets World, but no one makes an impression in any good way here. Roth's direction, like the story, is nightmarishly incompetent. He has no idea of pacing or how to generate suspense - he just starts hurling blood, mucous, grime and body parts at the lens and hopes something will terrify the viewer. He has also revealed himself to be a one-trick pony - by consistently recycling the theme of young people who travel out of their comfort zone into a foreign setting and pay the price. His next films were the odious Hostel and Hostel 2 (with the victims being gruesomely tortured to death in Eastern Europe) and coming soon will be The Green Inferno, his feverish tribute to the Italian cannibal genre featuring young people crashing in the South American jungle and being eaten. Oh what ingenuity! One trembles to think what repulsive imagery Roth has concocted for that cakewalk.

A sneaky and surprisingly smart horror flick, Cabin Fever sets up all the clichés of its particular sub genre (what might be called the "sexy young people go into the woods" horror movie, featuring hostile redneck locals, dead animals on hooks, cars that suddenly stop running, etc.) and by the end has played a clever twist on every standard element, often to darkly comic effect. What's the plot? Well, five sexy young people (Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, Joey Kern, Cerina Vincent, and James DeBello) go to an isolated cabin where they contract a nasty bacteria that eats their flesh; this, combined with a bad-tempered dog and a party-loving police deputy (Giuseppe Andrews, giving a particularly funny performance), leads everyone into confusion and bloody chaos. Some of the ironic twists are a little obvious, but most of them effectively subvert your expectations to entertaining effect.

Seriously?What a load of craptacular awfulness.And what's so sad is that there are people who actually thought this movie was good.I'd like a case of whatever they're drinking.HOW do movies like this, get funded? More importantly...WHY do they get funded?This film got theatrical as in major, world wide screenings and press.There are struggling film makers who will never get the backing, press or prestige this film has had and THAT is what's wrong with Hollywood.I've seen first-time filmmakers, with little to no budget, no fame and no fan base, do better.The only reason it got a 3, from me, is because the geezer in the general store, was hilarious.Is there a rewind button on my life so I can get back the time I wasted on this useless garbage?

Review title: Over Rated and tedious. Who says Eli Roth is a Horror Master?
Review_body: Five obnoxious friends rent a cabin in the woods. After pissing off the locals at the general store they arrive and the loudmouth of the group Bert (Debello), stumbles on a man who has contacted a flesh eating disease. He asks for help but Bert leaves him. Later that night he shows up at the cabin and the five selfish idiots panic and end up lighting him on fire and killing him. He falls into the nearby lake and the water supply is infected. Karen (Ladd) is the first infected and the others lock her outside in a tool shed leaving her to die. All though we see the characters easily walk to near by cabins through out the film theses idiots can't seem to find away to escape the cabin and they soon become infected. This is the debut film from Writer / Director Eli Roth a self proclaimed horror fan who struggled for years to get this first feature made. Too bad this film with potential is as bad as it is. We could care less about these fully obnoxious characters and Roth himself has an annoying cameo scene as well. The flesh eating virus makes for some nice gore moments but there isn't one true scare in the film. Amazingly, the film has zero atmosphere either. With a creepy cabin set deep in the woods, it would seem Roth would just have to turn on the camera and you would get atmosphere but there is none. The cast is good but they're characters flat out suck. The movie takes a bunch of stupid turns along the way including the entire conclusion. What could have been a great bloody chiller turns into tedium in the hands of Roth. Eli Roth would go on after this film to become a horror film celebrity with the dreadful "Hostel" series and other depressing films of nausea. It's hard to understand why he is being regarded as a Horror film master?

CABIN FEVER does not break new ground. Having said that, the same applies to most of the movies that have been released so far this year (2005). CABIN FEVER is a surprisingly entertaining little horror flick, written and directed by horror aficionado Eli Roth. It's the story of a group of teens who decide to have a weekend party at some old cabin in the woods of North Caroline. OK, so the premise is nothing new and neither are all subsequent events, but one thing is sure: CABIN FEVER entertains! And that's what movies are for: entertainment. Well, these kids in the woods find themselves victims of some unidentified skin virus and thus puts them in awkward situations; like isolating one of themselves in order prevent the virus from spreading and infecting the rest of the teens. Shades of movies like Texas CHAINSAW MASSACRE, EVIL DEAD, DAWN OF THE DEAD and Friday THE 13th are all present in CABIN FEVER and I see this movie more like a tribute to all those slasher/splatter films of the late 70's and early 80's, when really gross films actually played out in theaters. Sure, there are a lot of plot holes and unresolved answers in CABIN FEVER. There's one scene where a trio of locals plan to kill the infected teens and one of them is carrying a little box in his hands. I mean, if you're gonna take someone out, shouldn't you also carry a gun??? We never know what this guy's carrying. We also never know where the virus came from; we only know that a dog dies from this virus and infects his owner, early on in the movie. There were little things in the movie that could have been turned into interesting plot twists, but Eli Roth keeps it raw ands simple and without any fancy plot twists. All in all, CABIN FEVER was a fun movie to watch, It's not the perfect horror film, but like I said, it was fun to watch and seems to have been made by people who are true fans of the genre!

Well, despite of its good basic idea to form a scary movie without ghosts, zombies, wicked spirits or serial psycho killers, it turned out to be a very poor production in the end. The storyline is very common, still one can do a lot with it. But Eli Roth blew that chance by horrible script. The screenplay is so bad it becomes hilarious when combined with the gory scenes the movie contains. And for gore, well, it is abundant, but in wrong places. For example I expected much more gore in the leg-shaving scene.OK, jokes aside, I am fairly disappointed. B-grade horror movies always have their special places for a viewer, if made well. But with such potentials, "Cabin Fever" could provide more suspense and horror.

The first thing I expected with Cabin Fever was that it would be all blood and no body. But to my pleasant surprise, Cabin Fever is almost quite intelligent, fun and quite a good movie. It is completely expecting, unpredictable and even quite funny at times. If you don't understand the horror parameters, this movie may fly under your radar, but a seasoned horror fan will appreciate everything in this film. A nod to B-Grade horror movies like The Evil Dead, Cabin Fever is surprisingly original and fun to watch. Unlike reviews that I have seen for this film, Cabin Fever is probably one of the most underrated and most under appreciated films ever made. Eli Roth really does know how to make a good movie.

Cabin Fever was better than I expected but there were some things that weren't that good. For the most part the movie was a well made horror film that tells the story of five college friends on vacation at a remote mountain cabin when one of them contacts a flesh-eating virus. The movie is a somewhat realistic look at how people would react to such a situation. The movie stars Rider Strong (from Boy Meets World), Jordan Ladd (Broken Lizard Club Dread), Cierina Vincent (whose "spolier" featured in two steamy sex scenes one of which is good and another is okay at first then it gets weird. For those of you who have seen it. You know what I mean), James DeBello (from Detriot Rock City), Joey Kern, and the rest of the cast of unknowns are believable in their roles. I didn't really like the ending which could've been better and the dialogue wasn't the greatest at times but overall Cabin Fever is an effective horror thriller better than others that have come out recently from writer/director Eli Roth the man behind Hostel and Hostel Part 2 which at least to me weren't as good as this one. So if you're in the mood for a decent horror thriller you can go wrong with Cabin Fever. It (for the most part) delivers on whats expected from these kind of movies.

Five teenagers(that look like adults) are going camping together but they suddenly find themselves among very strange people and the cabin which they are staying at itself is a little freaky. But the horror starts, when each one of them gets infected with a horrible disease, a virus that eats away at the flesh. This movie was VERY gross, there was way to much blood and gore but however, it was still a fun movie with hilarious moments. The acting was decent yet at times very cheesy. It isn't oscar material, but it sure is entertaining. I would give Cabin Fever 6/10.

Review title: Brainless horror, for the most undemanding audiences only
Review_body: A group of beer-guzzling College drop-outs rent a cabin in the middle of a Forrest, but their fun's about to end when a flesh-eating virus begins spreading among them. I put-off watching this for a while because it didn't look promising, but let me tell you, this film is so damn stupid that when it was all over I just found myself starring at the screen in awe. How could this have been made?Problems start with the script, which is brainless in the most extreme meaning of the word. The characters are so stupid, their actions so dumb, cliché's are plentiful, and the hillbilly endingwhat was that? How Eli Roth managed to get the film made is truly beyond me.Acting ranges from just plain good (Strong and Ladd stood out) to overdone (DeBello) to just plain bad (Andrews). Everyone involved must have wanted money really, really desperately. Hopefully they have all since fired their agents. The music was also annoying and out of place. A moodier, more atmospheric score maybe would have made the film at least a little effective, but the score the makers decided to use instead consist mostly of annoying pop songs.If there are any real merits here are the gore effects, from the always reliable KNB effects group, who have done a bang-up job here (the laughable Deer scene not withstanding). There's virtually no CG effects here, thankfully, and the old-school effects were the only thing that had me watching in the end. "Cabin Fever" is a stupid, ridiculous horror movie that never takes itself serious enough. It had the potential to be a cult classic but fail miserably in the end.Oh, and is anyone getting tired of gun-slinging in-bred hillbillies in these types of flicks? 1.5/10.

What is not to like about this movie
First of all .2 of the most gorgeous chics ,you will ever see in a horror movie
It must be the first horror I've ever enjoyed while sporadically laughing out loud .Hilarious in parts .One of the babes shaving her legs while knowing she has flesh eating decease😂
Seriously enjoyable watch though

Review title: Is everyone in horror movies an idiot?
Review_body: I rented this movie today mostly because I loved Hostel movies directed and written by Eli Roth. I thought it would be interesting to see his earlier stuff. But funnily enough the most interesting thing about the whole thing is that it's listed as both "comedy" and "horror". Watching the film I had no idea it was supposed to be a comedy as well. Sure, it's slightly absurd, but not so much I'd see right away that it's comedy. There are jokes there, of course, but there are in several horror films, and they aren't automatically comedies. Well, you can always learn more about movies...The music in this film is completely unnerving. The soundtrack of this film is magnificent, and a good score always gives a horror film something extra. There are genres where it doesn't matter so much, but in horror it's surprisingly important. It keeps you on your toes. And even the lack of soundtrack is extremely effective in horror movies. But in Cabin Fever there is a soundtrack, and it works.The thing about Cabin Fever is that there's no serial killer hunting the young characters. The "bad guy" of the film is a disease. And what's the thing about that? You can't outsmart it. But still, the characters are idiots. That is of course a typical trope in horror, but sometimes someone does something so obvious you want to punch them. Someone is infected and you decide go touch them? Yeah that's definitely a great idea!Cabin Fever is thrilling, yet there's something about it that makes it slightly annoying. I enjoyed watching it this first time, when I have no clue what's going to happen, but I doubt I'm going to see it again.

Cabin fever tells the story of a group of friends who have just finished college and decide to stay at a cabin for a week or something. When one of the friends stupidly decide to go hunting with a gun for squirrels,he shoots a man who looks sick and infected. Then the friends tell story's around a camp fire when they meet a man who has a dog and is very violent threw out the film. Then this infected man knocks on there door and remember the man that shot him,he tells them not to let him in as the man try's to open there trucks door,the friends run out with weapons and the truck sets in fire and so does the man. The next day,everyone is scared by it and one of the friends who has a crush on a girl gets into bed with her when he finds out she has the infection. The friends put her in the shed as she just wants to go home. The next day,the friends go looking around for help when a weird sheriff who loves partying tells them everything is going to be OK. Soon,everyone starts getting the virus and spoiler everyone dies in the end. I loved this film so much,so original and cool. I saw all the sequel which were all crap. I mean the prom come on,I also saw the remake and to be quite honest it was the exact same as the original but very very gory but it was OK. Cabin fever is a class teen horror film for horror fans.

Review title: A sick, twisted cabin in the woods horror movie
Review_body: Cabin Fever 12/6/2009This film is the directorial debut for Eli Roth. Eli is a Boston native and horror fan boy at heart. Cabin Fever takes on several parts of well known horror films and put his out ideas and twists on them. This is a creepy cabin in the woods movie like Evil Dead. It's a mysterious virus movie like The Thing. Then throw in some crazy back woods rednecks like Deliverance. Cabin Fever is disturbingly authentic in the fact that this could actually happen. Eli got the idea from a real life experience, when he got a flesh eating bacteria at an Icelandic horse farm.Cabin Fever starts out like many recognizable horror flicks. A group of young people headed into the woods to a cabin for a weekend of partying. The main characters are Paul and Karen played by Rider Strong and Jordan Ladd. They have been "friends" forever, while Paul is always pushing for closer relationship. Bert is the not to bright football player like character played by James DeBello. Then there is the yuppie douche bag couple. The blonde haired Ivy League style jerks always get butchered and for good reason. The look of the film is set in the early to mid 1980's, so that rules out any cell phone usage. We don't ever learn the origins of the virus, although we do see a dead dog that infects a local hermit. Bert accidentally shoots and wounds the hermit while hunting for squirrels. That night the man comes to the cabin pleading for help. He is a horrible bloody mess who after puking infected blood all over their truck, is set on fire by the guys. The girls are upset by this and it creates a great deal of tension and dissension in the group. Paul finds the decomposing body floating in a lake. The virus has now infected the water supply for the whole town.Winston Olsen is a young sheriff deputy and quite the strange character. He is bored to death with his job and just likes to party with all the vacationers. Even when the story gets extremely gory he is only worried that that party is ruined. Another very unique character is Dennis, played by Matthew Helms. He sits on a swing in the front of the town general store. Don't get to close to him though because he bites, as Paul finds out. He is also known as the "Pancakes" boy who has a black belt in karate. Yes I know that sounds a little strange but you really have to see the movie.One of the most disturbing scenes in the movie is when Karen who hasn't been feeling well, lets Paul comfort her while she's napping. Paul moves his hand below her waist and you could say he has bad aim. He finds out that he is fingering a large flesh wound in her thigh. She is infected. Karen is then ostracized and quarantined from the others. She is locked in a shed with a grungy mattress and a blanket and then served food like a prisoner. The characters are now only interested in their own survival. Even though this movie was made in 1999, the main story line and the characters reactions to it seem to match today's fears of the swine flu and global flu pandemics. They all eventually get this virus and deal with it in their own separate ways. The leg shaving scene is quite possibly the most cringe inducing scene ever filmed. While the blonde guy take two six packs of beer and runs into the woods. If you look at the beer closely it's called "Arrogant Bastard Beer". He does how ever get his comeuppance for abandoning his friends. In one of the movies final scenes he is killed in a very similar fashion to that of the classic zombie flick "Night of the Living Dead" The last scene shows a semi truck full of tainted bottled water leaving the small town. There is a sequel, Cabin Fever 2: Spring Fever which is directed by Ti West. It is currently showing at various film festivals around the country and is not yet out on DVD. Eli Roth had no part in the filming or production. So see it at your own risk.

Review title: If you go unbiased into this film it's not that bad
Review_body: This is a teen horror movie so the only rule it has to follow is that everybody gets killed off, one or two at a time, by a scary monster.The scary monster is given away in the title of the movie - it's a bacteria/virus. That was the first thing that was impressive, no matter how small. It always has to be about monsters, serial killers and other physical peekaboos. A teen horror flick with a virus is welcome change.The group of teenagers brought in for the slaughter is a group of not very likable city college students coming over to a strange small local community. They behave erratically and panic when under pressure. This unlikability and reactionary behavior makes them realistic, even though the specific actions of those characters are not.There is not that much happening in the movie and it could have done much more with the idea than it did, but the movie did creep me out - something a lot of horror movies fail to do.

A bunch of friends visit a remote part of America - not quite sure where - to spend a holiday in a cabin in the woods (clearly, none of them have seen Friday the 13th OR The Evil Dead.) Anyway, one of their number inadvertently contracts a hideous virus that eats the flesh. As one after another succumbs to the deadly virus, we get to share their true thoughts about one another.An interesting, gory, and often disturbing horror from the director of Hostel, this is shocking in places, and hangs together well as a movie. OK, it feels a bit like an extended episode of The X Files, but there's nothing wrong with that.A good movie.

Welcome back to a new age of horror.  We are not in it just for the gore but for the story as well.  This movie was near perfect.  It plays on fears of people.  What would you do to protect yourself and family?  How far would you go?  This movie shows you just that.I will own this movie and will definitely watch it again before it leaves the theatre.  Take a chance on this movie, I'm sure that it will be around for some time.Thanks to the makers of this film. It is good to see that new ideas are still there for horror films and not just the same crap.

I already know the sequel will suck and the remake is god awful but this film is good. I like this film and I do see problems in the film. I'm not saying the film is the best but it's really bloody for fans that like horror movie that's bloody. Now Bert in this movie is the rebel (he's better than the other Bert in the remake). This film is good not great or perfect.Score: 7.5/10

Review title: Movies don't get much worse than this.....
Review_body:
**SPOILERS BELOW!!!**Cabin Fever has my nod for WORST film of the year...that I've seen that is. This movie is straight GARBAGE!  There is so much wrong with the film you can't help but be amazed at how bad it really is.  This movie had so much potential to be good, but ultimately made nothing of it.  The characters were as dumb as one can be; for the entire movie you're just asking yourself "why would you do that?" or "what's your point in doing this?"...this is how illogical and stupid the characters are.  We get NO background into them, so naturally you really don't give a rats as$ about their fate...you could only laugh at their stupidity.  The 'slut' (Marcy) for instance... was she that horny that she had to sleep with Paul (Rider Strong)?  There was no point in that....its almost as if the filmmakers needed a excuse to give her the virus so voila!  UGH. 
Would anyone really go into the woods and drink water from the faucet of a cabin WITHOUT looking at it first?Why didn't Bert just shoot the sick guy from the start?  Movie would've been over that way....besides, they ended up killing him anyway.Why did it take them so long to finally decide to leave the cabin, even if they had to walk?  'No, I'll just wait until 2 of my friends are infected (one a blink away from death) to finally opt to walk outta there.What was exactly the reasoning behind Paul's attempt to fish out the body of the Hermit, only to fall in the contaminated reservoir and get infected with the virus?  Pure STUPIDITY!I swear, common sense was not a friend, much less an aquaintance to these idiots.  I don't think there has ever been a worse ending to a movie.  In the beginning the kids ask the hick store cashier what the rifle was for, and he replied that 'its for the niggers'.  In the end of the film, 3 young Blacks (dressed in baggy clothes, one of them in a du-rag no less) go into the store....come to find out that the cashier was cleaning it for them to be used for hunting.  THEN, he proceeds to give them all pounds and handshakes and joke around with them as if they're his homeboys.Okay, WHAT THE HELL WAS THE POINT OF THAT?!?!?!?  How tasteless can one be, what were the filmmakers THINKING putting that in the movie?  I as a Black man was of course offended by the initial 'Nigger' comment.  It was a tasteless, pointless remark.  My question to the filmmakers: what was the point of the ending with the Black kids?  Was that to force me to forget about the initial racist comment made earlier?  To smooth things over with Black viewers, by making a joke out of it?  Well, I for one, did NOT find that pathetic attempt at humor funny in the least bit.  The whole movie was a joke....a PATHETIC attempt at filmmaking that shouldn't be given the time of day.  Peter Jackson really thought this film was that good?  What film was HE looking at?  ZERO * out of **** stars....if I could give it a lower rating I would. Please, fellow IMDb'ers, don't waste 1 1/2 hours of your precious life watching this abomination of a 'movie'.  This is one of the worst movies I've EVER seen.

Review title: Despite the teenage angst the film is fun.
Review_body: Most viewers will find the movie fun to watch. It has decent pacing with good direction. Even though the film was't the best, it does alot right compared to other horror films. The effects used are good and threat presented is real enough to create anxiety for the viewer. I find the acting suspect but its not all poor. Its overall story is some what average and follows the structure of other horror films.

Review title: If she has contacted a flesh eating virus, locking her in a shed is not advisable.
Review_body: Most of my movie-watching time is spent taking in new films. New releases, older stuff I'm just seeing for the first time, so on. That's one of the reasons why I enjoy Halloween so much. It's a time for me to revisit stuff I haven't seen in a while. Sometimes that's like visiting old friends. Other times that means reassessing my opinion on films I haven't seen a while. Thus: "Cabin Fever." I loved it when I first saw it in the theaters and I don't think I've seen it since then. With the possible exception of Rob Zombie, Eli Roth is the most divisive filmmaker to come out of the horror wave of the last decade. The tide of controversy his "Hostel" films ignited easily overshadowed his first feature.Roth's biggest problem is evident through all of his movies. The dude can not write genuine, likable characters. At best, they come off as simple sketches. At worst, they are intensely unpleasant jerks. Case in point: In "Cabin Fever," characters are separated into two types. Rider Strong and Jordan Ladd are the main characters, defined solely by their relationship to each other. Strong's Paul is trying to transfer from childhood friend to serious romantic partner to Ladd's Karen. That's pretty much it. Their personalities otherwise morph in accordance to the story's whims. The rest of the main cast is obnoxious, deeply unlikable cartoon characters. Joey Kern's Jeff spews homophobic dialogue, does senseless things like shop-lift or shoot animals, and never lets the audience forget for a minute he's a jockish bonehead. As bad as Jeff is, James DeBello's Bert is even worse. An opportunistic lout who doesn't seem capable of caring for another person. He spends most of his screen time screaming profanity at his friends, begging the question of why he is on this trip with these people. Despite being a massive tool, the guy has an absurdly hot girlfriend in the shape of Cerina Vincent's Marcy.Marcy best exemplifies the movie's biggest issue. The characters lack any common sense. They made wildly bad decision for no particular reason. If you accidentally shoot a guy, you take him to the hospital and apologize profusely. If a sick person comes to your door, call 9/11. Do not attempt to beat him to death with bats and crowbars. (And stop taking swings if you're destroying your only mode of transportation.) Most definitely do not set him on fire. If a friend has contacted an aggressive flesh eating virus, locking her in a shed is not advisable. Marcy's only defining characteristic is her overwhelming sluttiness. When it becomes obvious she has the virus, she decides random, enthusiastic fornication is the only course of action. I know Cerina Vincent is really hot but, if she's infected with a vicious skin-eating disease, decline her sexual advances. It won't end well. And, hey, what's a natural thing to do when a horrible virus is drilling through your layers of dermis? "Shave your legs" is not an appropriate answer. If you see a dead body floating in a reservoir, do not climb down a rickety ladder just to poke it with a stick. Writing characters who are intentionally dumb is one thing. Having your characters do things that no human being would ever do is an entirely different faux-pas. Even the otherwise sensible humans make astonishing bad decisions.Roth's strengths as a writer and director is his surreal sense of humor and an ability of craft sickening horror set-pieces. And that's why "Cabin Fever" is worth checking out at all. The local redneck characters are bizarre enough to be humorous. Which do you prefer, the blonde hair kid who screams about pancakes and does inexplicable karate moves? The local deputy who highly moans about "parties," in the face of all sanity? How about the kindly, folksy shop owners who engages in unexpected racist dialogue? (A gag that has a hilarious pay-off at the end.) Even Roth's aggravating cameo gets a laugh or two. Later on, the harmonica man and a resilient deer appear, to choruses of laughter. As for the horror sequences, some of them are gleefully nasty, like the Bowling Alley Massacre or Strong turning on the trio of invading rednecks, the result of a man weaned on seventies/eighties sleaze-exploitation horror films. Others are body-horror worthy of Cronenberg, like the snap of an ankle or red marks trailing down a back.Angelo Badalamenti's score is unnerving and gets under your skin in the same way the movie's disease does. Roth's direction is stylish enough. I'm not sure if his horror-nerd homages are endearing or annoying. All the songs on the soundtrack are from "The Last House on the Left." In any other movie, a lingering shot on your actress' plump butt would be just that. In a Roth film, it becomes a callback to "Texas Chain Saw Massacre" or "Friday the 13th Part II." A screwdriver in the ear? "Dawn of the Dead." Vomiting on somebody? "The Fly." The movie even has the Batcave putting in a cameo. Not to mention the entire premise owes a considerably amount to "The Evil Dead." Roth's homophobic dialogue is as tin-earred and hard-to-swallow here as it is in "Hostel." Talking about a dog sticking its nose up your anus isn't helping your case, Eli.Still, the parts are greater then the whole. "Cabin Fever" is worth sticking around through for the wacky or sickening moments, even if Roth's flaws as a writer are all too apparent. The "Thanksgiving" trailer is still the best thing he has ever done.

Ah, damn. I really wanted this movie to be awesome. I've loved horror films my whole life, and "Cabin Fever" is being marketed as a return to the raw, low budget, deep-in-the-woods horror films like some of my favorites. And yes, those films, like "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre", "The Evil Dead", and especially "Night Of The Living Dead" are constantly referenced and ripped-off (which I wouldn't mind if it was any good), but "Cabin Fever" itself, which should be able to stand up on its own...sorta sucks. The basic idea is a GREAT one. 5 mostly annoying college students rent a cabin in the woods to party for a week. That's interrupted on the first night by a drifter who stumbles up to their cabin. The drifter has some sort of flesh-eating virus that has already turned his skin into a bloody mess. Scared of contagion, the kids threaten him until he runs away, but not before he vomits blood all over their truck. Before long, one of their own, Karen (Jordan Ladd) begins to show signs of infection, so they lock her in a shed. Unfortunately, she's the only character who is sort of likable, so we're left with a bunch of jerks for most of the rest of the movie. The movie's main problem, and it's the one that kills it, is of tone. One minute it's a straight-up horror movie, then it's a stupid (and I mean STUPID) comedy. After a while we don't know whether we're supposed to go "Ahh!" or "Haha!" when the bodies start dropping, and as a result, do neither. Horror and comedy can mix quite well, but since the comedy here sucks, it keeps killing the mood and by the end has completely ruined it.
The horror elements are strong. There are some extremely unsettling ideas here, most notably the girl left in the shed to rot (literally), who is in much worse shape every time they go check on her. Wait til you see her in her final state. But every time it gets good, the "comedy" comes in and ruins it all over again. This movie honestly hurts me, because there is so much potential for a great, gory backwoods horror movie here. Director and co-writer Eli Roth obviously has good taste in horror movies, but he dropped the ball in a major way.

Review title: The early 2000s had some of the worst horror! And you people ate this one up too lol
Review_body: Can't believe how people who clal themselves horror fans loved this film so much... It's played out like a sitcom because it's super dull and looks like a TV movie...It's gross but not a good film... This one was a little too cheesy for me and Hicks don't make me laugh.

Apart from the rest of the recent cheap horror movies, this movie is loaded with shocking gore and scenes so gross and at times nightmarish that if nothing else, you will remember it for some time to come.Cabin Fever has your basic plot (like that of Friday the 13th) where a bunch of teenagers decide to go to some remote location for a camping trip.  But the killer in this film is a flesh-eating disease that rots away at your body at an accelerated rate.  What's worse is that once the disease enters the bloodstream you're...yep, a goner!  And the death is slow, painless, and pretty much ruins your chances of getting a date on a Friday night.Five hapless individuals start out having the time of their youthful lives, living it up with the stereotypical sex, drugs, and rock-and- roll.  Soon after, they encounter a local man who is infected with the strange disease. The forester is somewhat delusional having been in the woods rotting away. He tries to seek help from the kids but their fear of him and the unknown that is eating away at him scare them.  In a panic they end up setting the stranger on fire.  What they fail to realize is that his dead body ends up floating in the nearby lake, infecting the small town's water supply. Anybody thirsty?  Well, of course, one of them ends up drinking the water. The remaining members go nuts over how the disease was contracted and they each begin turning on one another in a "every man for himself" philosophy. To add to the dire straits, their vehicle is out of commission so that they can't go for help.  As they try to repair it, time slowly ticks by.  One of them sits in a locked shed (sequestered from the others) slowly decomposing from the outside.  The rest of them are...well...standoffish to put it mildly.The ridiculous which is already somewhat present, enters in full when some of the villagers go after the teenagers to kill them before they contaminate the whole town.  The gore and shock levels then go up to a twelve on a ten-point scale with unforgettable scenes like the sleeping sick girl, the Listerine disinfecting (guys I know you'll cringe in pain), and the bathtub shaving scene (girls, this will make you feel different when shaving).This movie stands apart from the rest in disgustingly creative shock treatment with a killer that you can't see - a disease.  Cabin Fever will make you think of stocking up on Zephyr Hills water the next time you go camping.  Happy trails.

Review title: a great throwback horror flick, sam raimi would be proud
Review_body: eli roth's cabin fever is a great ride full of gore, laughs, homages to classic horror movies, and a cabin that looks suspicialy like the one from the evil dead, but isn't that the point. eli roth also makes a hilareous cameo as a stoner, a role he played again in 2001 maniacs. the script is never going to win any Oscars, and not all the acting is great, but in a way it makes it more of a purer horror film, group of unknowns, in the woods, buckets of gore, just like the good old days. im a fan of eli roth's work, and the movie has a much lighter tone than his hostel movies, but is too grim to be a comedy, so in many ways it is like sam raimi's evil dead in it works better as both, i highly recommend

Review title: The dialogue and characterisation is embarrassingly bad
Review_body: The only positive for 'Cabin Fever' is that it boasts a decent premise. But lets be honest, anyone can come up with a good premise. What's particularly challenging, is writing a script that contains such bad dialogue that you can't recognise your fatal inability to script. It serves a warning for anyone getting into the film industry: if this is the best you can muster, do everyone a favour and pick a different career. Eli Roth and his co-writer (not even worth remembering his name) manage to create a horror film that is horrifying in all the wrong ways.The story is about a group of friends staying at a cabin in the woods who fall victim to a flesh-eating virus. Unfortunately, the characterisation and dialogue is so painfully immature and inept, that you don't care what happens to them. In fact, they are so unlikable in their own way - racist, cheats, or thieves to name a few - that they deserve to suffer. One by one they contract this nasty disease, and the decision-making becomes more implausible and excruciating as the film goes on.Pointless sex scenes, nonsensical homicidal streaks, stupid police enforcement, a random retarded kid who likes to bite ... it's all here ready to further antagonise any rational audience member. Even the gore effects are tame, with little creativity gone into the flesh-melting possibilities. All of this makes for an experience that has no entertainment value; the camera work is adequate, but everything else varies from problematic to downright abysmal. Like the virus, this is a horror film best avoided.3/10

So I went to see this film twice opening day not necessarily cause it was a great horror movie but because i had promised people I'd go see it with them at two different times that day. My first initial reaction after leaving it the first time was extremely mediocre. I felt it was completely innovative and clever.  The acting was good, the spfx gory, the story decent and the direction a little off kiltered.  I'm probably one of the biggest horror fans you'll ever meet! So my expectations were pretty high and although I felt the film delivered on many levels.  I loved the homages to Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Mother's Day, Last house on the left, Night of the living Dead, Evil Dead and etc. And the film is definatly a powerhouse for people who have seen these movies. But what the film truly lacked was entertainment value. It was truly an unpleasent film filled with nasty things.  Not very entertaining at all.  However, on second viewing after seeing it with an audience my opinion has changed. It's an audience movie, something cultish to be shown at midnight with a bunch of people that know the film scene for scene.  The auidence had a ball with this film, there was screaming and laughing.  And groans of disgust as they showed the nasty and believable fx(especially the leg shaving scene). So my opinion changed and I found it quite entertaining. Sure it's a sick movie but it definatly gets a great reaction from the audience and thats the way it should be seen.  The film may not be top of the line but the director and creator of this pic Eli Roth has big time flair.  I eagerly await his next and more finely tuned offerings. 7/10 -Don't miss out see it in the theatres

Never pass up an opportunity to see teenagers meeting gratuitously grisly ends. If only the cellphone-wielding adolescent cretins who insist on cluttering up my local cinema would suffer a similar fate. Then again, it was foolish of me to venture out to see a horror flick on its opening night and not expect a barrage of unfunny comments accompanied by a symphony of annoying ringtones. I live, but I don't learn.Oh, the movie. Patchy and derivative, but packed with enough bizarre and delightfully stomach-churning moments to overcome any technical shortcomings. If you want serious, beautifully rendered, intellectual fare, go see The Hours. I'd rather take a blood-soaked trip into the woods with three bozos, a bunch of hillbillies and a couple of scantily or unclad chicks.Certainly the most fun I've have at the flicks this year, moronic audience and all.

This is about some kids who go to a secluded cabin in the woods for some heavy duty partying. But there's a guy living out in the woods who has a strange disease - flesh eating bacteria or something. He ends up dying and falling into the reservoir for the area's drinking water. So, the infection spreads.The good: Nice characters; fun, sexy, humorous, likable. These folks seem like they could actually be a group of friends, they more or less like each other. Most of the action is fairly believable, most of the secondary characters are totally over the top but also in a sort of believable way.The bad: The plot. We never learn the source of this bacteria, and the movie doesn't really have any ending as far as the spread of the disease. Sure, there's a climax to the movie, and it's rather clever, but the whole disease thing is just left up in the air.Overall, I'll give it a 5. Average, okay, a semi-satisfying waste of 90 minutes.

Review title: fun, crazy, and inspiring...HAIL ELI ROTH!
Review_body: When was the last time you loved a movie so much that you spent more money renting it over and over than you would have if you had bought two copies? When I first heard of Cabin Fever, I was foaming at the mouth. I had read nothing but praise for it, and was just dying to see what Eli Roth had committed to film. I read all the flack about "...return to 70s" and interviews with Eli about what he was trying to accomplish. I thought, "Thank God, someone has come along with enough love for the genre that he could possibly resurrect from the stream of crap that it has become. All this just made me want to see it even more. When the day finally came, I was there, in the theater waiting with glee, wishing there were some way that I could hit the fast-forward button and skip through the trailers. I was a little nervous. Had I built it up too much? Had I set myself up for a big let down? No and no. "Cabin Fever" was even better than I had anticipated. My (then) girlfriend was repulsed and furious that we hadn't gone to see "Matchstick Men" instead. Me, being the selfish jerk that I am, found myself in the theater again, the very next weekend for a second viewing. I couldn't get enough. I was completely hooked.Why am I so obsessed with this movie? Well, I'm not exactly sure why. Maybe a shrink could figure it out, but I can tell you what I LOVED about this movie: First would be the characters. I loved every single one of these guys and gals and was with them all the way. For one, they were all REAL, not some cookie-cutter stereotypes that we're so used to seeing. These are real, flawed human beings. Ryder Strong did great as Paul and Joey Kern was very good as Jeff. He's the one that you love to hate. Cerina Vincent was wonderful as Marcy and Jordan Ladd was good as Karen. My personal favorite (aside from Deputy Winston) was Bert, played with great energy by James Debello. Yeah, he's the "comedy relief" and all and he's supposed to be annoying, but I love his carefree attitude and his laugh had me laughing. His squirrel shooting antics were hilarious and I still laugh when I think about the Snickers bar. Many have complained about Deputy Winston (Giuseppe Andrews) showing up midway through the movie and supposedly "wrecking everything". To me, these were some of the comic highlights and he gets most of the best lines in the movie. Just the idea of a party-hard Deputy puts a big smile on my face and his reaction to the truck still gets me. In fact, his reaction to anything odd gets to me.I love the look of the movie. I guess it's supposed to be Spring, since they're on Spring Break vacation, but to me, it looked like Fall. Whether this is a goof or not, I don't really care. It gave the film a great look. I loved the set-design of the cabin. That cabin is a character in itself. Next time you watch it, pay close attention to the detail.The pacing: I love it. The first half is relatively tame and plays more like a comedy. You meet the characters, spend time with them as they party and do their thing, and begin to feel sorry for them because you know all is about to be ruined. I especially loved the campfire tale about the bowling alley. Classic indeed. Once things finally kick into gear, the last third moves at a breakneck pace. THAT was great directing and as for the ending, well, (notice how I'm avoiding spoilers for those who haven't seen it) I really hope that Eli gets it in him to do a sequel because I want it to continue.In short, I love this movie so much it's downright scary. I don't know for sure how many times I've seen it over the last years and there's no telling how many times I'll watch it for years to come. Clichéd as it may sound, this is by a horror fan FOR horror fans. Easily in my top 5. HIGHLY Recommended

Review title: A Good Effort in the New Paranoia (possible spoilers)
Review_body: While not a perfect movie by any means, Cabin Fever succeeds in  creating an atmosphere of suspense at appropriate times while not becoming entirely dependent on gore and violence to get there.  The acting was passable and the story was well-told, with enough specifics left to the imagination to allow the audience to fill in the blanks with their own imagination -- a trademark of a successfully executed horror/suspense film.  The pacing is excellent; there are enough tongue-in-cheek moments and nods to the films which influenced it (including Cujo, Evil Dead, Night of the Living Dead, and Friday the 13th) to let the audience catch their breath before they start waiting for the next crescendo.  Each of the main characters has their own story and their own moment of climax throughout the film, giving the whole enough energy to reach a conclusion that makes it obvious that there WILL be a sequel.  A few factors make this a foregone conclusion:* One of the main characters survives* What's in the box?  Hint:  The director is already at work on a film with the working title "The Box."* A truck full of the local water pulls out of town in the film's last scene.This film is part of a new genre.  In the 1950's and 1960's, the main source of paranoia was the USSR and nuclear weapons.  During the height of the Cold War, there were a long series of films about atomic mutants, creatures awakened by the bomb (e.g. Godzilla), and the world ending in nuclear war (On the Beach, for instance).  In today's new paranoia, the focus is on biological weapons, and hence we are seeing a new series of films that play to that fear.  "28 Days Later..." and "Cabin Fever" are excellent examples of this, and we can expect to see many more films of this sort coming at us in rapid succession over the next few years.All in all, "Cabin Fever" is worth seeing.  There's enough here to keep those who aren't going to faint at the sight of blood entertained.  It's not a great film, but it's definitely not a bad one.

Director Eli Roth is a rather clever man, as can be seen from this modern day horror film which has aspects of 70's and 80's horror in it. The movie should not be taken too seriously, it is a fun film, and it looks as though the cast are all enjoying themselves. The five main actors - Rider Strong, Jordan Ladd, Cerina Vincent, James DeBello and Joey Kern - are all great, particularly Strong and Ladd. The premise of the film is nothing new for a horror and blends the hillbilly outback of "The Texas Chainsaw Massacre" with the cabins of "Friday the 13th", and a deadly virus liken to "Monkey Shine". The combination, with great direction and a likable cast make for a good film that, while intense, does not require too much thinking. 8/10

Upon it's release this film was very heavily hyped as the best horror film in recent years. It isn't. However it is far from bad. The story revolves around five teenagers who go to a remote cabin in the woods to spend a week of shooting squirrels, having sex and drinking, but instead end up with a flesh-eating virus.The plot naturally enough gives plenty of opportunity for gruesome special effects, which are good for the most part, and despite being riddled with implausibilities and some frankly ridiculous scenes, the film remains for the most part both suspenseful and fun. The teenagers are mostly adequate enough, but they are not really particularly likable or interesting enough to care for.Fans of "splatter" horror films will probably enjoy this.

Review title: This isn't a documentary, let's see some gore.
Review_body: Cabin Fever should serve as a warning to new film makers... don't try to be clever. If you are clever, it will show in your work; if you're not clever no amount of trying will compensate.The movie starts well and has a very good, very straightforward plot: college kids in a remote location that are infected by a flesh eating bacteria. They try to survive each other as they try to survive the bacteria. But we can't just stop there, we have to have sexual intrigue (an excuse for nudity), a killer dog and some mentally unstable town's people and they just don't mesh together.I would have liked some stronger effects from the bacteria. They get infected, they bleed some, they fall down, bleed some more and die. Whoopee. This isn't a documentary, let's see some gore.

Review title: If you like downbeat 70s/80s style splatter horror, this'll be for you
Review_body: Cabin Fever starts pretty much as it means to go on. Within about five minutes of the fairly odd opening credit sequence, we've seen a dead dog covered in flies split in two. If this makes you think you're gonna hurl, grab some sick bags or just don't watch the movie at all, as it doesn't get any better.You see, seems there's a virus passing around the backwoods. Cue braindead teenagers piling into said backwoods for a bracing weekend of beer and nookie. As they do, in the States at least. One encounter with an infected local leads to the virus getting into their water supply, and the rest is fairly self-explanatory.It's nice (in a way) to see something as uncompromisingly nasty as Cabin Fever. In a similar fashion to Wrong Turn and The Toolbox Murders remake, Cabin Fever is unrepentantly un-PC and downbeat, and honestly all the better for it. Nobody in this movie gets off easy, good guys or bad guys, and to be honest, the teenagers are such vile self-serving pieces of work that it seems almost right that something bad should happen to them.That said, the movie is totally unbalanced. An attempt to inject some Evil Dead style slapstick comedy is pretty badly judged, and the less said about the almost Dude Where's My Car style dialogue the better. The main reason both are unwelcome is that without them, Cabin Fever would pack so much more punch. The failure for the elements of frat-boy comedy, doom-laden plotting and visceral gore sequences to ever mesh means that you'll come out wondering what the hell you just saw.Basically, Cabin Fever is a brave, violent addition to the horror genre, but not without it's flaws. On a final note, if you learn anything from this film let it be this: DON'T SET FIRE TO PEOPLE WHO TRY TO ASK YOU FOR HELP. THEY MIGHT BE INFECTED WITH A FLESH EATING SUPERVIRUS.

Review title: Worst movie i have seen in a long time (spoiler)
Review_body: What the hell where they thinking making this movie? As if Rider Strong hasn't already ruined television in the "comedy show" "boy meets world" , he now stars in this horrible horrible movie. I was actually p***ed that i had seen it when it was finally over. There is an hour and a half i will never get back. This movie is so terrible and so full of plot holes that it looks like a Swiss Cheese. The kids make one idiotic choice after another and if they shared half a braincell between each other they would all survive. Do people actually think this is what people in that situation would do? And suddenly Rider Strong turns out to be a cold blooded killer. And what about the ending, how much did that suck??? I am so very glad that i borrowed this movie from a friend and that i didn't pay money to see it, because then i would probably kill myself. If i could give this movie a 0 i would but i have to give it minimum 1 so there you go Cabin Fever. 1 is really too good for you.

As one who has been somewhat of a horror thriller fan for over a half century, I was surprised to see that a 2002 film had somehow totally escaped my attention, so I recently rented it on Netflix. It has been so thoroughly reviewed on this site I won't go into the plot itself. The early scenes got me interested and hopeful. I always enjoy when movies show a rural gas-station general store that has some strange people, as in "Texas Chainsaw Massacre" for example, or more recently, "Population 436", and the girlie looking Dennis certainly fit the stereo-type of strange or weird, with a sign warning people not to sit next to him, apparently with good reason. Then I heard a song by David Alexander Hess called "Wait For The Rain" which was written for the original "Last House On The Left" from 1973. Also the infected man with the flesh-eating disease was genuinely frightening. So I was hooked and hopeful I had overlooked a minor horror gem. I was wrong. As others have noted, the 5 teenagers (who look older than teenagers) have little resemblance to any college students I have known. More like itinerant construction workers on beer. Then too much time was devoted to their sexual appetites, slowing the pace somewhat, so the 90 minutes seemed much longer than that. Also it was hard to tell who was who, with a lot of unnecessary characters. The sequences often seemed confused and illogical. I think it had the potential to be a truly scary and rather original idea, but by the end it was a convoluted retread with some homages to better films. By the way, two other films about the water being a source of danger were 1986's "The Curse", with Wil Wheaton, and a slightly older minor indie "Nightmare At Noon" filmed in Moab, Utah. Neither were great films, but at least they were coherent, and I liked "The Curse" infinitely more than "Cabin Fever". Not as bad as some say, but not very good either, despite a promising beginning. Update: Repeated viewings have raised my opinion of this to about a 7 or 7.5.

Review title: Stupid College Kids/Stupider Adults+Poor Plot=Bad Movie!!!
Review_body: The premise of Cabin Fever starts like it MIGHT have something to offer. A group of college teens after finals (in the fall?) goes to a resort cabin in the woods where one by one they are attacked by an unseen flesh eating virus.Unfortunately, the first paragraph is where any remote elements of film quality stop. Cabin Fever is little more than college kids looking for sex, booze, talking non-stop about nothing, and seeing how many F-bombs they can get into 1:40 minutes or however long this mess is.The kids act and react stupidly to everything around them. One of them for instance discovers that the skin virus has infected her legs, so what does she do? She keeps shaving her legs failing to take proper medical attention for her wounds. The scene is little more than a gross out. In another scene, Rider Strong from "Boy Meets World" gets bitten on the hand by some kid who only says "Pancakes" and likes to do karate kicks on those who sit next to him. If you can figure out the reason for why the "Pancakes" kid was included, I'd love to know. Anyway, Rider pets a wild dog and goes off to wash his bitten hand in a most likely contaminated creek. Another kid likes to drop F-bombs in reacting to everything around him and shoot squirrels. Why? Your guess is as good as mine!Rider Strong is the ONLY kid with any recognition in this movie. He tries to calm people down in-between the yelling and screaming and F*** Y**! bombs that people are throwing around. When the kids aren't yelling, they are having or talking about sex or talking nonsense to the other adult characters who are EVEN MORE (if that is possible)idiotic than the kids! The idiot cop with an IQ of 60 at best may be one of the WORST acting jobs I have ever seen in a movie. You talk about people not playing with a full deck, this dork doesn't even know how to find the cards! LOL! I was like, "Will you PLEASE shut up already?!" He makes the kid actors look like geniuses! The only part that I sort of liked was Rider's scary story (although gory) about the deranged bowling alley guy. In interviews, Rider said that he had a great deal of respect for director Eli Roth. But the problem is that Mr. Roth appears to be going for little more than shock and gore. There are far too many bad things about this movie for Mr. Roth to get any credit. I wish I could agree with Rider and find something likable about this movie. Maybe the fall scenery in the beginning? Actually, Rider Strong JUST saves this movie from being a 1! Hopefully, he was compensated for this junk!

Review title: Scary, but not everyone cup of coffee
Review_body: As we already known, Cabin Fever supposed to be a homage to 70/80's horror classic, so the atmosphere and style are very reminiscent of those. Watching Cabin Fever is as watching those prior flicks with a bit millennium touch. The result is a scary and intense gore-fest.Cabin Fever told us about a bunch kids spend their weekend in a cabin deep in the wood. Little do they know, a deadly virus spread over the wood. When they realize that their life in danger, it's too late for them! The act for survive can be deadly it self.There's a lot horror movies lately, but most of them could easily watch with our own entire family (they aren't scary). In this case, I think the director is well managed the tension and did a good amount between scary and funny moments. Despite the cliché character and plot (it's the homage, right?), this is a good movie, even I can say that it is a restless movie. I must warn those whose have weak-hearted, this is not your cup of coffee and avoid it like the virus it self, before you burst your intestines out. If you miss those American Horror Movies that ever glory in the yesteryears, you should watch this. But if you dislike the sickening scenes and gore, avoid this!7/10

Its true that this movie doesn't really have a direction.  It kind of meanders around a bit.   But, all its meandering is HILARIOUS.  Party Cop, Grim, man, the characters that pop into  this film are great.  This movie has an identity problem, it doesn't really decide whether  it is a comedy or a horror, but overall, its excellent.  Buy some Miller High Life, get together with people who have a sense of humor and you will enjoy this movie!

Review title: how awful is cabin fever? let me count the waves...
