After a run in or two with some of the locals, the kids start getting infected with some sort of flesh-eating virus, and the battle for survival begins, with friendships put to the test, a very healthy helping of gore and nudity, heaps of randomness, and possibly the smartest character in a horror movie to date (when his friends get infected with the virus, he grabs a couple of six packs and takes off running).Performance-wise, 'Cabin Fever' is not outstanding, but certainly not terrible. The expletive-littered dialogue is ropey at times but provides a few decent laughs throughout, and when the virus starts taking hold of people, the make-up job is really quite impressive, providing probably the best shocks (and I use that word lightly) in the movie. On a whole it's fairly predictable but not altogether bad. There are some random, usually quite amusing moments - the "party" deputy; Dennis, the Karate Kid; the old man in the shop; and director Eli Roth's cameo as stoner Justin ("Yeah, he's a professor...") - but you're given the distinct impression that these were thrown in purely to flesh out the script to make it feature length, and thus have no real impact on the story. The last five or ten minutes descend into a farce, and the last scene in the shop is pretty unnecessary.It's very bloody, it's mildly amusing, and there's enough nekkidness on show to keep the morons entertained, but other than that it serves no obvious purpose. Just about watchable, thanks to the two gorgeous female leads, and, of course, Dennis.

Review title: Biggest bunch of bananas this side of c.1890
Review_body: Was it trying to be funny? Was it trying to emulate the classic '80s idiot-student horror film? How much was Peter Jackson paid to say it was great? The general scene, set deep in a conifer forest lends itself well to a potentially spooky film. A tired theme none the less !!!! Add a group of fresh university graduates with absolutely no common sense, a stereotypical script, loads of red grape juice thickened up with mono-sodium glutamate flowing out of every orifice, the local hermits, social outcasts with rotting teeth and weird children, a mad German shepherd dog, and the statutory single sex scene with no-show camera angles, and you have an instant turn-off-and-never-watch-again film. Oh and it wasn't funny either.Don't bother watching it, don't even think about it. This goes instantly into Room 101.

Review title: I wish I had never seen this movie.
Review_body: A one sentence summary:  A few corny jokes mixed in between tests of your gag reflex, and all topped off with an ending that didn't explain or solve anything.  I wish I had missed this one, not because it was scary, but because it was just disgusting and there was no plot behind it.  There's no explanation of what the virus is, all you know is that one guy gets it and everyone else starts to get it, too.  There's no real struggle to stop the virus or to stay alive (you know...PLOT), and it's like they go out of their way to make sure that you hate all the main characters and don't care when they die.  I was hoping for something along the lines of The Ring, where there are plot twists and a freaky cause of all of it, but there's nothing like that.  This is just a gore flick.  If you like that, fine.  If not, be glad that you were blessed with an ounce of brains and SKIP THIS MOVIE.

Review title: Just okay to watch once, but nothing I would ever see twice.
Review_body: "Cabin Fever" has a plot that is very simple. This is it: A guy cut up a sick infected dead dog. The guy gets infected of course. Then the guy transfers this virus to out-of-towner kids who are coming into town to screw around. The kids then die off one by one with horrible rashes where their skin peels off.Then the townspeople find out about what happened and instead of calling in help to save the kids or quarantine them, they decide to kill whoever is left alive, and burn the bodies. That's the whole movie pretty much.The beginning with the dead dog carcass was kind of a disappointment, because it was obvious what would follow. Although this movie has been bashed repeatedly (sometimes fairly, sometimes not fairly), the one thing I think was pretty scary was the scene was this.... When the couple were about to have sex in bed and he's touching the girl's thigh. It is bloody and then you realize she's been infected down there. That was gross.Overall, this was not a bad movie despite being a little too much on silly side. There were a few good twists that made it worthwhile. The twist at the end was also not bad, and was unexpected. The big problem is that the characters are not likable and you don't care if they get infected or not.

Review title: Rehashed teen stereotypes hampered this hackneyed attempt at horror...
Review_body: I have to be honest.  I only made it through half of this DVD before I had to shut it off.  For horror to be effective, there has to be an element of believability to the characters.  Instead, they were so poorly drawn that I quickly gave up caring what happened to them.  They represented two-dimensional teen stereotypes that any young adult should find insulting. I'd have to say that the best part of this movie was the trailer, which led me to believe that the movie had potential.

I thought Cabin Fever would be a brilliant horror,it was! The right amount of gore wasn used here, but i admit there was no scares in this film. But there was a good use of paranoia and reminded me of The Thing. This movie doesn't need a serial killer or monster, it has something new a flesh eating disease. This concept works well. Very well indeed.My rating 10/10

This had to be the worst movie that I have seen in a long time! Bad Acting, Bad Script...ok bad everything! We left in the middle of it, in fact, half the show left during the middle. I'm surprised we made it that long! How did this movie get such a high rating on here? I'm amazed!

There hasn't been any good horror movies recently.  The only one I can recall is Freddy vs. Jason.  I haven't seen Wrong Turn or House of 1000 Corpses but who cares, I'm pretty sure this movie is better then both.  The best part about this movie is how not holding back it is.  It shows how things would be in real life.  Like the deer and the truck scene.  Or the make up effects of the disease.  It was very real and very scary for being real.  Great horror movie, it reminded me of Evil Dead and other old horror movies.  It's good to see Rider Strong again but I couldn't get the Boy Meets World image away from the movie he was carrying but near the end, I didn't even think of it.  Cerina Vincent from Not Another Teen Movie who played the foriegn exchanged student, once again bares all in this movie, twice.  I found the movie scary with lots of good dark comedy themes to it. I know everyone loves this so I'll end it with... PANCAKES!!!!!!!

Cabin Fever starts off with a group a friends going to celebrate their graduation with a trip to a rustic looking cabin pretty much in the middle of nowhere. Upon arriving, they meet a dying man(who got sick from his dead dog, of all things) who tries to steal their vehicle to get help, one thing leads to another and the man gets lit on fire, runs off and somehow winds up dead in the cabin's water resevoir, and, as you guessed it, helps to infect the college graduates. We are then "treated" to an hour(on top of the 30 minutes used to set the story in motion) of the kids dealing with getting the illness, a vicious dog, a scene with a kid yelling about pancakes and practicing kung-fu(those who've seen it understand), irrational rednecks who can't use basic logic, an ending that partly rips of the original "Night of the Living Dead" and is highly anti-climatic, some "humour" involving a group of African-Americans and a rifle, which essentially goes against the "horror" aspect of the film and a cheesy montage of Rider Strong's character and the love interest.This film is an absolute mess that doesn't make a whole lot of sense and deviates from the horror aspect with half hearted attempts at humour and drama.For the love of all that is good, skip it.

Review title: What a waste of time and money...
Review_body: I purchased Cabin Fever whilst looking for a scary movie for me and my girlfriend to watch on Halloween, she scares easily so I wanted something terrifying and spine chilling, before I went shopping I searched for the best horror films and Cabin Fever kept coming up, so I thought "hey it must be good" how stupid and naive I was, this film is just terrible and not in the good horror way, the acting, the fakeness of the blood, the acting, the poor poor Lake Placid 2-3 like special effects, oh god the cringe worthy horrible shallow embarrassing fake acting.DON'T BELIEVE THE HYPE SURROUNDING THIS FILM IT'S A TRICK! THE FILM IS AN UTTER MESS! IF YOU WANT A SCARY FILM GO ELSEWHERE BECAUSE THIS WILL JUST FRUSTRATE AND ANNOY YOU!

The title sequence and the following 60 seconds are promising. But that's a promise that gets broken.  When all the cabin dwellers seem to be infected, one of the characters says that it feels like being on a plane that you know is going to crash.  I got the same feeling watching this movie.  Poor direction, bad editing.  It had some laughs; it looked good; the music was fantastic.  But the pilot of this plane (Eli Roth) just couldn't keep it in the air.  3 outta 10.

Review title: Delicious and twisted mixture of horror-themes
Review_body: This movie was already a classic before it even came out. Well, by rumors anyway. As Eli Roth's debut film it manages to deliver some serious chills and to be hilarious at the same time.Of course the plot is a cliché itself: A bunch of college kids travel to a remote cabin to relax but end up being harvested by a bloodthirsty bacteria. One could conceder this partly a unique idea as we haven't seen too many horror films that actually have a disease as the "villain/menace".This movie is most importantly stylish. The camera work and editing is in fact outstanding and i can see Roth has an eye for this kind of things. The eerie atmosphere is cleverly created with slightly moving camera and fantastic score in the background. Filled with tributes, funny jokes and twisted characters, Cabin Fever is absolutely one of the most precious things in the current horror cinema and if you haven't watched it yet, now is the right time! BTW, love the scene with the accordion. ;)

Review title: Just another b-movie with a budget
Review_body: I'm not sure where these directors get their kicks. It's probably the gore. Yeah! That's always fun! Lets make the audience squirm and go "EEEEWWWW!!!" Or maybe it's the babes! Yeah! Nudity and sex! That'll be fun. Lets get a girl naked for a movie that really doesn't take itself seriously. That is all and good. Heck I've seen some really great films that have just that. There's only one problem...This film isn't entertaining.This type of slash/gore film should not be striving for anything more than a creepy, scary time at the movies. It should be fun and self referring. It should have people laughing at the moron characters that can't seem to get away. It should never take itself too seriously, or think for a second that the film might be saying something more than it really is. This is Cabin Fever's problem. There is a time where everyone has finally seen all the blood and guts they can handle, and there is really nothing left in the script but badly written characters, a predictable and boring plot line, and gallons of fake blood to clean up.This film attempts homage to the old slasher flicks of the 70's and 80's, but really only reminds us how we wasted our time watching them. Not to mention this film as well.

Cabin Fever was not the best horror film of all time or anything BUT it was one of the best of 2002. It had the same formula of movies like Friday The 13th, kids going out to the cabin for some "fun" and getting knocked off one by one. The only difference here is that instead of a homicidal maniac it's a flesh eating virus. Now I am a Jason fan 100% I like to have a villain to root for, but I was really pleased with the way this film was told. It was scary and funny. Nice combination for a horror film that does not want to take itself too serious. The acting I will admit was not Oscar material but in my opinion it fit the movie. Cabin Fever has its moments that really freak you out a good example of this is when the blonde girl catches the virus and all her friends as well as her boyfriend put her in a shed away from them, they fear they'll catch the virus. But it shows how in extreme circumstances people will turn on the people they love. I gave Cabin Fever a 10 because it did what it was supposed to do. I enjoyed watching the film and even had a few laughs. Excellent Film!!

This is just a collection of gruesome scenes strung together by a ridiculous, unimaginative screenplay.  I like gory, violent horror flicks as much as the next guy, but this movie fails miserably to deliver on what should have been a pretty potent premise.As amateurish as the directing (and some acting is), the worst problem is the screenplay.  VERY MINOR SPOILER .... If this is supposed to be about a killer virus, why are the main menaces a mad dog and locals with shotguns? Why do the man characters seem to miss half-a-dozen potential escape routes to stay stuck in their silly predicament?  Why is the lead character such a zero?Anyone over the age of 12 should stay away from this stinker.

Review title: I felt the need to write this... (sorry, small spoiler- I think)
Review_body: A bunch of kids go to a cabin in the middle of the woods and subsequently become infected with a flesh eating virus.I felt the need to write this on account of all the negative reviews I have read. I know, everyone is entitled to their own opinion, but some people are fu*kin idiots. Sure this film wasn't "scary", but really- be honest with yourself, is any movie since the 80's scared you that much? I mean, Honestly. You may jump a few times, but you are not scared, and if you watched a horror movie with no jump scares, the scares are on account of "shock", and those are rarely any good. There are few filmmakers that can use this horror technique without immediately going into cliché category. Takashi Miike is one of the few lasting filmmakers that can still disturb me with his visuals, and its a shame he is not more known in the states. The scream/Friday the 13th/Halloween franchises are a joke, they are just keeping those films going because stupid teenagers (not all of them, I will admit... but most of them) keep fu*kin paying to see them. Cabin Fever is one of the few movies that tips it's hat to the old horror movies of the 70's-8o's without completely giving up all hope for a plot. This movie was meant to be scary, but not terrifying. I mean, you are a fu*kin lier if you tell me that you don't find the concept of a skin eating virus the least bit scary. And this whole "the characters act like psychopaths, and no one would actually act like that when put in that situation" argument is bullshit. Of course they would act like that! People are fu*kin selfish, man! You would do the exact same thing when put in that situation. The scary killer is not the flesh eating virus, but the teenagers themselves. In fact, looking back, I don't think one person died from the flesh eating virus in the film. All in all, I think this was a great horror film in comparison to the sh*t we are subject to on a daily basis. Eli Roth IS the future of the horror genre. That is inevitable. Lets just hope he doesn't fu*k it up more, which I highly doubt. Hostel looks excellent. In conclusion, I would just like to say, no- Cabin Fever was not horrifying, nor was it a classic. But it was entertaining and impressive due to the small budget (in comparison to the normal movie nowadays). 8/10

I think I read someone els say it best. This movie was terrible. I understand that the toronto film fest launched this film, but to this day I can't understand why, or....why. I, mean I really watched this film with a genuinely open mind trying to look at it in many a different way, but failed to place my finger on how this thing got labeled as good! I wouldn't waist your time. worst thing, I hear they're trying to do a sequel. brother... Eli roth is supposed to be coming out with a horror film inspired by the movie "Audition." Audition was awesome, but I cringe to think what Eli's next film will be like.

Cabin Fever is like your subconscious nightmare. Just the concept of some virus eating your flesh gives you the chills. Being a horror movie buff myself, I am very hypercritical of most horror movies, because most horror movies really aren't that scary anymore. But this movie, just makes you think "what if?" it very supernatural, but you still think "oh my god, that's going to happen to me". There were some scenes that made you think that it was so over the top and campy, but then you realize it really works. Cabin Fever is amusing, and gory fun. I highly recommend it to those who do not take movies too seriously, but still know how to enjoy a fun horror movie.

Review title: Not the worst movie I've seen, but in the top two.
Review_body: Before arriving at the cabin, a violently psycho child allowed to sit in public outside a general store bites the hand of a cabin inhabitant.  The General store owner tells the bit person to wash their hand in the creek out back.  Story gets worse from there.  There is a hermit who wears a trench coat and a deputy who arrives on a ten speed bike.  The "trapped" people have more visitors pop out of nowhere than a whack-a-mole game! With one bearing gifts from a zip-loc bag.  Somebody earshot hears them and calls the police, twice. These trapped people need to find this person.  And my favorite, gee our friends are dying from a flesh eating virus, want to have sex? Okay, sex is always appropriate.  But gee our friends are dying from a flesh eating virus, I'll be shaving my legs to increase my chances of infection.

With the current advent of lousy teen flicks, CABIN FEVER, stands out as a new venture into the horror genre, while going back to the basics of the likes of Evil Dead, TCM, and the terror of Deliverance. CABIN FEVER has done what WRONG TURN desperately tried to do. Become one of the best horror movies since Evil Dead: Dead by Dawn, and scaring the crap out of us. Sex, violence and gore...and a great story with superb acting...what more could a horror fan ask for? A modern classic. Hooray for Horrorwood!

this movie is freaking scary and i bet there are people making fun of me but i don't scare easily it is just scary seeing all that gore and to think that there may actually be a virus out there that can do this. Eli Roth makes a great debut performance and i give him 2 thumbs way UP!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!. if u wanna just watch a movie and cant decide just go to the movie store and rent cabin fever and tell me how it is by posting your own comment. something i didn't like was the continuous use of the F word i mean it would have been way more enjoyable watching a great horror movie without all the cursing i also think thats y everyone says bad things about it is because of the cussing. JUST REMEMBER IT IS AN ENJOYABLE MOVIE. RENT IT!!!!!!!!!!! Heath ***1/2 out of 4

This is a good film. I think that there are so many people who underestimate this film and think that it sucks, but being a pretty big movie buff myself and watching films all the time, this is a good movie. I think that anyone that truly likes movies would have some respect for this film. Any fans of directors out there would also have much respect for this film. Eli Roth is one of the most brilliant directors of all time, in my opinion. He never goes any other way with films. He is a horror buff and always sticks with his horror films, keep up the good work Eli Roth. And for those of you who don't know, there are parts of this movie that were inspired by true events that happened to Eli Roth. There is a great part in this film with a girl shaving her legs and her skin is peeling back. When Eli Roth was young, he had a disease where his skin would literally, if pushed on or scraped, would peel back from his body. Eli Roth is by far one of my favorite directors mainly because he never drifts away from the horror/violence films. Any fans of horror, this is a must see. View this movie with an open mind!

Review title: This movie put the Horr in Horrible
Review_body: If I wanted to rent a movie with lots of sex and cuss words in it I would have rented a porno. This movie was a terrible example of horror. I was disgusted by the way it had mostly gore and sex, but lacked the horror essential. I'm sure that the boys will like this film, especially the single ones who are very hormonal. But when you want a scare this is not for you. This is just as bad as House of 1000 corpses and The Village. I can't believe that the director allowed this to be filmed. Don't they watch these things before they make it to view in theaters. Rider Strong is lucky to be cute other wise I wouldn't have continued to watch it. If you want to fall asleep watch this then the Libertine. Waste of money personally. one of the 100 greatest horror movies, yeah right!

I'm so tired of horror movies containing such dumb teenagers that their combined IQ would not exceed 50. Such a cliche. I mean, can't they come up with something new?? This movie is so bad, I don't understand why some people like it so much. Don't waste your time on this trash. I wish I had gone to bed 2 hours ago instead of wasting my time on this. It didn't have anything and was a complete letdown. For example, there was a lot of hype about the 'shaving' scene. It sucked! I've seen worse in cartoons! And I was expecting something really nasty. 1 out of 10, just because I can't give it 0.

Review title: I love horror films but this...
Review_body: Boring. The worst word I could use to apply to any film, let alone a horror film. Tries to be quirky and off the wall but is just squirmingly transparently contrived. If you rent this on DVD (don't bother...really) you won't even bother to pause it for a bathroom break. The last year has seen a lot of sub-par horror that would normally skulk straight to video appear on the big screen, with films like "Cabin fever" this just seems insulting. Allegedly made by film fans...get back to watching them guys. Dont make any more. And Im not a hater... I just hate having my time wasted.

Review title: Great movie but not for everyone.
Review_body: This is the type of film that I have a hard time recomending even though I think it's great.  The reason it is hard for me to recomend this movie is because to me it is deeper than most horror or teen movies and also more disturbing than some.  Some of the stuff is more subtle or original and it might take a second or third viewing to fully appreciate certain parts. Most of the movie had a very cool and original look and feel that I liked very much.  The comedy of the film worked very well for me too.  There were a few moments that were a little too disturbing for my taste but most of the movie was right on. I will be very excited to see what this director does next.  I would like to see him stay with more independent stuff that he would have lot's of control over but I know it does not always work that way. I'm not a huge fan of horror movies but out of all the horror movies I have seen this was towards the top of the list.  I give this movie 8 out of 10

I've heard from numerous sources that this movie was very simple and anti-intelligent, so I never did have high hopes for it, hell, I didn't even want to watch it. So my tale of sorrow begins with me flipping through channels and some unknown force compelling me to watch this eyesore. I just kept thinking in my head, "it can't be that bad." I was VERY wrong. The plot (if there is one) of this movie is about college students (who are all unlikeable) who fall victim to a flesh eating virus and dogs from resident evil. The college students all die and then this ridiculously RETARDED ending shows up. It starts with two small children getting water from an obviously dirty and polluted stream. Why, you ask? To make lemonade of course! As if purified water is a thing of the past! That's still not worst part. These three black kids (who have on baggy clothes of course) show up at this white guy's shop (remeber that this movie is about a flesh eating virus) and begin to go in. The white guy runs into his shop and grabs a rifle and begins cleaning it, and then hands it to them...hmm Once this had been done, he then started pounding up with the black guys and they all start laughing AND THEN THE MOVIE ENDS?!!! WTF. What did that have to do with anything in the movie? Honestly, save yourself from the torture and evade this movie at all costs.

Review title: Its So Bad It's Not Even a B-Horror Movie
Review_body: I am a fan of scary/horror movies, some of which fall into the b-horror movie category and some that do not, and I even like a good comedic horror flick like an Evil Dead 2 or anything that falls into Peter Jackson's early zombie movie career, and so I can therefore appreciate films like that. With that being said Cabin Fever is the worst movie that falls into any of those categories that I've ever seen (not that I know what category it was even hoping it'd fall into because yes whether it was meant to be comedic or whatever I have no idea). I was just too amazed at how dumb it all was. The teens in this movie are of course stereotypical of what you would find in a b-horror movie (though in my opinion worse than that actually I mean you expect a bit of stereotypical nature when you see these movies, but when you start hoping everyone will soon just die off you know something must be wrong here).All in all save your time and your money from this movie. Your brain just may thank you later.

I went into this movie thinking that it would be a good story. And it could have been, really! But in actuality, this was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. It was boring, the amount of swearing was ridiculous, and I really didn't need to see the implication of a girl sticking her finger up her boyfriend's butt! Just a horrible, stupid, terrible movie!!!!

Review title: Boy on porch = funny; Movie = not good.
Review_body: This movie is really not too good.  The acting is fairly solid, but the story is extremely weak and boring.  If you want to see a good movie about a flesh-eating virus, please, watch 28 days later, and avoid this one.The kid on the porch made me laugh, and having a girly to cuddle made the whole thing entirely bearable, but had I been alone, I might have made this the second movie I've ever walked out of.

Review title: The worst film I have ever seen
Review_body: Well what can I say. After using this site for many years to check out whether a film was worth watching or to challenge my views on it I sat down to watch Cabin Fever.90 minutes later and I think I would rather stick pins in my eyes than watch this again. Yes I did expect it to be bad from reading the reviews but not THAT bad.This film is so bad that it has inspired me to register with IMDb so that I can post my first ever score and comment. If I stop just one person from watching the film, then my life has not been in vain...Oh yeh, about the movie: The characters were so unlikeable that I was glad when they all died. There was no tension, no build up, nothing except ludicrous (why are they doing that) situations. What was the deal with the dog eating people, why didn't he die? Why do I even care.And the ending, well that just about put the cherry on top.

I am a huge horror movie fan. I go to 24-hr film festivals, conventions, you name it. However, I just cannot stand this movie. I first saw it when it was released in theaters and HATED it, avoiding it and its sequels like the plague depicted therein. Tonight, 13 years after its release, I decided to give it another go.And I still just DO NOT get the appeal. Unlikable characters who garner no sympathy from me, intentionally weird supporting characters who seem to serve no real purpose other than to be inexplicably weird, and a plodding pointless story that has no real mystery to be explained or suspense as to what might happen. It reminds me of something a student might put together in an attempt to make a sloppy, unappealing homage to true pioneers of the strange in film like Lynch, Cronenberg, or even Tarantino. The difference is that those three (and others I'm not going to take the time to list) had a POINT to the oddities and strange, obnoxious weirdos they wrote and put out there for consumption. This film, like many of Zombie's films, feels like a cheap ripoff of much greater freak-shows on film.

cabin fever is an excellent movie for anyone who truly appreciates horror movies made in the 70s and 80s. if you want a special effects tragedy, go watch something made by bruckheimer.the movie is quite artistic, has a great and new storyline, and has redeeming value for it's humor. when you watch cabin fever you almost want to yell to the characters don't do that, don't do this... just like the early 70s slasher movies (think halloween, Friday the 13th, Texas chainsaw massacre). in fact, it pays homage to a number of the early classics horror roots. the music is wonderfully composed by one of the industry's greatest composers angelo badalamenti (twin peaks, lost highway, muhulland drive) and the sound effects as well as visuals are impressive given the budget.if you want to see an interesting, humorous and funny tribute to old style horror flicks, cabin fever is a winner

Review title: I tried to get my money back
Review_body: Sure I've seen bad movies in my life, but this one was so bad that I actually became angry in the theater. I wanted my money back. I wrote to the director asking him to refund my movie ticket, of course I didn't receive a refund (or even a reply) but it's the point that matters. On a scale of 1-10 I give this movie a -42. Why did the "Jeep" (Chevy Blazer??) stop running from being hit with a bat? Why did they hit the "Jeep"(Chevy Blazer?????) with the bat in the first place instead of cracking the bum's skull? The plot was thin, the movie filled with obvious clichés, and certain parts of it just didn't make any sense.

This movie is O.K. by me, it's silly, it's got some dumb moments, but it definitely has it's moments. The shaving scenes (inspired by real life events in Roths life) were pretty gruesome and cool effects. The script could use a lot of work, mostly the fact that even though they wouldn't' be drunk, they would feel really awful after only drinking beer, the simply dehydration factor alone would make you somewhat ill. I thought it was kind of cool that water was the enemy because they didn't know it. I understand the ending which seems to be a major point of confusion, but the part i don't understand is the necessity of the evil little kid at the store, maybe i just missed the story of that. All an all it was a descent movie probably won't own it, but i'd definitely watch it again.

Review title: Bad acting, bad music, bad direction -- amateur thru and thru
Review_body: This movie offers you nothing.  Horrible acting, cliched, bad music, bad direction, worse writing.  It is, bar none, the most amateur film I have ever seen in a mainstream movie theater.  Ignore the hype, ignore the idiots at the Toronto Film Festival who accepted the film, and ignore this film. It is a badly done as they come, and will make you long for a Roger Corman resurgence.

As far as I'm concerned, watching a Horror film is one thing. Rewatching is another. The Horror's I enjoy rewatching are normally blood-soaked rhapsodies full of black humour and snide references to everything under the sun. This is one of those films and I will gladly rewatch this film any day.Beginning with a simple enough premise of 'woodsman gets infected with virus, begins to infect a cabinful of good-looking teenagers partying in the woods,' this film spirals out of the normal cliches and conventions: making an original movie whilst still giving a wink and a nudge to Friday the 13th, Texas Chainsaw Massacre, Evil Dead et. al. Within thirty minutes of the beautiful title sequence, people are shaving skin off themselves, firing BB gun pellets at squirrels, drinking beer all holiday, quarantening each other in shacks, and killing a disease-ridden hobo. I mention such specific things because this is a film that does not 'broaden' things over with large Spielbergian brushstrokes: every character has a life of their own and you will walk away discussing the old Shirley Temple bottles in the bottlestore or a rung of a ladder breaking instead of the artful references to your favourite movies.A good Horror should have original kills. Check. A good Horror should make people laugh whilst making them jump out of their seats. Check. A good Horror shouldn't give away its punchlines or sporadic murders early. Check. A good Horror should always feature a badly written review from a gobsmacked 17 year old who can't figure out how to describe the fun he just had watching this movie and meeting the director afterwards at the Wellington International Film Festival. Check.Go see this on September 12. You won't regret it... that is, provided you have nothing in your stomach. 9/10.

Review title: Oh, m'God, was this an awful movie. Don't wast your money!
Review_body: I'd give this a negative rating if I could. I went into this movie not expecting much, but I had an open mind. The whole thing is stupid! The gore was obviously fake and the first two kids that died looked like they poured ketchup on themselves. Oh how original; if I were a 12 year old boy I might laugh at that. I have no idea how this movie became so popular. Seriously,the worst thing I've ever seen. I wasn't entertained, it wasn't funny,I wasn't even bored! I wasn't anything. It wasn't even so bad it was good, it's just bad. Ridiculous actually. Please do not waste your money on this movie. Don't even rent this movie. No clue how it's getting such a high rating.

Spoilers contained within.I'm aghast at the comments here, I adore this movie.  I think there were a bunch of folks who went in with expectations that went unfulfilled. Perhaps viewers don't like their expectations being messed with -- I certainly do. A film that looks shallow at first glance but has good depth is always welcome.  I can't believe that other viewers didn't see the thought that went into this well-made film that I did.It being way to early to tell, I won't gush over Eli Roth's genius or anything, but he is a student of horror.  His script is a horror script and not intended to be particulary scholarly or thought-provoking.  It's uncomplicated and serves to move the plot along, it's not the focal point. It also guides the viewer into perceiving who the characters are and establishes the necessary fatal character flaws that get everyone killed. The plot, as well, is horror-uncomplicated: after the setup, everybody run from the menace, we're all going to die.It's Roth's juxtaposition of menaces that makes this movie fabulous.  The virus is scary enough, but what about the rampaging hillbillies or incompetent police?  How about a drifter's mad dog growling at the perimeter as they fix the broken truck?  Tainted water passed around by characters, blissfully unaware?  Even an over-the-top horror tribute to the original Texas Chainsaw Massacre which turns out to be nothing but a fireside ghost story.  It is in the combination of threats and the innocent characters' confusion that the real horror begins to shine through, and the audiences fear starts growing.Then there's the gore -- truly horrifying gore in shocking clarity. Scenes are often established with enough preamble to encourage the viewer to anticipate the blood; when it comes, it roars past your expectations and sends you into tense discomfort.  Best makeup effects of 2003, truly awful to behold. [An aside: one viewer I recommended it to vomited after the shower scene. Granted, he was a bit hung over, but it serves as example: this film is not for the weak of stomach.]The love interest between the main character and his longtime friend at first glance seems banal, overdone.  But the cinematic shots that set it up and the nearly-consummated romance undone by blood help increase the romance's potency.  The stupendous review montage at the end of the film sends the beautiful blonde offscreen in horror glory.  Without the jaded impression the viewer gets of the initial romance, the shock at the end has nowhere near the force.In what I see as a tribute to Blair Witch Project, the characters all begin to turn on one another, which helps prompt audience anxiety.  There are several particularly effective scenes as their friendship decays into survival instinct.  As the turmoil increases and the frienship decays, there are several cathartic moments where individuals realize the shaky base of their relationship in the first place.And, of course, there's "PANCAKES....  PANCAKES".  Good old Dennis, I laughed and laughed.  Truly great horror films are interspersed with grim humor.  Cabin Fever is exceptionally funny in parts.  Without this, the ride never lets up for the viewer and a constantly, ever-increasing fear factor becomes numbing.  This film makes sure to pull the viewer up for "air" with laughter, before plunging you back into the bucket of gore for more fear.At some length, let me sum up by saying this is worth a look if you like horror.  Do not be swayed by the nearly universal antipathy here, many of these bad reviews may stem from offended sensibilities.  Oh, and there's a coda at the end of the credits.

I was lucky enough to see Cabin Fever at a screening in Sydney where there was a Q&A session with director Eli Roth after the viewing.The film itself seemed to have many homages to the classic horror movies of the 70s/80s, which was reassuring. This director knows his film history, and knows how to share that knowledge without ever going overboard.Cabin Fever is relentlessly gory. And considering 'the killer' in this case is a flesh eating virus, it makes the film all the more entertaining and keeps your hands hovering over your eyes- with the occasional peek.There is just enough humor without going overboard- mainly coming from "the jock", who likes to shoot squirrels, because 'they're gay'.As for the discussion after the film, Eli came across as a down-to-earth person who knows his stuff. He has a passion for classic horror. His feet are firmly planted on the ground. My call is that Eli Roth is going to become a household name.

Review title: Finally, a horror movie that delivers
Review_body:
So often you come across horror movies promising blood, guts, suspense, trills, etc. and so often they fail. As a teen who has been watching horror movies since before I can remember, I've seen A LOT of crap.  "Cabin Fever" is a horror film that contains all the necessary elements of a good horror movie.  It's not just another ordinary slasher, nor is it a zombie flick.
The acting isn't great, but the creepy atmosphere and the gore should be enough to make up for it.  Besides, who watches a horror movie for the acting?Overall, a good rent if you want a horror movie above the rest.

When I think of 70's horror, I think The Exorcist, Texas Chainsaw..., Last House on the Left, Halloween.  Eli Roth has been quoted as saying he was upset that films like Wrong Turn were improperly sold as tributes to 70's exploitation horror.  Well, he can now be upset that his own film Cabin Fever inexplicably falls into the same category as Wrong Turn...false advertising.  This is the same disposable horror garbage as just about every other "new" horror film to come out lately (sans 28 Days Later).  I'm amazed it was hyped like this.  Cabin Fever isn't even a horror movie.  It's a comedy ala Meatballs with some blood thrown in to make it more marketable. If I knew I was going in to watch some more stupid characters that I don't care about get more stupid as the "plot" rolls along, maybe I wouldn't be so hard on this movie.  But with the way this baby has been talked-up, along with Roth's off-the-mark comments everywhere I look, I can't stomach it. And, unfortunately, that's got nothing to do with the "gore", which is pretty tame for a film that is supposed to follow in the footsteps of Evil Dead.Whatever.  I know.  I should put up or shut up.  But when you wait over a year and a half to see a "real" horror movie and all you get is Cabin Fever, you're allowed to be a little more than just disappointed.  Had Roth taken his idea (which was a good one) seriously and not tried to ham it up so much with inane bits, it could have been a success.  But instead, I felt like I was watching the Kevin Smith of Horror Shows.  A few worthy moments ruined by shallow, witless banter and inconsistent tone.

This movie had a great concept in trying to go back to the cult favorite Evil Dead, but came up unbelievably short in the overall quality.  The best part was the irony of the ending.  I love horror movies, even the bad ones, and this one just didn't do it for me.

One of the worst films ever made. I never stopped laughing through this entire film. It was so cliché that it was laughable. The dialogue consisted of simply curse words and the characters were immature dirt bags that I wanted to see get sick. They constantly over reacted and were prone to violence that made no sense. They fit every cliché in the book all they did was curse drink and have sex. It was terrible and I am a big fan of horror movies. This movie was a terrible b film that the studios decided to pick up and market and sucker us into seeing it. The studio knew it was terrible but was able to sucker some of us into the theaters and made some nice money on it. Do not give them the satisfaction save your money and go rent a nightmare on elm street flick. This movie is simply deplorable. Also every horror movie now portrays people from the south as crazy old hicks who carry shotguns and hate outsiders. I would think this stereotyping is really getting to the people of the south. Once again that is a cliché and what this movie is based on. What a miserable film. You will lose brain cells watching this movie.

And the best of both worlds. For any horror fan, this movie rocks the house, or should I say cabin. Eli Roth's direction is right on the button. He knows what makes horror films good; sex, violence, and unknown actors. This is the anti-Urban Legends, or any of those other knock offs of Scream. Eli Roth yanks the horror genre out of PG-13 pop territory and plants it firmly back in Cult-land.The actors are all capable. The gore is delicious. The audience will laugh hysterically one moment, cringe the next, and scream to end it all. The music is perfect and ominous. The location is eerie. The writing is snappy.This movie is certainly going to gain cult status when it hits dvd. A must see/must own for any Horror fan.

You can't get much more satisfied than this walking out of a horror movie. It truly amazing stuff that has your heart racing as the film delivers one shock after another. This movie needed to be made to satisfy all those desperate to see plenty of gore and originality in a horror film. 10/10

Review title: Horror as it always should have been
Review_body: God created Eli Roth, and he saw that it was good.Im not going to say too much about Cabin Fever, other than watch it watch it now.Its the film I have been begging for, for the last 10 years. If you love Horror, you'll love Cabin Fever. If you respect early Raimi, Craven, Fulchi, Carpenter, Hooper, Argento, Jackson,  then this movie is for you.Thank you Eli Roth for bringing Horror back to the fans.If there is one horror film you watch this year, make it Cabin Fever.

Review title: The most awesome horror movie of the year!
Review_body: This was shown at the Frightfest festival in London on Sunday 24th August, and simply blew me away!This is a rare example of a horror movie that DOES NOT disappoint!  After all the hype I was reading on the Net about this, I was hoping that I wasn't going to be disappointed, and I wasn't at all.  It was even better than I'd dared to hope.Yes, it's a homage to THE EVIL DEAD and many other movies from the 70's and 80's, but WHO CARES!!  That's not the point - what true horror fans like myself want is a movie that'll shock, thrill and delight an audience of like-minded people.And this movie does that.  This is easily the best movie I've seen in the genre this year, and deserves to be a success so that the director, Eli Roth, can continue to make other horror films that are as good as this one.Miss this at your peril - a real cinematic thrill ride!!!(10 out of 10)

This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen!  It almost seemed like a knockoff of Texas Chainsaw Massacre.  A bunch of teens are driving to a house (log cabin in this circumstance), are having a good time.  Then they get stranded, and everywhere they turn for help they find nut cases.
Worst movie ever!  Don't buy or rent it.

This was quite a shallow movie, barely delving into the question of what people would do when faced with the fear of a horrendous death. Without the addition of the redneck store owners (and Denis who was possibly the funniest character) this movie would have been entirely predictable. Wait it still was entirely predictable. The acting was fairly good for this level of horror movie, the makeup was detailed and the splatter patterns were ever-increasingly excessive however this movie failed in both possible aims of a horror movie. It did not scare its audience, nor did it make the audience laugh at the unrealistic splatter and throw popcorn at the screen.

OK. First of all, I want to explain how I came to this movie. I had watched "Darkened Room" from David Lynch with Jordan Ladd and Cerina Vincent. I had seen, that both of them are staring in "Cabin Fever", which has a good poster. And I'd read some critiques, which were good about the Movie.So, I watched. This Movie is horrible. Very bad directing from "Eli Roth". I hadn't known about him, and i don't wanna watch other Movies of film. Picture was good. Director of Photography has done better job than all others, who worked for this movie. There is also no acting, they cannot act. Full of people who cannot act. This Movie is horrible. DON'T WASTE YOUR MONEY & TIME!!! Regards

Review title: Point made, and well done at that
Review_body: Cabin Fever has been given some pretty poor reviews by a lot of people who are watching it to be scared, sickened, and shocked. I sat down to watch it very skeptically, not a fan of horror movies, or the grotesque in general. But Cabin Fever proved itself to be more then meets the eye.First, let's get the essential stuff out of the way. The characters were well done, even though some may not take to them. Anyone who's been through college in the past 5-10 years can tell you the depictions are (unfortunately) quite accurate. The cinematography was great, and gave the movie an appropriate feel.Now on to the important stuff. The movie, marketed and filmed as a horror film, is really about the human condition. Of course, the premise is simple. Kids in the woods. Car broken down. Strange Disease. But what's really brilliant is how Writer/Director Eli Roth turns this setup for a white-bread film disaster into an excellent movie.The themes are obvious to anyone who's watching it for more then blood and boobs. Canadian-made, I began to think that Roth was trying to tell Americans something. Perhaps it's because I agree with him that I catch them so easy, but the point is well made, and the message is well needed today. I'd rather not give away the vehicles Roth employs, and leave it to the viewer to see for himself. Of course, the point-to-grotesque ratio wasn't quite in balance, but I suppose, had it been done tastefully, it would have defeated Roth's entire point.In short, this was a great movie, with a lot of thrills, but to be fair, I'm giving Roth the benefit of the doubt on his characters and plot. To really appreciate this as more than a horror film, be looking for more then a thriller when you see it. Hopefully, you'll be more than pleased.

Review title: Not as good as I expected
Review_body: Cabin Fever by nouveau writer/director Eli Roth is the story of five college kids (three male, two female) who, after finishing their final exams, go off into the woods to a cabin where they'll spend a nice holiday of drinking, sex, and the usual stuff college kids do. Instead of finding the perfect way to top off the end of school, one of them finds a hermit man in the woods with some kind of serious disease. Let me let you in on a little secret: it's NOT SARS! You can guess where it goes from here. This film started off fairly promising, but in the end the lack of real character development really hurt what was potentially an interesting idea. You don't really care for characters who are all clichés of what we've seen in too many other teen horror flicks. There was a good opportunity with the lead male and his love interest for the writers to develop that relationship so we could understand it more and thus feel sympathy for both of them. But, it never happened. As for the rest of the characters, what little we get to know about them only reveals they are pretty shallow and one-dimensional. Thus, making them pretty cliché-like.It's very similar to other far better films such as: "The Thing" (1982), "28 days later" (2002), and "The Evil Dead" (1981). What made these films work was dark humor, which this film has shades of, character development, and effective creepiness and scares, which "The Evil Dead" has in spades compared to this one. "The Evil Dead" is given homage to in the end credits here. Out of these three "Cabin Fever" is most similar to "28 days later." What that film has that really makes it stand out from this one is two dimensional and realistic characters who are actually smart (a rarity in horror films). Instead of creating two-dimensional characters the director here would rather gives these characters every opportunity to have sex. This film does have a dark humor type ending that works okay. And it manages to be kind of creepy in some places. But, as I said before, you don't really care that much about the characters so it doesn't matter who dies and how they die. It did have the potential to have some pretty interesting psychological warfare going on with the characters alienating potentially "sick" friends and thus echoing how paranoid and cruel mankind can be towards one another. But, it didn't manage to pull that off as well as other films have in the past, namely "The Thing." Some places in the film did manage to be pretty humorous and so it succeeded at times in that respect. Overall, the film is mildly entertaining and it's a decent first film for Eli Roth. I just hope that his new film, which is produced by Tarrantino, is better. The "fake shemp" used in the end credits is an obvious reference to Sam Raimi. This film even though it tries comes nowhere close to achieving what Raimi did with "The Evil Dead." He pulled that off for a measly $150,000. And so, referencing Mr. Raimi seems like a cheap way to put yourself in the same category as he is. The bottom line is: this is a decent horror film that is worth seeing, but don't let your expectations run too high. James Sutherland.

Beautiful people go out to a cabin in the woods and get a dreadful skin disease.Hmmm, this film is a poor pastiche of a number of others. If you want to watch genuine horror about a cabin in the woods watch Evil Dead. If you want to watch a more light hearted horror about a cabin in the woods, watch Evil Dead 2. If you want to watch a film about a mad dog.. watch Kujo (don't bother though, it's almost as bad as this). If you want to watch a film about wasting bleeding diseases, how about Outbreak.. (poor, but better than this). I could go on, but can't be bothered....This film seems to jump from one loosely connected scene to another, with very little explanation of what's going on or why. I would have give this film a much lower score ( I gave it 3) apart from the fact it did stick to all the worst bits in horrors.. cabin in the woods, dumb hicks, sexy stars... etc and that must be worth something. I did like the scene with the underage booze party near the end, but there where no surprises from beginning to end, each scene and gag was signalled way in advance. The only thing it had me wondering was "What's in the box?"In all, a waste of time and I'm glad i didn't pay to watch it (saw it on SkyMovies the other night)...

Review title: great horror genre piece...homage to the great 70's classics!
Review_body: i really do not understand what people are talking about in the other reviews. i feel like this is a continuing pattern on here. don't intelligent people watch movies or is it because this is a horror film and the viewers are incompetent? anyone who loves good horror should appreciate this! i wont go ahead and mention the storyline except for that it comes off as just another cheese ball teens in the woods getting slaughtered, at least thats what i thought when it came out and thats exactly the reason i originally avoided it. after a couple of years decided to give it a shot and was very pleased. every ingredient for a well made horror is here and more. if you want to look at this "cabin fever" as a social issue, its also possible. human nature is examined at its best here. yes, it has its flaws, this is a "horror movie and not an academy award winner dramatic and audiences should start viewing movies based on what the purpose is. every movie has a flavor and you wouldn't go compare coffee with wine would you, even though both are beverages!!! also, this film is much better than most in the genre including i madman, Axe, and even Tobe Hooper's eaten alive. most reviewers are not avid film goers and think they know all, such as those bush supporter who think they understand history! if they do understand like they say, they should feel guilty...another thing, reviewers have to stop comparing movies that are classics by anyones standards, TODAY...that is, if it wasn't for people like me and others who enjoy these, Texas chainsaw massacre, night of the living dead, the old Vincent price, Boris Karloff's, Christopher lee, and corman productions would not be liked mainstream...again, this is and will be CLASSIC...known for the best attempt for bringing back 70's horror. Mainstream people always want to butt in on things they don't understand, such as good horror...and to end this for all those Rex reed's out there, film theory is my thing and movies are a passion, don't stick your ignorant nose where it doesn't belong! RENT THIS MOVIE...especially if you enjoyed old Wes craven, Tobe hooper, George Romero and many others...this is a great modern approach to the genre.

Review title: This film made me cry... not in a good intentional way
Review_body: I saw this film without any hype surrounding it so my expectations were neutral... watching the film I felt a mixture of emotion; sadness, anger and frustration. Sandness - I could not get a refund on this movie, anger - realising I could not get a refund on this movie and frustration - not being able to do anything to get the 90 minutes of my life back.This film is so horribly dull and full of clichés and cheap shot jokes that it made me feel ill to sit through it. I saw this film with Hous of a 1000 corpses (saw this first) and I wanted to stab the person who said this was a fun/funny/gory/action/anything (delete where applicable). In fact, the person who recommended this freaking bore-fest to me is no longer a close friend or friend at all. This film made me want to hit people. Wow it had a gay joke - that completely describes all of the youth of today (none at all are mature no...) and the pancakes joke...wow...just wow... worst script ever, worst director and worst film.I wish I was exagerrating. This film was a complete chore to sit through. There's no gore, nothing to make me wince, cringe or feel uncomfortable - AT ALL.The only thing that made me cringe about this film would be having to admit one day to people that I watched this film.This film has the worst humour, horror, cast and effects as well as some unforgiving continuity and in general the BIGGEST letdown in a film I've seen in years. There's nothing good about this and if I could give this less than a 1 I would. So much less.

Review title: The Worst Horror Movie I've seen in theaters
Review_body: After reading pretty good reviews from IGN.com and a Philadelphia newspaper article, I took a date to Cabin Fever and what a horrible mistake. The movie is complete garbage, and I'm not sure if it was meant to be a spoof on horror flicks or a comedy. "What???" must have slipped out of my mouth over a dozen times in the film. There's this one scene where a crazy little kid bites one of the characters and starts to do kung-fu kicks and crap. All of this is followed up by a quote about "pancakes." 'Sean' from Boy Meets World was in the film, and that was kind of funny (plus the one actress was pretty hot) but this film really sucked. It wasn't scary, it wasn't creepy, and it wasn't really that funny either. Stay as far away as possible from CABIN FEVER...what a horrible movie.
Hey this movie is not super bad. But still... It doesn't work that much. But still isn't super good.

Review title: THE WAY HORROR SHOULD BE DONE. (Finally, a tribute to old-school horror!)
Review_body: Put simply, it's about FREAKIN' TIME.I had just about given up on the horror genre -- too many years of "Jason XXVIII" and too many teen soundtrack vehicles had come and gone for me to pay attention. I can list on one hand the horror films that ACTUALLY scared me: The ORIGINAL Friday the 13th, the ORIGINAL Halloween, the ORIGINAL Texas Chainsaw Massacre, etc. -- see a pattern here?Hollywood had forgotten a simple lesson: LESS IS MORE. You DON'T need a $45 million budget, half an hour of CGI, and a soundtrack featuring MTV's Buzz Bin / TRL to make a decent horror film. Whatever happened to woods? Whatever happened to country folk and stillwater ponds? A big THANK YOU goes out to Mr. Eli Roth for giving today's X-Box brats a healthy dose of what they'd been missing for years: old-school horror. Do yourself a favor and see this gem when it hits the screen -- you won't be disappointed.Later, freebie_grabber

Review title: Cheap but effective. Everything that makes a cult classic.
Review_body: From the very start, 'Cabin Fever' promises to be a formulaic horror film for moviegoers that like to be surprised, but not too surprised. No attempt was made to identify the main characters, five young adults celebrating the close of their college career. All of the characters are exactly what they appear to be, with very few exceptions. The title spells out the premise pretty well. These five young adults rent a cabin and run into a diseased man from the woods. The double entendre serves the film well, as the plot is the film's greatest asset. It deals with Xenophobia on many levels. The unique angle is that the real scare revolves around what it would be like to be the subject of xenophobia, especially if the people who were afraid of you were people you needed if you were going to survive. The illness serves up plenty of gore. The actors believably communicate the fear of being fatally ill. Less believable, but still effective, is their portayal of people who want to avoid getting ill at any cost. All I will say is this: Cabin Fever, catch it!

this film i saw in theatres, without knowing what i was getting myself into. throughout the movie more than half of the people walked out at random intervals and never returned, others who stuck it out, walked out shaking their head with a friendly smile towards the ones around them who seem to wonder collectively, 'where you there with me right then or was that all some ambrose bierce inspired wet dream of teen horror?' so of course i have found memories of this movie. the director is an obvious horror movie buff and it comes out in the intense black humor of the film. as illustrated in spinal tap, more likely in the quote itself, "there's a fine line between stupid and ... clever." this film is too good to do it justice in this review, or any review for that matter. i like films that are so out there, you refuse to think of ways you'd like to direct or write them yourself. this is one of those films, you must simply enjoy the ride.

Review title: Evil Dead : Tarantino and David Lynch style
Review_body: Evil Dead : Tarantino and David Lynch style. This movie has to be viewed as a comedy or else you will not enjoy it. It will become a classic just like Evil Dead, Pulp Fiction and Twin Peaks.....At the theather everybody were cracked up, especially with weird characters like Denis and the policeman...

Review title: Watch only if you have time to burn....
Review_body: Quite a pointless movie... the first 20 minutes of so did promise a lot, but as the saying goes - it came in with a bang and went out with a whimper. This flick makes a weak attempt at being a psychotic thriller... in the end, what you have is a bunch of horny young adults who end  up meeting their ultimate fate. If that wasn't bad enough, the ending is even worse with a bunch of hillbillies prancing away to bluegrass - - - what in the world were they thinking when they put this movie together!?!?!?!?!?!

Just saw this film at MIFF, and I've got to say I'm disappointed.  Sure we laughed, we jumped, but we left unimpressed.Eli Roth has done a very good job of putting together a great college death trip, but it is far from horror.  There is some gruesomeness, one or two shock scenes (but I'll get to that), but very little in the way of horror... I mean what is so scary about watching some dumb US college kids klutz around as they wait to die of a flesh eating virus.The humour was very hit & miss, some of the subtle ironies (ie the main character unwittingly giving his lover virally infected water) were fantastic, but most of it seemed over played for gratuitous yuks.But the whole thing smacked of Eli Roth's ego, and a sense that he was trying to prove that he is cleverer than the audience.  There are two moments that triggered this thought, for me:1. The whole town turning from 'inbreds' to jovial country folk is a bit off key.  OK, the whole thing is a joke, and played purely for laughs, and without any horror apart from, again, the subtle irony of simple folk quaffing deadly lemonade.  I can't help but feel this was thrown in so Eli could go "betcha didn't see that coming".2. The one jump-out-of-the-seat moment in the film is the introduction of Eli Roth's cameo.  You are expecting to see the infected hobo, but no, we have Eli turning up with a bag of dope.  Yup the scene was mildly funny, but completely out of touch with the rest of the film.  In fact, completely unnecessary in the whole film.  Why not have a drunken grizzly bear, or a swarm of squirrels seeking revenge.  It seems that Eli did this to make his own appearance more memorable in the whole film.I wanted to like this film, and there were moments that I was laughing with the crowd, but too many moments where I laughed at the film and without the crowd.  And it wasn't the gore that put me off, I saw this a day after seeing "May" another, and far better, Lions Gate release.

After the huge hype this film has received, I was really looking forward to it. Sadly, it fell far short of expectations. It's an extremely average horror movie. The performances are adequate, but it's very slow-moving and the few scary moments just, well, aren't scary. Congrats to Eli Roth for managing to parlay this into a mega-release distribution deal -- still, for low-budget brilliance, I'll take Bubba Ho-Tep over this any day.

Obvioulsy this is a B movie that some how by the grace of god made it to the movies.  It's a great B movie, but the acting was excruciating.  The whole begining of the movie was horrendus, there must of been 4 or 5 different songs crammed into the first 5 minutes of the movie.  And the "grim" guy was absolutley pointless, he came out of no where.  The cast was just wrong I think, it seemed like they were just reading lines, espeically the 2 girls and the dumb friend with the rifle.  But  I have to say it's not bad for a first time writer/director.  I would like to see what else he can do.

The following comments are what you will find yourself saying out loud throughout the whole movie, "Yeah right", "What the hell?", "Oh come on." and "Yeah like that could ever happen." Im not lying. It was that lousy. A group of college students go camping in a cabin to celebrate the end of final exams. Then they meet some sick hobo who infects them all with a flesh eating virus. Don't get confused, it may sound like a good movie but it isn't. The director tried to hard to make it scary but just adding a lot of blood and a few gory scenes. They tried to hard. Simple as that. Alfred Hitchcock could scare the crap out of you without showing you hardly anything!

When I first watched Cabin Fever I was totally in to that sort of movie.. But when i started to watch it it started to give me a weird feeling, like this is pretty scary yet strangely funny.. Surprisingly the acting was pretty good save for the overabundance of F this F that F you's and so on.. I sort of like how it was made with that psychotic sort of sense of mind, maybe it was the extremely Dark Humor. Personally i loved the very end when the dude who went into hiding returns only to find all his friends dead. He then gives himself a wave of gratitude before walking out the back door and getting shot up by the Homicidal police force..Another personal favorite is the hippie cop... Overall however the movie is crap. It was cheaply made, which is very obvious right from the beginning, and the language is enough to shut it off alone. A complete give away of the lack of funding is the scene with the dear, I don't think I have laughed so hard in such a long time. Watch it once and forget about it.

Wow, I'm really shocked by all the positive posts.  I'm a big horror movie fan and I don't want to be mean since this seemed like an earnest attempt, but this is a dull, dull, dull movie.  The technical aspects are fine; the acting is decent and the photography is very good.  However, all the gore in the world can't make an interesting and engaging film.  I don't need likable characters, just semi-believable ones.  And I'm even fine with a movie disregarding plot for the sake of cool visuals and ambiance, but this just rambles.  Go see 28 DAYS LATER and see the right way to borrow from horror classics.  CABIN FEVER just stews bits and pieces from movies like EVIL DEAD together into a mess.

Review title: wow....all I can say, is wow...
Review_body: What a piece of crap...can't say I was disapointed, cuz I thought it'd be a piece of crap, with all the incessant buildup surrounding it...but by the time the credits start rolling, I literally had my mouth agape at just how hideous this film was.Eli Roth must be the most delusional director to come by in a long time...for all the hype surrounding this movie that he gladly fed with his non-stop yapping in interviews and on the dvd, this movie is a disgrace.  ..an absolutely nails-against-the-blackboard bore, with not one scary moment to be found...for all the hoohaw about the return to gore and sex, the gore is tame and it's impact is lost by the constant score-blasts and cut- scenes that are supposed to pass for scares.  Awful performances, no suspense (at the 40 minute point, I'm STILL waiting for something, ANYthing scary to happen...), and a script that's bad beyond belief...there's a review I read that refers to the 'rifle joke' at the general store, and how the first part of the joke might have been funny, if not curious, on it's on...but to bring closure, and 'explain' the joke the way he does...and as THE LAST SCENE...??  It almost made me wish I had seen it in a theater, so I could have boo'd even louder then I had originally intended on booing it, BEFORE that final scene!!Yeah, it's a first film, but it's pretty clear: Eli Roth is a hack.  He may talk a good game in interviews and he's a protege to a genius, David Lynch, but he's a hack all the same. What's worse, is that with all the clamor to praise this piece of garbage, he seems to believe his own hype.  Like that other horror-film hack WS Anderson, Roth is utterly clueless in how to establish and manipulate tone, let alone go back and forth between horror and dark comedy.  For that, go back and watch Evil Dead or Dead-Alive...Cabin Fever is dismally boring, gutless, and most unforgiveable, excrutiatingly full of itself.

I like horror movies and when I heard about this movie first I was very excited. A film without an original killer but with a flash-eater virus!? Jeeez, that's sounds crazy! The idea is quite original and might be the base of an extremely powerful movie. But in the real life, it all goes wrong...... for the first, the plot is just stupid. The first murder in the story (the homeless guy's burning) doesn't even make any sense. Why do they kill that? But the most ridiculous part is still the end. The villagers are starting a manhunt against the ill ones, and kill them with no reason. Why don't they just call help? Like the ambulance or something? Senseless, again. And if we are here, then I must reply on the characters too. They are so unsympathetic that I've never seen before. There was no one who I could like or sorry in the whole movie! Why is it like that? The creators wanted to show us the today's youth's sins, or what? And why are so much nudity scenes? Oh God... this is just bad.I mentioned the ending before, but the real last scene was just ruins more. They wanted to ride the X-files "open ended" style but it just doesn't work as well. It only makes the movie more worse...I don't even know why I gave 2 points... Perhaps because the camera handing is not so bad...Chocho

Review title: A flick about human stupidity and urban fear of the contry folk
Review_body: Today I took in a double feature of first run films. Jeepers Creepers 2 and Cabin fever. I chose to watch JC2 because I was "saving the best for last". I had heard a TON of good things about the film Cabin Fever and was actually looking forward to seeing it. I often agree with the reviews in the NY Times (though not always) and there were several other reviews comparing it to that of Evil Dead 2, etc... In the end I found myself curious as to what movie they were watching.*** The following is to discuss plot elements within the movie and does contain spoilers ***I like a good horror flick. No, wait.. I LOVE a good horror flick. But the probability of finding a good one is growing more and more dismal. What writers/directors/producers seem to forget is the fact that it's not the blood and gore, though fun and cool in and of itself, which scares people. It's the ability to relate to the main characters then feel for them as they face the horrors presented in the course of the films. To this end I believe Eli Roth started off quite well. I went to college. While there I went on various road outings with my friends. Camping, Spring Break, Mardi Gras, etc... Yes at this point I can relate. I imagine most other people can to since I am not the single target audience on the United States of America. Where things began to go wrong for me was when the entire group was approached by the first infected man. Not a one of them had a rational thought. Now of course in the heat of the moment they all could have had a group panic that resulted the way it did. Fine. But then the movie proceeds with each main character making a series of idiotic decisions which can only be explained away as methods to keep the plot moving.For example, if my friends were in danger I would not hesitate to walk 5 miles, 10 miles, even 100 miles at night down a country road to find any sort of help what so ever. But the actors in this film walk to a house in broad daylight, find it empty and decide to go back to the cabin to drink beer. Also upon finding that their friend is infected with a serious disease decide to stick her in a shed then wait till morning to seek help. Hello, start walking someone! So yes there was the plot element of the mad dog that might have been placed there to keep them in the house or something. Give me a break. Also if they are so afraid to catch what the blond chick had why didn't they quarantine her in the room she had already bled in so much? Why move her to a shed? It's not like they are going to sleep in that bed. It wasn't gallows humor, it was just dumb. Also after being in the shed for more than a day instead of hitting the pavement during daytime and walking to the nearest town to find help, the love interest of the blond and some other chick decide to have sex. These events and the events similar lead me to one conclusion. Eli Roth made a film portraying humans in general as being selfish.Should I disagree? Should I impose upon Roth's vision of general natural human selfishness by saying at least one person should have been selfless and tried to help their comrade? The answer is no. As an artistic vision if the Writer/Director wishes to deliver a certain message then so be it. That's what art is all about right? But then other problems arise in the course of this film that go beyond artistic license and enter the realm of stupidity. Eli Roth also wishes to add an element of urban fear of the rural folk. By rural folk I don't only mean the hillbillies that run the local shop and teach their young retarded children Wu-Shu Kung fu, but also the law enforcement agencies. When the law learns of the disease the put out a radio call to shoot anyone they see infected on sight. Ummm, yeah. Then when they actually have one at the hospital the local physician suggest they take him to a bigger hospital, where the sheriff decides it'd be better to have the infected person killed. Ummm, right. What about the Centers For Disease control in Atlanta? EVERY law enforcement agency in America knows about this. EVERY hospital big or small knows about this. If an infectious disease breaks out they leap at the freaking phone in an effort to get it off their hands and get the hell out of dodge. It wasn't even mentioned and explained away in the film. It's just stupid stupid stupid. Stupid. Did I say stupid? It was ignored to create the silly irony at the end of the film. I don't know what's more goofy about that ending. The fact that the body was bleeding out into the river which would then contaminate the lemonade... or that those dumb kids found it easier to fill a 9 gallon Gatorade cooler with river water than just run tap water into it! How do you make lemonade from river water with leaves and fish and water moccasins and crap? What is this? Funny?Funny is the noise I made when the black people finally showed up. Actually no I'm not even going to touch that. That was just an ill-conceived disaster.Sorry if there are allot of type errors in this. I wrote it quickly and I'm fairly sure that my 8th grade English teacher would berate me for not having a driving focus through out this commentary. I suppose this is just my general disappointment with the film. What surprised me after my little movie marathon was that I found I disliked JC2 allot. But I expected to. What was unexpected was my dislike of Cabin Fever. That took me by surprise. Sadly.Frank

This movie is a classic. Hilarious, entertaining, and a little bit creepy.Perfect.To me a horror movie has to have either incredible camp value or actually be somewhat frightening. Cabin fever actually accomplishes a ten on each scale. The character of Winston played by a guy named Giussepe Andrews, whom I haven't seen much of since this movie, is hilarious. They play on political correctness, our unhealthy fear of viruses, everything. My only surprise from this movie is that it didn't garner a lot more attention, that it didn't get better reviews, and that the guy who played Winston didn't become a mega star afterwards. seriously, watch it just for Winston.
This movie has turned out to be a classic horror movie. Enjoyable gory dun fun from master Eli Roth. Highly recommended!

Cabin Fever is AWESOME!! Without a shadow of a doubt, one of the premier horror films ive seen in quite a while. Ryder Strong is perfect for his character, and James DeBello is amaizingly hilarious. Great acting jobs by everyone involved -  a definate 4 out of 4 stars on this one.

Review title: Nothing Like I Expected And I Wouldn't Have Wanted It Any Other Way
Review_body: I had been waiting about 2 years to see this movie. I remember reading about it when it was in pre-production and thinking it seemed like a good idea. It was filmed right outside of the city I live in so that made me want to see it even more. I finally saw it tonight and it was absolutely NOTHING like I expected...it was better. I had heard it was very scary and very gross. Both are true. Being an avid horror film fan, I have seen so many scary movies that they don't really scare me anymore. I simply watch them because I love them. However, several times during this movie I did jump. If a movie can make someone who has seen EVERY horror movie jump, it has to be good, right? It also had some very gory scenes but, to be honest, I found the scenes that only implied the gore rather than actually show it to be MUCH more disturbing...sort of the old "what you don't see is worse than what you do see" concept. What I was not expecting was how truly outrageous and off-the-wall this film was. On more than one occasion I was left with mumbling "what the f*** was THAT??!" I guess this really SHOULDN'T surprise me because David Lynch was involved with the making of this film and let's face it: ALL of his own movies tend to leave you scratching your head...to say the least! The comedy was also an unexpected, yet welcome surprise. It gave it a sort of "Evil Dead 2" feel. I feel duty-bound to add here that contrary to the rumours this film is not really ANYTHING like the first "Evil Dead" unless you consider that both films take place in a cabin in the woods (and if that is the only reason for comparison then you might as well say that "Evil Dead" was similar to that god-awful waste of celluloid with Morty the giant puppet called "The Fear"). Several of the cast and crew were at the theatre promoting the film (since it was filmed here). It was fun to talk with them and then see them running around covered in blood on screen. I think Cerina Vincent may well have a promising career ahead of her. Overall, my friends and I decided that we may very well have NEVER seen a movie quite like this but we truly loved it. The whole theatre was laughing one second and screaming the next. I highly recommend this film so go see it! You'll be promoting independent films and having a damn good time, guaranteed!!****1/2 out of 5

While Rider Strong really tried, nothing could save this doomed film.  I like just about any horror movie, but this one needed something.  They might have been able to pull off this plot as a 30 minute twilight zone, but as a movie?  No way.
