Can somebody please explain to me why the girlish-looking boy starts screaming "PANCAKES!!!" at the top of his lungs while going into Jackie Chan moves I've never seen before, and even further biting the guy who has the virus? Why does the father of the kid proceed to get angry with the virus-infected guy, and go on a redneck hunting spree to find him? I was left with a feeling of such confusion and utter disbelief that I literally said out loud, "Where the hell did that come from?"I just simply couldn't believe what I had seen. I really thought I had seen some bad movies, but I have to say that Cabin Fever tops them all. This movie made me want to puke and then puke again. Then blow my brains out.Please, save yourself an hour and a half and do something more productive. Watching grass grow, perhaps, is a proper alternative.

Wow, was this movie a let down for me.  I really was stunned when the credits started rolling, and all I could think about was the $17 I had just spent for the "privilege" of watching this film (for myself + 1).
Talk about a movie that doesn't go anywhere.  It just bounces around here and there, with no real direction, particularly in the latter half of the movie.  It seems like some scenes were just randomly drawn out of a hat and stuck in there.  It was not scary, nor was it funny.  It was gory, I will give it that, but so what?  A few buckets of blood does not a movie make. And what was the deal with that kid on the bench?  Pancakes and karate kicks?  Why?Why all the hype? I don't know.  Bad acting, bad story, bad ending.  The only redeeming part was looking at Cerina Vincent, and I couldn't even do that anymore after that bathtub scene *shudder*.Final score 1.5/10Don't waste your money, unless you like to watch movies that belong on the USA network at 3 in the morning.

this was a really bad movie, i got it cos the cover looked good but my god what a disappointment. It started badly with some dude(the director I think) coming on introducing the movie to us, then we go into 5 kids going somewhere to do something that u never really care about, the characters themselves are not very interesting and u really don't care if they live or die .the girls are underused except when naked and there was to much blood, not enough plot, to many random bloody characters, and the ending had us just shaking our heads going ' are u kidding' save your money and time and have someone poke u hard with a sharp stick, it will have the same effect.

Review title: Best original horror movie of the 00's.
Review_body: Cabin Fever is excellent horror flick, and it does a wonderful job at what it sets out to do. It's a (genuinely) funny horror movie with an original plot (which is rare these days), good acting, GREAT gore, an excellent score, and some fantastic all around weirdness thrown in for fun. I honestly don't understand the negative criticism this movie receives. What is it that people don't like? The tension? The nudity? The death scenes? The violence? The humor? The hopelessness? If so, then what the hell are you doing watching horror movies!? This isn't Final Destination. It's a real deal old school style horror flick. I can only assume the critics were born post 1990 and unfortunately raised on garbage such as Jeepers Creepers. Sad.

This movie was opposite of boring. You're either freaked out or laughing. I thought that this movie, and all other movies made by Eli Roth are always quite different....but the best horror stories I have ever seen....besides "The Shining". In addition, you watch his movies and you think that it could never happen, although you will learn a bit more of reality that most people just don't know about these days. Watch his movies and you will know what I am talking about. Take my advice and go rent "Cabin Fever" and "Hostle" and you will appreciate what you saw. Put it all together, if you are young and love to laugh see this movie a.s.a.p. If you are over 18 (its almost x-rated) and you love weird, odd, freaking movies then go check out "Hostle". Trust me, my boyfriend and I were both in shock when we saw these two movies with how great of a horror movie they actually were, and can't wait till hostel 2 comes out!

This was one of the funniest movies I have seen recently.  I liked the gore-humor combo and the special features and multiple commentaries are entertaining.  Just want to say this movie isn't for everyone, especially those that can't watch a movie without analyzing everything.

Pancakes was the answer to this movie.  The beautifully crafted martial arts adds a more unique flavor to this already awesome film.  This film also contained some hot sex.  Santa makes a cameo appearance in this movie, and at first it seemed like he didn't like black people, but we were all wrong.

This is one of the first horror movies from the US that's actually frightened me in a long time, and also strayed from the usual recipe...Basically four friends go off to a cabin in the woods as an end of term treat, they open the door to a man asking for help, however due to his appearance they refuse to help and then beat him when he tries to steal their truck, and end up setting fire to him. This, along with a local family of rednecks with a wierd son who has a biting fetish adds to the story...What a film!

Review title: Watchable but not good at all
Review_body: I'm a huge horror fan, I've avoided this one until now so I thought I'd give it a watch. Only thing this movie has going for it is the gore. The characters are all unlikable, their dialogue is ridiculous, and their actions are mindless.

It's a fun horror film to watch but certainly isn't the best. What it lacks in plot and storyline it makes up for in very, very gory deaths. The start is good but towards the end it sort of loses it. Funny in parts but not enough to make it an amazing film.

This movie has the ability to spawn hundreds of inside jokes and inspire night after night of shenanigans. I think the problem that most people have with Cabin Fever is that they take it too seriously. I feel the same way about this movie as I do about Shaun of the Dead and other movies like it, there are countless nods to Horror classics, buckets of gore, randomness galore, and more soda-spewing-laugh-out-loud moments than you can shake a stick at. Not to mention, a ridiculous plot, and a former sitcom heart-throb for a main character. Oh yeah, and one more thing... pancakes!!! How can you go wrong?Get a bunch of your campy-horror loving friends together with tons of snacks and possibly alcohol, preferably sometime around 3ish in the morning, and pop in the DVD. Try not to cringe as the flesh-eating virus ravages the college students one by one, then try not to pee your pants as Dennis launches into impromptu kung fu, Bert shoots squirrels, and you experience the very first on-screen death by harmonica. Whoever said this movie is a waste of time is seriously disturbed.

I had heard mostly negative reviews about this movie, but when I saw a 3 star (out of 4 star) rating in a popular magazine, I decided to give it a go (horror movie fan that I am). I really like slasher films, but let's face it, I went into this with no big expectations. I expected the not-so-fabulous acting, overt sex scenes, etc. This turned out to be one of the worst movies I have ever seen. The low-rent, tacky dialog was in a league by itself. We are a family of crazy Irish Americans and by no way prudes, so for us to be offended takes a lot. I wish I could get those 90 minutes of my time back!!! If you want to see a fantastic virus horror movie, see Outbreak. The plot for Cabin Fever was good; too terribly bad the writers and director cheapened it.

This is a great flick that is very loyal and pure to the genre. Eli Roths debut is a seeming success. Whereas it seems that some could view this as a trashy exploitation of pop culture others value its pure brilliance. Driven by its powerful cast the film mirrors slashers of old. Cabin Fever relies on the viewer for its main source of terror. It is within the viewers reaction where the films tension regins. The identification with set killer as well as protagonist sets Cabin Fever as a memorable part of slasher film history. The only complaint may be Roths constant gore at times takes away from the true terror. Regardless this film is definitely worth watching and must be taken for what it is.

I loved this movie.  Nauseating, unnerving, funny, gross, and cool.  Well worth my money and definitely worth a second viewing.  I enjoyed the off beat pacing and homage paid to different great horror movies from the 70's and eighties - each nod with a unique spin making the movie it's own.  The story, performances, and effects present a unique patchwork of paranoia, fear, hopelessness and isolation.If your brain absolutely needs each and every movie you see to follow a strict formula so as to not challenge your ritalin addled, ADD mind - stay home and watch football or "scream 12" or "I know what you did last friday in the ring".  You will probably focus on the fact that the "killer" is not a conscious being, or the odd humor and characters that the director throws in here and there and then, unable to handle any departures from the cookie cutter world of entertainment you've been weened on, begin to whine and complain that this is the worst movie ever.

in my rankings of the worst movies ever made.  I wish I could have voted a zero.  Actually, I asked for my money back from Blockbuster as they should have a sensor to remove films like this one.  I think the people who voted anything above a 1 were just upset at the time they wasted and wanted to trick other people into seeing it so that their misery would be shared. Bad plot, bad acting, bad special effects, yada, yada, yada.  My wife insisted on watching the whole movie in the hopes that it really couldn't be that bad, and something of substance had to be in the next scene. Unfortunately, we both just ended up wasting our time, which we would have much rather spent shaving potatoes.  The only redeeming quality of this movie is that it makes me think of pancakes, and I love pancakes. ps - The Messenger is #1.

The Main jist of "Cabin Fever" is actually pretty clever. Each of the five college kids has some sort of negative issue that consumes them. It does the whole immorality thing from "Halloween" and "Friday the 13th." This suggests that each of them is being punished for their misdeeds. For example, Jordon Ladd's character Karen has drug problems. Her best friend Marcy is very open with her sexuality (tramp), and another guy, Bert is an alcoholic. So since they committed these crimes, Eli Roth (writer/director) is punishing them in the woods. Slowly they are getting killed off by a flesh-eating bacteria that has infested itself in the area. Looking at some of the actually reviews of the film, everyone is optomistic and astounded at "Cabin Fever." But looking at some of the comments other IMDB users had, I realise that they DESPISED the movie with an apparent passion! After watching it and reading everyone's ideas, I think they both have an accurate idea of what it's about- to an extent.Yes- It was unnecessarily gory. Yes- It goes back to our roots of horror in the 80's. Yes- The acting is frightfully corny to a comical extent. AND Yes- This movie perfectly describes how humans react in situations like this, according to instinct. Okay? Still, I give it a 4/10, because the ending bothered me to death. I can't understand what Roth was thinking when he allowed that on screen. His attempts at comic relief feel embarassed in his movie- AND they should be. "Cabin Fever" was still a nice try at reviving old 80's horror flicks. I think some of the critics were looking for something that simply wasn't there- some kind of meaningful symbolism. I also think that the IMDB users are mostly cynical and don't understand what this movie is supposed to be saying. They are so thrown off by some of Eli Roth's bizaare sequences that it has ruined their movie experience. I do suggest you wait until video when watching "Cabin Fever" and don't expect much. Maybe then, what's good about it will come out from the bloody background and you won't be so bitter towards it.

This movie was praised, so I was curious, but deeply disappointed. It was full of clichés, like the young people driving into the woods for vacation, local people who just get after them, corrupt police. The characters are just stereotypes. Heck, if they were only stereotypes, there would at least be somebody to care about in some way. The characters were scripted in way that makes them totally unbelievable. There is no motivation for them to do the things they do. No one of the five people really cares that they torched a sick man. They dump their sick friend in the shed and wait for the night and half a day to start getting medical help, and abandon these tries pretty soon. The script was totally unbelievable, just lining up events. The actors were not able to transport something interesting either and the directing was dull. It was crap. Why does anybody think this movie is exciting or inventive. Everything has already been done over and over again by other and better movies.

I'm sorry to say this, but this is one of the worst films I've ever seen. I just can't believe how stupid it was! Instead of being scary, it ended up being funny, that's how stupid it was. I wouldn't recommend it because there are many really good horror films out there to watch, so try to find them!!!

This movie is awful. There is no suspense no action, mostly just a series of F-bombs dropped by unsympathetic characters. The unbelievable behavior of the characters who make little or no effort to save their dying friends. The complete stereotypical characters. The Horny couple the long time friends who both seem to want and the dumb jock like character. If that isn't enough in walks the skater from California whose sole purpose seems to be to own a dog that later kills one of the main characters. As if that isn't enough the filming techniques used look as if they were learned by the director in last weeks film class. Please save your self from getting sick watching this movie

Review title: the movie sucked....just my personal opinion
Review_body: Other people I have spoken to about this movie liked it, the only reason I watched it in the first place was parts of the movie was filmed in Davie County which is where I live. Now I did buy the movie, why would I buy a movie that I think sucks, only one reason. My first cousin Donald Lee Hall Jr is in it, even though he has a very small part. I do support my family in whatever they decide to do.When I spoke to my uncle Donald, D.J.'s dad I told him I thought the movie sucked. So it's not like they don't know what I think about it, but like I said it is my on personal opinion.So that is my thoughts on this movie.....Sharon Lea Hall Roberson

Review title: Should Die of Its Own Fictional Disease
Review_body: This is probably one of the worst films i have ever seen. The events in it are completely random and make little or no sense. The fact that there is a sequel is so sickening i may come down with a case of cabin fever (I'M SO SORRY). I describe it as bug being smooshed to a newspaper because it seems to be different parts of things mixed together. e.g Kevin the pancake loving karate kid is just freakishly weird on its own, then there's the cop who is slightly weird and perverted, then the drug addict, then there's the fact that they attack some random guy who clearly needs help. then all of a sudden the main character is having sex with his friends girlfriend just because she says something stupid about a plane going down. then at the end some good old family racism followed by a rabbit operating on Kevin the karate kid. Its actually pretty despicable that they can use racism as a joke in this film. There is no reason for anyone to enjoy this film unless you love Eli Roth, even that did not make me like this film. Hate is a strong word but seeing as it is the only word i am permitted to use it will have to do. BOYCOTT CABIN FEVER 2!!!!!

Hello my name is Nicole Scott. I work for a movie theather. I went to see what Cabin Fever is all about. The movie had no plot. At least one that made no sense. It wasn't scary at all. It was more of a great laugh. So did the rest of the audience. Acting was bad. Complete disappointment. If I had spent the money to see this movie I would have died. Why did they make this movie? I would like to know. Plot had so many holes. Copying sences like from Carrie and the Matrix. If  I  wanted to pay for some laughter I would have gone to Uncle Funny's. Don't see this movie unless you feel the need to laugh or waste time.

I have seen this movie at Toronto Film Festival"s midnight maddness program.I love watching films in film festivals and ths one was the last film that festival showed that day.I was very sorry festival was finishing ,it hearts sooooo  much.However film was very well done horror.Ijumped a few times from my seat.It was a closing movie for midnight maddness program. If Eli roth himself contact me ,I would be very happy ,I would like to ask a few questions to him. Elvan

Review title: True colors come shining through when a flesh-eating virus infects a group of college graduates trapped at a cabin in the woods.
Review_body: I was shocked by Eli Roth's 'Cabin Fever'.  From the title sequence all the way to the ironic tag out, I was enthralled.  Roth had me on a leash.  He understands the horror genre.  After the movie, my girlfriend vomited and vowed never to return to the theater with me again, unless it's 'The Lion King' at The Pantages.   Mark my words, we will see great things from Eli Roth and we all might vomit.

A fine thrill ride with a good blend of scares and laughs. I saw it on opening day with a crowd that clearly got the jokes and were scared out of their seats on occasion. It would be a ten, and a horror classic, if there wasn't a smattering of screenplay thuds from trying too hard. These broke the trance of beleivability so crucial to the horror experience. Even so, this may become one of those midnight movie staples like Rocky Horror or Eraserhead.

Review title: Pure Entertainment- a great-time = don't miss this one.
Review_body: I saw this movie at the South By Southwest Film Festival, and it rocked! It's the perfect blend of comedy and horror/suspense.  I had the most fun I have ever had at a movie!  Words cannot do it justice, so go see this movie, if you have any sense of humor whatsoever.  I can't wait to see it again, for the first time!

CONTAINS SPOILERS Nothing beats a really well made b-movie, but unfortunately, films with its tongue firmly planted in its cheek always seem to get slated on IMDb. Starship Troopers gets 6.7, Cabin Fever gets 5.1, and it's a real shame that people just don't get it.This is NOT a proper horror film; it is a proper b-movie and should be judged on that. This film has no pretensions - it is not trying to be Godfather II. This wasn't made to scare, it was made to be laughed at and enjoyed. And it's pretty hard not to enjoy this film - all the elements of a good b-movie are there: backward red-necks, pretty teens, gratuitous sex scene, lots of gore, an isolated cabin etc.There is a great supporting cast providing laughs all the way through, not least from Eli Roth's cameo and, of course, the rednecks. Add to that some very memorable scenes (the leg shaving) and some superb photography and you have a winner.Sure, there are plot holes (the disease is never explained), but this film does not for one moment take itself seriously enough to care. If you feel unfulfilled because you need to know, then you really should be watching something else.Once again, this is a tongue-in-cheek teen b-movie that is pure entertainment. If you are after a cathartic experience or genuine scares, you are not going to find it here. But for 90 minutes of fun, there's not much better. This film does exactly what it intended to do, and should be praised for it.8/10

I wasted 5.75 to see this crappy movie so I just want to know a few things:What was the point of the dog being split in half at the beginning of the movie, the disease had nothing to do with being split in half.What was the point of dragging Karen into the shed, she already totally infected her room, they could have just locked her in there where she would have been safer.Why would the Hermit be running around the forest asking strangers to help him when he could have just asked his relative, the hog lady, to take him to the hospital?Why didn't any of the characters bother to walk into town to get help when things started getting bad, are they all really that lazy?Even if Paul was threatened by the guy w/ the shotgun for peeping on his wife, Paul could have just sent Jeff or Bert back to the house to ask for help. the girl he loves is deteriorating.What was the point of the box?Why did Jeff go back to the cabin after he left when everyone else was getting infected, if he was that big of a jerk to leave in the first place wouldn't he have just gone back home?If the police went to all the trouble of gathering up the kids and burning them on the fire pit, why did they throw Paul halfway into the river, it wasn't even necessary for the plot because the water was already contaminated.Who makes lemonade out of river water, that crap has dirt leaves and bugs in it. Why couldn't the two kids have just use the tap water, it was contaminated too, so the stupid ending would still work.

CABIN FEVER REVIEW - SEPTEMBER 13, 2003 ---------------------------------------------------------------Sad as it may sound, I was really looking forward to Cabin Fever. The trailer looked good. Overall opinions and reviews of the film were generally positive. The Toronto International Film Festival marked it as a highlight, some claiming it to be the best film present. So what went wrong?One thing I think we can all be assured of (if not all, then just me) was the growing hype around the film. At least that's what I felt in the weeks leading up to its release. I was generally excited to see Cabin Fever. The film starts out good, and goes along at a good pace, but never really gets any kind of build up to something satisfying. No parts scared me, and very few were startling. In fact, the only scene that really got me was the image of Karen missing her lips. And that's just a general thing I have against people with no lips. That will always bug me.To say Cabin Fever was down right bad is unfair. While the events that happened depicted gore and violence, in certain scenes (like when Bert gets his head blown off) it seems to be scaled back. And by scaled back I'll present an example. Jeff finds Bert on the floor, dead, with his head (assumingly) blown apart. However, we never get to fully see the headless body because a chair is in the way. Nit picking, yes I know, but with a balls out horror flick, I was expecting it to be, well, balls out. Which it wasn't.The two scenes towards the end (with the pancake kid and rabbit headed doctor), not to mention the ending itself, make you wonder if this film was even constructed as one single film. Or in fact had ideas and scenes sewn together from other failed script attempts. This idea is very present, specifically during the ending credits where `the ending credits' are divided up based on the scenes in the film. Not to mention the detail that is put into the campfire stories that are told. To Eli's credit though, I would have to say this was a great attempt in the right direction. Even though it misfired on so many occasions.That said, after the film had finished, I wanted to like it. I really did, but something was holding me back. I was undecided the entire ride home from the theatre. Alas, after much thought I would have to look down on the film. And mainly because I felt the story never materialized the dread the title Cabin Fever is supposed to make you feel.Two films I find dreadful, creepy, and just down right scary are the `Blair Witch Project' and `Session 9'. Despite the flaws both films house, people reading this might be able to pick a part, those are the two films that do it for me every time.(I included the last part as insight to readers to get an idea of my tastes in horror.)

About as clever as a train-wreck.  Trite, obvious, and predictable. Roth takes every horror-slasher film considered a classic, puts them in a blender, drinks it up, then vomits it out on film.  This is supposed to be paying homage?  This movie was a tired retread without any of the redeeming qualities of the original films it was attempting to mimic. Please just go rent Evil Dead, Dawn of the Dead, Friday the 13th, Halloween, Scream, Nightmare on Elm Street, Blair Witch Project...ANYTHING ELSE BUT THIS MOVIE!

Review title: This movie made me have cabin fever
Review_body: I am a huge horror movie buff, I love cheesiest to the most terrifying. This movie was just plain awful. I wanted to leave half way through it but my need to see it improve made me stay. It didn't. I won't even go into the multiple plot holes the movie had. Let's just say the movie explains nothing. The gore and gratuitous violence is no where near clever enough to pull off. The acting, with the exception of the lead was less then poor. I would wait until late night cable for this one folks, at least you won't waste a penny but maybe 90 minutes of your life.

Review title: This is the worst movie I've seen in quite some time . . .
Review_body: yet I continued to watch. I wanted to find out why my cable station rated it at 3 out of a possible 4 stars. I watched all the way to the end and was never satisfied with an answer. The acting was poor, actually atrocious; the plot was incredibly bad; the continuity was unexpectedly poor; the special effects were laughable. I'm not sure why breaking the windows in a truck would result in later being unable to start the vehicle. Why was there so much blood on the outside of the truck when the guy expelled most of the blood on the inside. When did the kids get to him with an accelerant? He couldn't have gone up in flames that way without some help. And why some of the victims contracted the disease a few minutes after exposure, while others were unaffected and the locals seemed not to have any symptoms. What happened to Grim and why did his dog come back alone? Why wasn't the dog infected? These are only a few questions - I could come up with many more, but I'll leave those to other ranters.I wish I could give this "film" a vote of negative 10! Granted, I don't usually watch flicks in the horror genre, but the few I've seen had at least some staying power. I just don't know why I wasted the time to watch this to the end. I guess I kept hoping to find out why the critic gave it such a high rating. I think my suspicions are now verified - there is only one critic working for my cable company!

Whoever at LionsGate green-lite this movie should have their heads examined.. I would so embarrassed to have my name attached to this movie in any aspect.I'm sorry, but this movie was HORRIBLE. The plot line was week at best. The story was driven by 5 characters you could care less about. At one point a new character was introduced. There was no real reason to introduce this character. Then to add insult to injury-we don't see this character for like 20mins, then he ends up dead. Who cares..I understand that story lines are recycled now adays. But at least add some imagination and creativity. Traditional horror films should contain some scary moments or at least be fun and entertaining. Cabin Fever was neither.
Save your money! Turn on the weather channel. At least it would be more entertaining..

Review title: I had a flesh eating virus once.
Review_body: And lemme tell you watching this movie was a worse experience. It was amazingly painful to watch. The premise was ok but i think it was directed by Corky from 'Life goes on'. And the characters were retarded. I think their trip to the cabin was sponsered by Easter Seals.I know there were points where they are trying reallllly hard to be funny. But really all it is sad. I also hear alot of people talking about how the pancakes kid is funny. I am assuming these are the same people that keep the simpson's still on tv.

Review title: One of the best films of the year, no bull.
Review_body: I'd have to say this is one of the best films of 2003. After watching horror films when i was younger its great to see this film and it is excellent to see horror making a comeback. Go the gore! . Excellent effects and production values top off a great story and great night out!

This movie was a total joke. I wasn't sure which they were trying to do, gross you out or turn you on?? (see sex scenes and then extreme violence) The constant battle between to gain control of the group was distracting, and the action started and stopped way too much. The rate of infection varied widely among the people which made it less believeable. You just felt you spent the whole film trying to get in the "groove" of the movie, only to be constantly side-tracked on already presented facts. The make-up and special effects were good, and the actors did a good job playing their roles its just the plot/story needed to be more consistent. In the end, I was glad it was over and would not suggest anyone rent the movie.

Review title: I'm going to try to be as nice as possible...
Review_body: My friends and I spent an afternoon watching this movie (and the DVD extras) and were in a constant state of awe. Initially we expected the worst, but were horrified, shocked and appalled throughout, wondering how in the world anyone would let a movie as horrible as this be created, spawned, forged from the dregs of Satan's vomit. In scene after scene we see unrelated nonsense and random crap that appears to have been thrown together over a three-day weekend of shooting and production. Director Eli Roth tries and tries, but consistently misses the mark-totally misses-in making a Lynch-esque horror movie. At least in David Lynch movies there is some sense made of the weirdness and a connection-somehow-developed between the scenes. This movie had none of that. The acting was horrible, the dialogue was much worse and the plot was about as solid and developed as a morning bowel movement after a night of spicy burritos and cheap beer.Apparently Mr. Roth hoped to `pay homage' to horror movies past, and I noted the `connections.' But if Sam Raimi, Wes Craven and Tobe Hooper were dead they'd be rolling in their graves. Well, maybe not Tobe Hooper.The best part of this movie experience, however, was watching the behind the scenes/making of the movie from the DVD extras. Wow. Do they really think they did something good here? Are the actors really proud of their `work'? They spend 20 minutes kissing each other's butts probably because they know nobody else will. I rated this movie an awkward `1' wishing I could have gone lower.not necessarily a 0, but certainly <1. The only.ONLY.saving grace in this debacle was the gratuitous and repeated sight of Cerina Vincent's lovely breasts. If Jordan Ladd would have joined in I might have given it a 2.but probably not.

Review title: Horror Fans should be happy with this one...
Review_body: I was suprised how much I liked this flick, I was kind of doubting it because of all the hype around it but it was a good decent horror movie. You all know the plot so let's just skip that part. Overall it was a good movie, a good date movie. If your into watching a deadly flesh eating disease whack off a bunch of people. The gore isn't that great, I mean come on its rated R you can only go so far with a rated R movie, the few "gory" scenes that were seen were very quick and most of the time we got the old "close up to the actors face looking horrified and 'scared" look. hopefully there will be a Directors Cut with more and more blood and gore. I'm a big big horror fan and if your one too then you should be very happy.

Maybe the worst "horror" movie in history.  Dumb plot where nothing the characters do make any sense.  Let's see - someone comes to your cabin asking for help and you light him on fire.  That does not bode well for the "hero's" of the movie.  Even with the flesh eating virus running rampant, one couple still has time for a hop in the sack (by the way the best part of the movie though).  I found myself rooting for the virus since all the characters were so easy to dislike.  Not worth commenting anymore.  In the end everyone got what they deserved.  They even left open the chance of a sequel.  Where have all the good horror flicks gone???  This makes a lot of movies look like Gone with the Wind in comparison.

Review title: This one goes up to eleven!
Review_body: Saw the screening of "Cabin Fever" at the Boston Film Festival last night, and all I can say is that it was without a doubt THE best movie I've seen at the festival *ever.* Apparently, I wasn't the only one interested in the movie as they had to open a whole other theater to show it.  "Cabin Fever" is brilliant, funny, full to the brim with reverent yet hilarious references to others of its sadly overlooked genre and well worth the second viewing I intend to give it on opening night this Friday.  Even if you are not a big fan of horror movies themselves but know a little bit about them and have a pretty strong constitution, I highly recommend this movie.  10 stars are NOT enough!

i like this movie because its really gory and has a real good pace the plot is these 5 kids go to a cabin and get a disease what i don't like is that no one dies from the disease which i don't like.that is the whole point of the movie thats like Friday the 13th without Jason killing anyone but it kept me on my toes in most horror films there's 1 thing killing everyone like in nightmare on elm st. Fred Krueger kills everyone but its still a good film.the nerd (Paul)kills a lot of people in the movie like when he puts the stick through tommy which i think is a reference to Dracula by putting a stake through his heart.one thing i don't like is this scene it just shows Paul holding the stick putting it into tommy it doesn't show like it going in him.but i like all the deaths like eaten alive by a vicious dog screwdriver in the ear is my favorite so the deaths are a step in the right direction

Saw the film the other night. The entire cinema was loving this flick. If you enjoy the dark and groteque humour some of us humans posses. Go and See this film.I loved it. Haven't been that entertained in a cinema for a while.

OMG, big horror fan and watched this whole film because some reviews were positive, appreciate all genres of horror i.e. black comedy, supernatural, etc. and could not decide which direction this was going, this is possibly the most random film I have ever seen and feel robbed of 90m of my life, still don't know what it was trying to achieve even after watching, IMDb rating system is not as accurate as they would like to believe methinks.one of the most random story lines I have ever seen, makes no sense whatsoever. Only wish that I did not have to write ten lines about this for review to count as I am scratching for anything good to say about it, worst film I have ever seen and I have watched some bad films but never had to comment about it.

I saw this with my friend Amber last night not expecting much. Really what I was expecting a pointless movie with no plot and tons of gore and bad acting. So I wasn't let down! It was a bunch of people dying very badly. It ended up being very funny just because it was so bad. The best part of the night was when this girl from a group behind us that wouldn't shut up walked down the stairs of the theater tripped and fell. That was the only thing that really was memorable.

Loved this one - sneak preview - expected to hate it - was in line for 45 minutes to get in to this one - it was 2 out of 4000! films chosen from Toronto Film Festival
I was on edge of my chair and kept trying to get up and go to rr - but kept having to hold it because good stuff kept happening.  Scary as @#$% - intense as @#$%the people around me screamed and said they loved it too - a nice surprise...you will have lots to talk about when you leave the theater...going to see it again, but rr before film this time

When I started watching this movie I didn't expect anything great, but I thought it would be a good watch, a solid horror movie.  I expected a B-movie, because what horror movies aren't (other than 28 Days Later). But what I got was one of the worst movies I have ever seen!  The plot was horrible, there was absolutely nothing scary about this movie, and it seemed like it would never end.My advice: don't waste 90 minutes of your life on this piece of crap.

Review title: I looked forward to seeing this, what a TOTAL waste!!!!!!
Review_body: The previews are by far the best thing to come out of this movie, because they made it look 100 times better than it is.  The script, direction, and editing were all terrible.  The acting wasnt much better, but with what the cast had to work with, nobody could have saved this movie. It wasnt scary, but was bloody . .  the flesh eating virus turns skin into a bloody mess and the victims throw up blood everywhere.  The plot was pretty predictable . .5 college kids in a cabin in the woods . .man with virus comes to them for help, they shoot him and set him on fire, he runs off into the woods, eventually the kids start getting sick. The scenes skip from thing to another and so much of this movie doesnt fit together and alot doesnt make sense.  There are attempts at humor, but really those are, in a word, stupid.  My friend and I began our own "Mystery Science Theater" and were openly making fun of how ridiculous it was at the point where a deer ends up being hit by a truck driven by one of the "cabin crew", and almost mauls him to death with its front legs which are protruding through the windshield of the truck and kicking the guy while he just sits there.  After only a few minutes into the movie, it was obvious it wasnt going to be good,  but I kept sitting through this thing because I just knew it had to get better, but believe me, it only gets worse.  They set up the ending paving a way for a sequel . . . .just the thought of that is the only thing scary about this movie!!!!!!!

Review title: Possibly the worst movie ever made
Review_body: Please do not let anyone you know go see this horrible movie.  I was shocked to find out the writer/director/producer was not 13 years old.  Thrown together garbage with no tone.  The "actors" were hopefully all first timers working for scale.  Anyone and I mean anyone can equal this production.Bad acting, no plot and a story that has been done many times over.  All with pathetic attempts at bad humor mixed in.Anyone rating this film above a 1 out of 10 MUST be related to this hopefully soon to be unemployed writer/director.

Review title: A good movie but Gro-O-O-O-O-O-OSS!! Nastiest I have ever seen
Review_body: Cabin Fever is the natiest movie I have ever seen. I knew it probably would be going into the theater because its about a flesh eating virus and I had a feeling the director wouldnt hold anything back.When I first saw the commercials, I thought it was going to be terrible on the sole fact that Sean was going to be in it. But after a while i was sitting there and I was like "wait, this actually looks pretty bad assed" and it was.A lot of people are going to be crap ass nay-sayers and player hate on it. That happens with every horror movie. They will say "the characters should have done blah blah" or "if i made the movie it would have been wikid good. i am wikid good at re-writing other people's movies" Yeah, the characters make some bad decisions. But thats what characters in horror movies do. You cant watch it from a 3rd person perspective and say you have all the answers of what should be done. Life doesnt work that way.One problem some might have with Cabin Fever is that it gets so graphic and nasty that it is a little hard to watch. Although I enjoyed the movie, by the time I left my stomach felt queesy and I couldnt get some of the most disturbing images of the film out of my head for about a full 24 hours.It has good cinematography, wonderfully disgusting skin rotting away effects, and cool direction and i liked it.Was it an awesome movie? naw. Was it good? yeah. I would rank it after Identity and 28 Days Later but definitely before Freddy VS Jason or Wrong Turn.If you're reading this, than you have probably have just read or are about to read a lot of negative reviews. Well, ignore those people. It definitely doesn't deserve the overly-negative reviews a lot of people are giving it. Go see it once with an open mind and a strong stomach.trust me.

I had high hopes for this movie based on the trailers. Now there was some false advertising. It started slow and never got much out of second gear and in the process managed to insult every group represented: stereotypical drunk, self-centered and vicious college students; ignorant, inbred hill folk; neo-nazi AND nerdy cops. I would have given it a 1 except for some brief glimmers of humor. It isn't social commentary, it isn't horror, and it certainly isn't entertainment.

Review title: A failure on nearly every level
Review_body: _Cabin Fever_ is marketed as a horror movie, but it's more than that. It's also part homage (and to some extent, parody), part dark comedy, and part character study. Unfortunately, it not only fails as a whole, it fails on each of these smaller parts as well. Fans of older gorefests will enjoy the Where's Waldo aspect of the film, as the audience is pelted with obvious homage after obvious homage. The writer-director is clearly fascinated with the genre, and the movie suffers from his heavy dependence on and borrowing of the past, because Roth has added nothing innovative of his own.The pacing is completely wrong for a horror movie. The immediate cause of the threat is revealed very early to the audience, and we have to wait in frustration as the bumbling cast manages to botch every effort to save themselves from the unknown. By the time they find out what's going on, it's too late to do anything about it. The characters have wasted their time, and unfortunately, so has the audience.The film dabbles in the surreal, but not the good kind. This is the self-aware "I'm so cool for being weird" surrealism that laces the Faulkner-inspired poetry that litters notebooks in every American high school. My mother is a fish, my mother is a pancake.Except for one or two notable scenes, the gore is rather bland, nothing particularly cringe-worthy or imaginative; you get far more blood, dismemberment, and decapitation in _Freddy vs. Jason_. There are a few cheap scares (an accepted staple of the genre), but any genuine suspense or tension the movie manages to generate is completely lost by the bad pacing, the poorly-timed comedy, the somewhat odd musical choices, the absurd supporting characters stolen from David Lynch's trash can, and the idiotic, unbelievable, and inconsistent main characters who you keep hoping will just die already.On the plus side, the acting is more than passable, and in fact, better than can be found in similar movies. In particular, the shopkeeper's swishy Appalachian twang rang true to this Southerner's ears, though I thought this was set in Texas.If you're looking for a good horror movie on the big screen, skip _Cabin Fever_ and go see _Alien_ when it's re-released. If on the other hand, you applaud weirdness for the sake of weirdness and playing "Name That Homage", you might actually like _Cabin Fever_ for its self-congratulatory randomness.

Review title: Bad Movie? You're Soaking In It.
Review_body: Something i've noticed over the past decade or more (and these days most of all)is the horror film maker's attempt to include too many elements of the action and comedy genres in an attempt to appeal to a bigger audience.  If I want a comedy, I'll go see a comedy.  I don't mind a little comic relief and I love dark humor when it is done in a subtle and meaningful manner.  I like a horror film that just beats the living hell outta me.  I want to come out of the theater truly shaken and effected.  Cabin Fever is played too much for laughs and the jokes just aren't that funny.  Just kinda stupid and pointless.  I found myself too often annoyed at characters like Party Cop, Grim and The Karate Kid who just had nothing to do with anything.  I've not seen as pointless a character as Grim since a real turd of a movie called Scared Stiff.  He's there to supply a crazy dog and a dead body to stumble over at the end of the movie.  I keep hearing that horror audiences want the humor these days and it is fairly apparent that this is true but if this is what they want, then aren't they missing the point of a horror movie?  I dunno.  I give this thing good marks for it's excellent and effective gore make-up and the little bit of tension that it did have, but too many things about it made no sense and didn't need to be there.  I've never walked out on a movie in my life.  No matter how bad it was.  But I came damn close with this one.  The last 10 or 15 minutes were pretty hard to sit through. Just got more and more ridiculous.  I find myself wondering about the rabbit suit guy in the hospital.  Was this a clumsy attempt at a metaphor for the guy in the beginning of the movie who was apparently hunting rabbits?  Was his dog supposed to have gotten the virus from eating an infected rabbit? Wasn't really made clear, so the rabbit suit guy seemed rather pointless. Just got another "huh?" outta me.  Maybe the rabbit escaped from an animal research lab up-river from the cabin, huh?  There.  I'll just fill in all the holes with my own story.  Then maybe this film won't hurt so much. Matter of fact, watching this thing actually gave me a head-ache that lasted 6 hours. Only 2 aleve got rid of this movies residue.  So...to sum up...too many stupid jokes.  Not scary enough.  And just bad film making in general. There.  I feel better.And please, this is not a forum for opinions of opinions. Reviews are nothing but someones opinion.  That's from you and me on up to Mr. Ebert. One man's trash is another man's treasure.  It's all subjective, guys.  No need to take it personally if someone doesn't like the movie you liked.  I hated this movie, but why would I sit here and put someone else down for liking it?  Let's try to grow up and be nice to fellow humans.

This movie would have been worth the money and time if the audience were given some sort of remote device to pick what was going to happen next. Very easy to figure out. Too bad I can't demand my money back. Total waste.

This movie was awful.  What a low budget D movie. Can't believe all the hype about it, very misleading!  There is no plot and things do not make sense during the movie. It will leave you dumbfounded.  Where do they get the money to make movies like this.  No good actors or acting here!!

Halfway through this movie I just didn't care who died or how they were going to die.  There was no suspense it was JUST A DISEASE, one that didn't shock me by the gore nor make me squirm at the situations.  I did however enjoy the humour in the movie intentional and otherwise.  Afterwards I felt as if Roth had kept us seated for 90 minutes just for the gun gag at the end which was set up at the beginning and everything in between was just a self-indulgent homage his favourite films.To say that this is up there with the best is very off the mark, it was neither scary nor thrilling.  Yes there was lots of gore and blood but that does not make a good horror flick if there are no intentions to keep your audience on the edge of your seat, which my friends and I certainly were not.  My only good thing to say of this movie is reading the reviews after I watched it which did remind me of some good moments in the film I had forgotten due to the rest being pretty dull and boring.

The problem with this movie is that it wasn't scary enough to be a horror film and wasn't funny enough to be a comedy.Director Eli Roth consistently sets up workable horror premises and at times creates a tense and unnerving atmosphere, but then he'll pop a joke in, either surreal or aimed at debunking the conventions of the horror genre. Time after time I was left wondering whether I'd seen a promising horror scene ruined by casual directing or whether I'd seen a very poor attempt at a postmodern gag.However, if I'd have known that this was a camp, kitsch cult movie I would have liked it an awful lot more than I did, because I was constantly waiting to be scared. The only horror element this movie really delivers are the endless shots of dismembered bodies, blood, gore, decaying flesh, people vomiting blood all over each other etc. But oddly these scenes aren't really all that kitsch - I found them as funny as the endless succession of murders in City Of God or the relentless intensity of the first half hour of Saving Private Ryan. i.e. not funny at all, just mildly disturbing and unpleasant.
There's plenty of gore, but every bit of psychological tension is scuppered by the director - either deliberately or by accident. After sitting through the movie, talking to plenty of people about it and reading all the comments on iMDb, I'm still not sure which he was trying to achieve.

While I admit that I laughed harder while watching this movie than I have in years, something still bothers me. The whole rotting to death thing could have been avoided if that group of ass-clowns had any sense. I mean, if I ever contract some horrible flesh eating virus, I hope that my friends would not think that the best thing to do would be to lock me up in the wood shed and leave me to either rot away or be eaten by a psychotic dog. Then beat me with a shovel instead of shooting me to put me out of my misery. Also, they only tried once to get a signal on their cell and made no real effort to get to town because the truck wouldn't start. Getting help just didn't seem like a huge priority. It was like every character in the movie made the worst decisions possible, at all times. Right down to the kids that made lemonade to sell out of river water, which was obviously much easier to gather than water from the tap! Jeez!

This is really a movie to watch when u just want to be entertained. When u dont wanna think bout characters, plot-lines etc.. It had great gory scenes, terrific humour, some sex. What could u wish more?

This movie was one of the worst movies I have ever seen. completely and utterly pointless.I was looking for a good horror film and made the mistake of reading a recommendation for this film in someones "best of horror" list here on I.M.D.B. I will not be considering any other movies on that list for viewing. This was essentially a movie about a severe case of the flu. One of my pet peeves about a bad movie is what the characters do in unusual circumstances that NORMAL people in the exact same situation would not do. In this movie there are many, many instances where I found myself laughing at the absurdity of the main characters choices when other clear and OBVIOUS choices were available to them. But then the characters lack of common sense is perfect for a movie of this sort since it serves the purpose of advancing the mindless script. One such example found a woman riddled with the "Cabin Fever" shaving her not so pretty "Cabin Fever" legs. Another had two of the main characters "making out" while one of their friends was under quarantine, deteriorating in a shed from the cabin "bug". Nice, huh? Another thing I found irritating was the predictability throughout the movie. On a few occasions I was calling out the outcome before it even happened to the point that my son, who was watching it with me, kept insisting that I had seen the movie before. I had to assure him that Dad was having the hardest time watching it right then and there let alone having sat through it once before. This movie is easily one of the worst horror films (or any other genre for that matter) that I have ever seen. I could have done better. Makes me think that I should have been a film director instead of a "can jockey" at the neighborhood grocer.

Please children, stop slamming great horror achievements unless you've done your homework first.  Everyone in the know will be championing this for some time and with good reason.  See kids, those of us who grew up watching all the B horror movies from back in the day realize what real horror movies are supposed to achieve.  Like how funny it is to see someone cut up their girlfriend with a chainsaw or how refreshing it can be to see zombies eating "BRAINS!" out of a bloody skull.  Get it now?  No, I didn't think so either. Eli Roth and crew have opened up a can of maggot infested worms with this gem.  I think everything about this flick is incredible e.g. plot,acting,dialogue and deserves its place in any horror fans collection. It pays homage to all the greats by extracting the essence of old school horror and laces it with a nu skool twist.  To all the disbelievers, stick to jeepers creepers and resident "what a great plot" evil and tell Flo to kiss my grits, noonch.  Blaze up for the rotten fruit and support indie horror.  nuff said.

Everyone is taking this movie much, much too seriously.  I think the problem is the trailers.  When this movie first was released, the trailers made it seem to be something that it is not.  It's only downfall is the way it mislead viewers.It was meant to be this way.  It is a high-grade B movie that was made in the spirit of "2000 Maniacs."  The randomness of supporting cast is just that, meant to be something random.  Made to make you say-WTF?Because it was meant to be a shlocky gore-fest, and clearly an homage to so many great 70's horror films, I give it a ten.  Yes, people I said a ten. I actually felt like I was watching a movie that was made in the 70's.Just rent the DVD, sit back and allow yourself to have some unadulterated fun, you just might enjoy yourself.

Do yourself a favor and never watch this movie. The characters seem to do things totally at random, the script is incredibly stupid, the actors are totally unbelievable.  This is the worst movie I've ever seen.

Review title: A couple of reasons why this bird don't fly!
Review_body: I guess it didn't meet my expectations.  I think Eli Roth is more capable than this movie... I think Rider is above it too.  Though the director wanted to pay homage to the late 70s and 80s horror films, they produced a gore flick instead.  I'm not going to mince words... as much as I like the cast and all, the movie's main drawback was in its plot. Simply put, if you want to make a good horror movie, follow the rules of the game.  The closest movie that works in the paradigm is John Carpenter's The Thing.  In the Thing you are studying something extraterrestrial which is borderline supernatural and you learn about its motives, wants and needs. Cabin Fever's phage is organic, and causes its victim's flesh to become putty and fall off... there is no knowledge gained, so its just plane ol' flat.  Its a gore flick relying mainly on bloodsyrup/mix, and it misses horror completely. I recommend the book The Philosophy of Horror for this director.  I think it will benefit him in identifying what it is that makes horror movies work beyond gore.  Eli Roth, uses a flesh eating phage as his "monster" that quickly eats away his unwilling and unmotivated victims.  There is no mystery as to who is infected or what the outcome will be. Roth doesn't do an effective job of turning his group against each other and breaking their trust. IMHO, There is very little motivation for the characters to do the things they do, or feel the way they do... a girl gets eaten by this thing and I'm left flat, because there is really nothing I feel about wanting her character to stay alive, the relationship hasn't been identified as something worth saving. Now, if Rider's character, Paul, was able to resist the virus because of interferon produced from the bite he received on the onset of the film... an immunity from a competing organism that counteracted the phage, then you might have something: a story about one guy trying to keep his group together and his film alive. Again... Roth needs to do more R&D on the script end before bringing it into production.

Although I would never recommend anyone not to watch a film as everyone will have their own tastes, I do wonder what Cabin Fever has to offer anyone. The storyline is wafer thin and barely entertaining and it simply is neither scary. There is a mere one scene in the entire film you may at least give it some credit for but it's simply cringe worthy and not scary.
Towards the end I found this film bordering on comical and when the credits rolled all I could think was what a waste of time and money. The film provides nothing that virtually every other modern day horror film doesn't do 10 times better. Simply put this comes bottom of my pile at the moment when it comes to my choice in films and it will take some beating to lift it from that position.

This movie actually had an okay plot...really. It did. But this movie also soaked up all the blood and gore it could get. Such being the bowling scene where Paul is sitting around the camp fire with his friends, telling the tale of an old crime that went on at a bowling alley he and his dad went to. Now, come on. I was already a little nauseous from seeing so much blood BEFORE this. Was that scene REALLY necessary? I swear, halfway through the movie, I had to pause it because I thought I was going to vomit. So if you are looking for a really graphic sex scene or so much blood that you think it could fill the ocean, I recommend this movie for you. If not, well, I might suggest picking something else for movie night.

Review title: This movie has everything: Blood, Sex, and PANCAKES!(a few minor spoilers, but nothing big)
Review_body: This is one of those movies that is so bad, that it is great. The plot half makes sense, but who really cares. It's not meant to be pondered on too much, but it can create days of conversations. My friend and I happened to see it on the same day and talked about it for an entire month, if not longer! Whenever we passed each other in the hallway, we would yell out PANCAKES, and just got used to the weird looks. We even thought of naming a band Don't Sit Next to Dennis. How great would that be!Anyway, I haven't even really talked about the movie much. The gore is absolutely fantastic. It was overdone so realistically... But if you think about it, what would it look like to see all of your skin fall off and your body basically decay from the inside out? Whatever you do, don't shave when you're in that situation (how stupid was that?) But besides the sickeningly awesome effects, this movie is hilarious. There are crazy hillbillies, a disturbed child that can do karate, and a random guy in a bunny suit. What more could you want. I bet you didn't even know that you wanted it. : )If you want to be grossed out and laughing for days, you'll love this movie. It's bound to become a cult classic, if it isn't already, much in the style of Evil Dead. It's great to watch with squeamish people without warning them - you'll laugh even more, well until they vomit on your carpet.

I will admit I am not a huge horror fan, but I do enjoy the genre and this is a movie that I felt really pulled it off nicely. The thing that makes this movie so frightening is the real factor. In most horror movies we see today it is the masked maniac or a possessed doll or even a freak show who gets into your dreams, but this movies "enemy" was an actual flesh eating disease. Now I'm not a medical expert, but I would assume the virus wouldn't spread that fast, but it's a movie you have to pull some strings. I thought Rider Strong did a great job with his role especially how his character changes throughout the movie and after recently having watched Grind I thought Joey Kern did a great job too playing a very different character. Now no movie is obviously perfect and the movie does have certain flaws, but I really thought it came together nicely and kudos to Eli Roth for a new approach. To sum it up I'd say it's at least worth a rental especially if you're into the genre and I suggest you approach the movie with not great expectations which seemed to happen after all the praise the movie got which left many people disappointed because when they saw it they were expecting a perfect movie. All and all 7/10.

Don't waste your time viewing this garbage. It's looks like was written by five different writers. Bad directed, bad actors, bad camera placement,stupid characters, etc. This thing looks like the son of 28 Days Later with Friday the 13. The scene with the pancake child ? I'm still looking for a reason for this scene.Where the virus come from? This movie leave so many questions with no answer, It's made Donnie Darko looks like a Disney movie. A ridiculous screenplay made by people that think we are going to watch every piece of garbage they send to the theaters. Make yourself a favor and stay away from this poor excuse of a movie.

I seriously don't know wtf people are talking about when they say this movie is bad. 'Cabin Fever' has been one of my favorite horror movies ever since it came out, and I think Eli Roth is a great writer and director. It amazes me that people go into watching ANY horror film expecting good acting. That is not what they're about. Go watch 'The Shawshank Redemption' or 'The Godfather' if you want to see first-rate acting and writing.Horror films are supposed to scare you, gross you out, and be nothing more than pure fun, and that's exactly what 'Cabin Fever' is. I think the humor in Cabin Fever is what puts a lot of people off. People aren't used to seeing funny horror films, so when they do see one they automatically think it's weird and stupid. 'Cabin Fever' is hilarious from beginning to end, and it's completely gross and over the top.All of the best horror films I've ever seen got bad ratings thanks to people who watch them and don't even like horror films in the first place. But that's okay, because real horror fans know that 'Cabin Fever' is up there with the best around.

Review title: Only watched an hour of this film
Review_body: This movie was bad from the start. The characters were goofy. You could not take any of them seriously. The entire budget was spent on a cheap nude shot and the movie just went straight downhill from there. Someone owes me an hour of my life back. It was pure torture watching that first hour. I think I might have poked my own eyes out if I had to watch anymore of it. The music was bad too. Did this movie even have a budget? This movie did not scare me or creep me out in the least. If anything it really made me feel sorry for the actors. Not worth the plastic on the DVD it was recorded on nor the postage that Netflix had to spend to send it to me. The best thing that could happen to this film is if it got lost in the mail on the way back to Netflix.

Review title: This movie is worth calling Amnesty International for cruel abuse of the viewer.
Review_body: -> teens decide to rent a cabin in a forest -> a man is infected by a mysterious virus -> man infects teen -> teen infects teen2 -> teen2 infects strange man -> strange man infects his dog (?) -> teen3 is infected, because man with mysterious virus fell into a water reservoir -> teen3 infects teen4 -> teen4 infects teen5 -> everybody is dead -> viewer survived movie (surprising but true!)I don't know who made this movie and to be honest I don't want to know, because I truly regret viewing this flick ... please oh god make me forget this awful flick :[ Go watch The Ring if you want a good thriller/horror which is not horribly bad.

I watched this pointless, tediously narrated movie with growing restlessness. Has some ideas and bursts with ambition, as it tries to deliver characters and relationships(rarely seen in a horror/gore - flick), but drowns them in trash and subterranean execution. The whole mullet kid/making fun of hillbillies part is totally cliché, the horror story gathering momentum is just uninteresting and without suspense or even shock. The rudimentary love story was completely useless and ineffective, as was the hermit with his dog, the young cop etc...What did the writer/director think when he made up the local residents around the lake. What was the point in finding out who the hermit was? Or what about the pig slaughtering lady? No point in that! This movie leaves so many loose ends, as it leads to nowhere. You get quite some story fragments, none of which are developed/used/revisited throughout the movie. It's just linear/twist - less narration. All the time you exactly know what is going to happen next... The ending tries to be pessimistic 70ies horror with a cynical/humorous edge (which before dragged through the entire movie).The only wish that rose in me watching this was to see everyone die so it can end...

Review title: Too Many Questions After Watching This Movie!
Review_body: So I just watched the DVD and I really didn't enjoy it. I can certainly appreciate (after reading some of the other IMDb member reviews) that it's a B-movie now, so that explains a lot of it. But there were just too many questions in my head once I was done, to say I really enjoyed the movie. I was left at the end wishing that we were at least told (1) where the disease originally came from and (2)whether or not it's ever stopped. I was led to believe that it WASN'T stopped, because the police bought and drank lemonade from those kids, who made the lemonade from contaminated stream water. You also never find out what the "party man" deputy does with the kid from the hospital at the end, either. You assume he's going to kill him, but... I was also really curious about what was in "the kit" that the hillbillies brought with them when they went after the kids in the cabin. The one carrying "the kit" got it in the ear with a screwdriver before he could open the box! If anyone could shed some light on all of this for me, I would greatly appreciate it.
Simply not worth your time. It's neither scary, funny nor dramatic - irredeemable garbage.

Review title: True American film values at their best
Review_body: A display of true Americal values; shot with quintessential American intelligence and displaying the finest of American acting talent.Thank heavens for British cinema!This film has absolutely no redeeming features, save for the fact that all of the main, valley-speak, clichéd characters end up dead. Perhaps the greatest tragedy here is that the 'actors' themselves will of course remain very much alive to spawn similar rubbish. Like most American film these days this complete waste of time offers no artistic value whatsoever. The one-dimensional characters do not even offer a parody of Americans today, as anyone who has had the misfortune of encountering dumb American youth can attest to.

When I first saw the trailer for cabin fever I immediately thought, bloody,unoriginal, teen horror movie. But to my surprise Eli Roth's low budget directional debut was an impressive re-invention of the cult 80's horror classics. The movie's shire simplicity and originality set It aside from the rest of the old cliché horror films and made out to be an enjoyable one-watch flick.The low-budget is recognisable when it comes to the special effects and the cast but the original script made a decent change from all them brutal slasher movies set in the woods. The basic premise of the film is about a group of college kids who decide to travel to a isolated cabin to get drunk and high, nothing special there. But when they start to get infected with an unusual flesh eating disease the group turn on each other and it becomes a battle to survive.I wasn't expecting much from the film but considering the low-budget and quality of filming I was pleasantly surprised. The movie made a name for director Eli Roth who won multiple awards and became a big hit with director Quentin Tarantino.

In a funny way I actually became obsessed with this movie. The main reason being because it was so bad. I had to watch it again and again and kept talking about it because I couldn't believe just how stupid some of the script was. It will make you laugh but also cry because of how pathetic some bits of it are. However, if you enjoy watching gory stuff, this is a good one. I have to say that side to it matched up to my expectations. I absolutely hate "Teen movies" so maybe this is why I found the script terrible but perhaps if you like those kind of films you won't think it is that bad. In all, it is one of those movies that is a good one to rent out but only watch it once (and if you are feeling depressed then don't watch it at all)

I love cheesy horror-flicks, so I was pleasantly surprised when a colleague brought this movie into work for the night-shift. Sadly, I was extremely disappointed!I get what Eli Roth was trying to do - create a homage to the cheap gore 'n' giggle films of the 80's. But boy-oh-boy, didn't he miss the mark on this one! To create a true homage, the direction has to have intelligence... this, however, was just plain awful in EVERY respect!In short, it resembled an un-entertaining parody of 80's horror devoid of any humour or smarts.Avoid at all costs!

Review title: complete and utter formula-based clichéd rubbish
Review_body: Terrible. Utterly Terrible. What a waste of a blank DVD. I want the money I paid to rent it back. This is a total insult to horror fans. What were the people involved in this movie thinking? Money - nothing else. Its what you would call a well-packaged turd. No Plot. No Point. Nobody actors. I'm looking for more stuff to say about it as they tell me you need a minimum of 10 lines to submit a review, but I said it in the summary. There really isn't enough to write about. It all boils down to one word I suppose - kak. Its a word we use a lot down in this part of the 3rd world. Hell, I thought you guys in the 1st world were supposed to set an example!

Review title: This movie is so bad my dog won't eat it
Review_body: I only give this film a 2 because it did have a lot of gore. It was pretty good until it got halfway through the movie then it took off in about three different directions. I do not know who was smoking dope, but it must have been everyone to let that movie get released. There are few movies I would like to get my money back for, but this is definitely one of those movies. It was so bad by the end I had to lie down and take a nap. Hopefully the director (the one responsible for this travesty of good movies) had his eyes and mouth sowed shut, he should never direct again. I hear now that they are going to release a Cabin Fever 2, God save our souls. I would not watch it, even if they sent me a copy for free. Who licks their own butt then goes back for seconds. Not this camper. I still have a bad taste in my mouth, and it is from the movie. My girlfriend says I should tell everyone it is a horrible movie, but I do not think that says enough about how bad it is.

As they say, critics have the right to express what they think. But do they have to be so harsh and so... like... hello?! With all those things that they say about movies being "a pile of crap!", GIMME A BREAK! Give em a chance will you?! It's not like you own the whole movie world or something! Okay, okay... so that's a bit too "touchy-feely" right? But thats beside the point. The point is... some guys out there( or maybe even girls ) just can't seem to cool off or relax a bit. I guess that's what they say about spoilers, "spill of whatever you want and get all the attention you deserve!". For me, that is SOOOOO SURREAL! How low can other people get huh?! Well, okay, enough about emotional distress and psycho-speak, lets move on to business. This movie was downright disappointing at the start. For me, it had a lot of downfalls. There was a lack of motivation, the characters are bloody boring, and the village perks are a total insanity. Why did they have to get all those set-ups when its not so significant? I mean this movie could be better if they worked on it much more. But overall, Cabin Fever somehow got my eye(i don't why) I mean if i didn't like the movie, why put up this comment anyway. This is why i prefer to stay in the middle despite everything negative about it. There may be hope for Cabin Fever if the viewers could learn to understand a little more. And for the last bit, I'm now a fan! I don't know why! It must be worth something after all those reactions. I still liked it in the end... And because of Cabin Fever, i'm now writing a revised version of it in another style. you wanna see? Well, hope you could! I made this story all of a sudden because of a weird vision! And... its a TRUE STORY! Only, no IMMORALITY ALLOWED! Just something i wish could come out well soon because i'm still working on it. Hope Eli Roth could read this! Godwilling! I really want him to read my own story out of Cabin Fever and see what he thinks about it! But I can only hope... If ever there's a chance! (",) PS: Just watch it if you want to, not by what others say about it. Its all up to you if you want or not; all that matters is that you'll have fun or have the bore of your life! Don't get tricked into changing your own perspective of this movie by just a mere comment on this site! It's all in your own hands! Just don't be too hoggish and too immature to understand some certain things... This movie still has a bit of "thang" in it. YOu'll see soon enough... Things may turn out different you know! Have fun! OR better yet.. Good Luck!

Review title: Amazing rehash of the horror genre
Review_body: I cant believe all of you morons writing a review for a genre you obviously don't understand. Cabin Fever is great on all accounts. In an era where Hollywood is trying to capitalize on everything and ruining the Horror genre (aka Texas Chainsaw remake, Freddy vs. Jason, etc,), CF totally gives its nods to classic genre defining films and directors (Romero, Hooper, Craven, Jackson, to mention a few). The key era of Horror in my opinion, and most other Horror enthusiasts, was the 70s and 80s (low budget B movies to be exact). Where do you think such amazing directors of Hollywood got their start? Peter Jackson- from "Bad Taste" and "Dead Alive" to "The Lord of the Rings," and Sam Raimi- from "Evil Dead" to "Spiderman." Why remake classic movies into some horrible high budget blockbuster (Texas Chainsaw, Amityville Horror, etc.) when you can just remake the genre in a way? Everything is all about being retro these days. Musically for example, the whole "garage rock" movement is being regurgitated through the likes of horrible bands like the White Stripes and the Strokes trying to be a new version of the Stooges. At least Eli Roth (director of Cabin Fever) knows where he is coming from. Cabin Fever is for the true fans of B Horror. If you respect movies like Zombie, Basketcase, Maniac, Night/Day/Dawn of the (Living) Dead, then Cabin Fever will be your new favorite. I was honestly skeptical about seeing the movie after new mainstream horror movies, but buying Cabin Fever was the right choice. Humor and gore make horror. No matter what you say. Cabin Fever is hilarious and gory enough for horror lovers. I am looking forward to seeing Roth's movies that he is planning currently. on a footnote...I was so into this movie that I watched it approximately 5 times in the first couple of days I had it. As a matter of fact, I'm watching it right now.

Review title: One of the worse movies I've ever seen
Review_body: If I had to choose a Top 10 of worst movies I've ever seen, Eli Roth's Cabin Fever would be a very close tie with the first three Faces Of Death movies as the #1 worst movie I've ever seen. I couldn't stand sitting through this piece of trash for more than 5 minutes without hating every single last character in this film. It starts off with a bunch of unlikable morons in a pointless setup to a very unfunny race joke that doesn't get resolved until the very end, said joke involved a redneck store owner implying that a rifle is meant for "n!ggers", when really the punch line is that this redneck is trying to speak jive without knowing how to phrase such language and the gun belongs to the African American customers and he meant to say "N!gga". That's the caliber of humor in this pile of garbage and it get worse and worse as the minutes go by, and the thing is the concept could have made for a decent horror film but ends up screwing itself over so much that you want to take an angle grinder to your temple to get out of it.

I am in love with this movie!!! I got it because I love James DeBello and I was very pleased with how well it turned out! I think all the actors were perfect for their roles and the story line was amazing! I like the idea of doing a horror movie without just a killer you have to get away from. I also thought that the humor fit perfectly with the movie and I loved the acting done by James DeBello! He was by far my favorite actor in this movie but I thought all the actors did an amazing job and made the story very believable! I was so sad to see all the characters die in this movie! This movie got you to know and like the characters, and it was sad to see them die. But it worked for the movie and I enjoyed it very much! I watched this movie over and over again and I think I will in the future! Well mad props guys and I hope you love watching it as much as me!

Review title: Response to the "last 30min went to pot" guy...
Review_body: As a response to the guy who complained the "last 30min went to pot."...Dude, you just didn't get it.Eli Roth even points out in the DVD features that such things as: the deer through the windshield, Winston, the bunny suit, etc... Were put in because if they didn't have the audience at the 3/4 mark, who the *#&$ cared? Those of us who WERE with the filmmakers by 3/4 through, nearly died laughing. Oh horror-comedies, why are you so great? Sigh!----------------- And not to beat the issue to death, but *grabbing beating stick*, if a flesh eating hobo-disease, and shooting squirrels ('cause they're gay), and...uh...DENNIS didn't strike you as "over the top" but a guy hitting a deer (albeit a ridiculously fake ones with lovely kicking feet!) with his car did...well...good luck to you sir! You'll need it!

I have a habit of loving films that are so dumb and so terrible that I should feel ashamed that I love them. Cabin Fever is one of those films. The gore (which I was expecting a lot more of, having seen Hostel) didn't scare me one bit, and I'm easily freaked out by horror standards. The characters were all idiots, except the whiny blonde guy Jeff, who actually did an incredibly smart (although somewhat gutless) thing by running away from the rest of the gang and NOT drinking the water. (I'll admit, I was actually pretty annoyed that he died eventually, if only because I had a slightly twisted little crush on him.) If they'd all just stayed away from each other and drank beer ... well, there wouldn't have been a film, but it was the one thing that made the most sense in a pretty much senseless film.
